PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —On Monday I received written advice from my department that a pilot review of rent assistance recipients in public housing had found that 100 per cent claimed more than the rent which would be paid to the State Housing Authority by a couple on a social security payment with a dependent child or would be paid by a sole parent with a dependent child. I repeated that advice in the information I gave to the Senate. Today I have been informed that the figure of 100 per cent is not accurate and that it is not possible at this stage to provide an accurate figure. For that, I apologise to the Senate. I very much regret that that information was given.

SPEECH.PARA: I am able to inform the Senate of the basis for the estimates and provide the department's advice to me about the number of households in this situation. I turn to the basis for the estimates. The calculation of savings from the measure are necessarily estimates. For privacy reasons, it is not possible to collect all the necessary data until the legislation has been passed. The definitive figures will not be known until matching has been completed with data supplied by state housing authorities. The data on which the estimates are based, therefore, is not conclusive but it is indicative.

The estimates of savings assume that 44,000 people will be affected by the measure. These estimates are based on review activity and computer matching to identify rent assistance recipients in public housing covering four areas in regional and metropolitan New South Wales covering 4,942 dwellings. This was complemented by pilot reviews of 60 people in one location to survey rent assistance recipients in more detail.

The proportion of dwellings containing rent assistance recipients ranges from 10 per cent to 24 per cent but over the four areas totalled 21 per cent of these dwellings. In developing the costings, allowances were then made to cater for houses attracting market rents and factors such as movement in and out of public housing. It was assumed that those affected were being paid at the average level of rent assistance—that is, less than the maximum rate—being paid at the time.

I turn to the number of households where the principal tenant is charging subtenants more than the rent that has to be paid to the State Housing Authority. The available information suggests that most principal tenants with subtenants receiving rent assistance are charging the subtenants more than the additional rent that they have to pass on to the State Housing Authority in respect of that subtenant.

Anecdotal evidence supported by some limited individual reviews suggest that there are cases where subtenants of public housing are charged a level of rent which exceeds the total household rent that the principal tenant has to pay to the SHA. However, until more detailed information is available from matching with data supplied by SHAs, it is not possible to define the extent to which this occurs. None of this changes the fundamentals. The government set out to prevent persons who were receiving the advantages of living in public housing getting further advantage from rent assistance. The measure achieves that purpose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement on the same matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am somewhat concerned that this disclosure did not come forward until the government was requested to provide that information. It leads to the conclusion that, except for the fact that the opposition and Senator Harradine requested the information of the survey, it may never have been dis closed to this chamber that there had been an error. I suppose I cannot say that that is absolutely the case, but I think that many people who followed the debate might question that in their minds.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems unlikely to me, bearing in mind that there is a sample of only 60 people, that it is really impossible over the period that this bill has been debated to take out the personal aspects contained in the review and give us some numbers as to those people who are supposedly receiving more from their sublettors than they are paying in additional rent.

I believe that the Senate, in relying on any of the information that we have been advised by the minister is contained in this survey or review, should treat this information with a great deal of caution. I would even go so far as to suggest that senators should put this matter out of their minds in determining whether or not they should support the amendment that we are shortly going to be dealing with.

TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (MALE TOTAL AVERAGE WEEKLY EARNINGS BENCHMARK) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 30 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —The committee is considering the Social Security and Veterans' Affairs Legislation Amendment (Male Total Average Weekly Earnings Benchmark) Bill 1997 and requests Nos (3) and (8) moved by Senator Neal. The question is that the requests be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —We have gone through this debate quite extensively, but because of the elapse of time since we last dealt with it, I would like to briefly recap. The effect of this amendment is to ensure that the benchmarking against average weekly male total earnings is set in legislation for allowances as well as for pensions.

SPEECH.PARA: The people who will not have the benefit of this benchmarking, even through an automatic flow‐on, are about 800,000 unemployed people on newstart allowances—even if they are married or have children—650,000 people receiving parenting allowance; 73,000 people on partner allowance—the partners of unemployed people—and tens of thousands of people granted mature age allowances after 30 June 1996.
Unless this request is carried, all those people I have just mentioned will not be benchmarked and, in real terms against general wages in the community, their allowances will be moving backwards.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Neal was claiming yesterday that Labor in government had always benchmarked the pension to 25 per cent. I would ask her if she would like to reconsider that statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I wanted to make a couple of comments in this debate that have not been canvassed before. I have got to say that I do understand the minister's concern about Labor at this point because they really should have fixed this when they were in government. If they have not, I can understand the minister being a little put out. However, the other point that I want to make is: whether or not Labor did it when they were in government, it is debatable whether that should be the basis for what this government should do.

SPEECH.PARA: If it is right to make the benchmark the male total weekly average earnings for pensioners, I believe it is also right to make that the benchmark for allowees. The reason I say that is because one of the problems we have with benchmarking and linking that to the CPI is that the CPI is based on a basket of goods which, for pensioners and allowees, is fairly irrelevant. In fact, one of the complaints I constantly get from pensioners is that when they go into their local shop to buy food, their perception is that prices are always going up. The reason why their perception that it is costing them more to live does not line up with the small increase in the CPI which we are experiencing at the moment is that those baskets of goods contain things such as interest rates which, as we know, are at almost an all time low.

The basic consumables which are important to pensioners do not play as large a part in the CPI as would indicate to pensioners that the CPI is an accurate measure of the costs they are experiencing. That is why the Democrats are inclined to support these amendments. We do believe that the male total average weekly earnings is a much more accurate measure at the present time for pensions and allowances. In terms of those on low incomes, I know there is some work being done on the CPI which would perhaps make it a better reflection of the costs they experience but, until that is done, the Democrats certainly believe that male total average weekly earnings is a more accurate benchmark.

My understanding is that in most of the European countries social security payments are tied to minimum wages, so obviously that is a recognition that that is, at the present time, a more accurate measurement. I simply share that information as part of this debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did ask Senator Neal a question and I hope she is going to answer me.

—I am. I just wanted to allow Senator Woodley the opportunity to have his say. I want to clarify any misunderstanding that the minister may have about the statements I made yesterday. I want to say absolutely that I concede, and have always conceded in this debate, that there was no legislation in place for the benchmarking of pensions but the government, since about 1991, always ensured that pensions were at least 25 per cent of average male weekly earnings, except for one occasion when it slipped behind by some 15c. I believe that was in about 1993 but I am not absolutely certain about that. Maybe the department can confirm that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Neal for her attempt to clarify what she was claiming yesterday. My recollection is that she claimed that the ALP had always benchmarked pensions at 25 per cent. I therefore would table a table demonstrating the single rate of pension as a percentage of male total average weekly earnings, from February 1983 to May 1997, by quarter.

SPEECH.PARA: The interesting thing is that, as I said yesterday, despite Gough Whitlam's claiming that they were going to benchmark pensions to 25 per cent of MTAWE, and despite the fact that that remained Labor party policy—we had the Hawke and Keating governments going from February 1983 through to 18 months ago—as the table will show, it was only after 1991 that they started to take action about that.

So it is not a very convincing argument that you have just used, Senator Neal. I am glad that your government saw the light late in its day but it did have a long time to, first of all, actually benchmark the pensions to the 25 per cent and also to do something about putting it into legislation.

I think Senator Woodley said that the CPI was irrelevant in terms of benchmarks for pensions. I do not know whether he is aware that in 1993—I think it was 1993; I am not positive of that from memory—the Australian Bureau of Statistics did a pensioner index, if you like, and found that that would be disadvantageous to pensioners largely because it did not include housing costs. Even though older people have frequently paid off their home—not all of them are home owners, anyway—the cost of their home flows back to them in maintenance costs, rates, land tax and things like that. So in a very real sense housing costs are still an issue for older people. It was not a very good index.

As you said, work is continuing by the Bureau of Statistics. Often pensioners are not aware of the fact that it is not the Department of Social Security that sets the index. We take an independent umpire's assessment of the index. I think Senator Woodley also said that the MTAWE would be a more accurate benchmark for pensions to be tied to. I would question that. I do not think it is a question of more accuracy. It is a question of yet another benchmark. So pensioners will now have the benefits of two benchmarks. One relates to the cost of living as ABS determines it and the other relates to the standard of living of those in the workplace. It is good for the dignity of older Australians to have their entitlements tied to those two indices. That surely means that we are guaranteeing to the best we can as a government that pensioners will not miss out if the cost of living rises or if wages rise.

Senator Woodley mentioned Europe. I think there is a misconception there. The majority of European countries have pension schemes which are directly related to the workplace. They are insurance schemes and, therefore, are tied to people's contribution rates. So it is like trying to compare apples with oranges to use that analogy in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that explanation. I certainly would not want to move to the European system and tie the pension to the wage people are receiving when they retire because that would put in a whole unjust differential. The information I had was that the minimum wage is also a significant factor, certainly in the Netherlands. But I accept that we are talking about the same thing.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Neal's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5) Schedule 1, item 2, page 4 (line 1), omit "annualised", substitute "anticipated".
(6) Schedule 1, item 2, page 4 (lines 3 and 4), omit "the most recent December quarter", substitute "the following June quarter".
(7) Schedule 1, item 2, page 4 (lines 5 and 6), omit "the most recent June quarter", substitute "the following December quarter".
(9) Schedule 1, item 2, page 4 (lines 25 to 31), omit subsection (3), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (3) For the purposes of this section, the anticipated MTAWE figure for a quarter is worked out using the following formula:

TAB.TAB: 52A X /
1 + (AE forecast)
where:
A is:

(a) if the indexation day is a 20 March—the amount set out for the reference period in the most recent December quarter under the headings "Average Weekly Earnings of Employees, Australia—Males—All males—Total earnings—ORIGINAL" in a document published by the Australian Statistical entitled "Average Weekly Earnings, States and Australia"; or

(b) if the indexation day is a 20 September—the amount set out for the reference period in the most recent June quarter under the headings "Average Weekly Earnings of Employees, Australia—Males—All males—Total earnings—ORIGINAL" in a document published by the Australian Statistical entitled "Average Weekly Earnings, States and Australia"; and

AE forecast is the percentage specified in the most recent Budget papers as the forecast movement in relation to average earnings over the 4 quarters of the financial year to which the Budget papers relate, expressed in decimal form.

PARA.TAB: Note: If the percentage specified is negative, the percentage is taken to be 0%.

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Schedule 1, page 6 (line 7), omit "annualised", substitute "anticipated".
(12) Schedule 1, page 6 (lines 9 and 10), omit "the most recent December quarter", substitute "the following June quarter".
(13) Schedule 1, page 6 (lines 11 and 12), omit "the most recent June quarter", substitute "the following December quarter".
(14) Schedule 1, page 6 (line 31) to page 7 (line 2), omit subsection (3), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (3) For the purposes of this section, the anticipated MTAWE figure for a quarter is worked out using the following formula:

TAB.TAB: 52A X /
1 + (AE forecast)
where:
A is:

(a) if the indexation day is a 20 March—the amount set out for the reference period in the most recent December quarter under the headings "Average Weekly Earnings of Employees, Australia—Males—All males—Total earnings—ORIGINAL" in a document published by the Australian Statistical entitled "Average Weekly Earnings, States and Australia"; or

(b) if the indexation day is a 20 September—the amount set out for the refer ence period in the most recent June quarter under the headings "Average Weekly Earnings of Employees, Australia—Males—All males—Total earnings—ORIGINAL" in a document published by the Australian Statistical entitled "Average Weekly Earnings, States and Australia"; and

AE forecast is the percentage specified in the most recent Budget papers as the forecast movement in relation to average earnings over the 4 quarters of the financial year to which the Budget papers relate, expressed in decimal form.

PARA.TAB: Note: If the percentage specified is negative, the percentage is taken to be 0%.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of these requests is to ensure that pensions are, in fact, benchmarked at 25 per cent of MTAWE at all times rather than just at the particular point of time the benchmarking is done. The present proposal contained within the government's legislation means that, though at the point of benchmarking it will be at least 25 per cent, for the subsequent six months the pension will fall behind. In fact, it is potentially possible that, in a situation where wages are increasing at a reasonably rapid rate, the balance of the six months pensions could be less than 25 per cent.

These requests actually base the variation on a prediction of what total average weekly earnings will be in six months time. So it ensures that at all times the pension is above that 25 per cent benchmark, not just at the commencement of the six-month period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do have some quite serious points to make about requests 5, 6, 7 and 9. I hope that Senator Neal and Senator Woodley will take particular account of these matters, because I believe they are not simply debating points but very important issues to consider before voting.

SPEECH.PARA: ALP requests 5, 6, 7 and 9 provide that, instead of using the existing published figures, as proposed by the government, the figures to be used will be anticipated figures. These anticipated figures will be produced by taking an annualised figure, which will be obtained from the last quarter for which figures are available, and multiplying it by the square root of the percentage increase which has been forecast for the next four quarters in the most recent budget papers.

First of all, the ALP requests do not provide that the budget papers have to be papers that are available to the public, so there is some question about whether confidential Treasury figures—not yet released—would have to be used. For any government, that would be totally inappropriate. That is the first point.

Secondly, there is a contradiction in the ALP requests. I do not know if they are aware of this, but ALP requests 6 and 7 refer to anticipating the next June or December quarter, whereas ALP request 9 provides that the figure to be used is the percentage increase forecast for the next four quarters. That is confusing and strange, to say the least. Perhaps we will get an explanation.

Thirdly—and perhaps this is the most serious of all for any government to face—when the ALP made an ad hoc increase in 1993, they used anticipated figures rather than the actual figures. That led to a pension overpayment—which I am sure the ALP would not have chosen—in the order of $156.34 million over the six months to July 1993. That, you can see, is an unsatisfactory way of determining what the pension should be at any given time. The government is concerned to ensure that such excess payments are minimised. That is why the actual MTAWE figures are used, rather than anticipated figures.

Our proposal is that the benchmark be assessed at the existing CPI indexation points of 20 March and 20 September each year. Those are chosen to try to minimise confusion to older people, so that things do not change too frequently in the year. They worry when they get a letter from us telling them that there has been a change, even if it is beneficial. They worry at the sight of the letter, often.

We would be using the most recent figures released by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. They provide an accurate benchmark instead of relying on potentially inaccurate forecasts about the potential movements of average weekly earnings and inflation figures between the two indexation points. Both of those would be forecast.

We are not proposing to use Treasury projections of CPI or MTAWE growth, because of the confidential nature of those projections. As we all know from past history, the volatility of Treasury projections, which we have seen over the years, may lead to unnecessary increases or to no increase where an increase is warranted. I do not think any of us would want that to happen. In seeing that people got what they were entitled to and nothing more than they were entitled to, we would be totally reliant on the accuracy of Treasury's projections.

MTAWE is used as the measure because it measures the level of wages across the work force, including full‐time, part‐time, casual and junior employees. That, we believe, is a broad spread, reflective of community differences. It is very relevant to social security customers. For the reasons I have given, we in the government cannot accept the requests the opposition has introduced. They introduce cost and complexity and they would significantly increase outlays. For many reasons, as was demonstrated during Labor's 1993 increase, estimates made at budget time—up to 13 months in advance—may not be accurate. The ALP formula apparently aims to build in some allowance for rises in MTAWE between indexation points and the lag between the survey dates and the indexation points. I think I have made clear exactly why we find this unacceptable.

I will conclude by saying that the ALP's formula could result in significant additional outlays where the actual figure is lower than the forecast figure. This would then build in to all future indexations. The formula proposed, as I have said, is complex. It lacks transparency to customers and, as the ALP would know from their 1993 expenditure—based on projections which cost so dearly because the actual increase in the MTAWE was less than the forecast relied on to pay those pension increases—that would not be fair to the taxpayer. I do not believe you could call it good government. If the forecasts were the other way around, it would also not be fair to the pensioners if they were to get less than they should have been entitled to.
I will leave it at that, for senators to contemplate. I think these are very serious points which should be taken into account before a vote is taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to deal with the four matters that have been raised by the minister. I have to say that they really do not have any substance.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an allegation made by the minister that the calculations would be based on projections contained in the budget papers which she says are not publicly available. The budget papers are publicly available. If there is some proposal by this government to no longer make the budget papers available, the minister should say so. At the present time, they are part of a public document.

The second matter the minister raised is that she seemed to think there was some sort of contradiction between the basis of anticipation as between requests 5‐7 and request no. 9. Requests 5 and 7 relate to a period of six months. You will see that, contained in request No. 9, the calculation is based on a square root of the twelve‐month period. Minister, you probably do not know this but I am sure your department can tell you: the square root of 12 months is six months. It is just a mathematical issue, but you should be advised that they are in fact equivalent. It is like saying that there is a discrepancy because on the one hand you have four and on the other two plus two. They are the same.

The other matter that you have raised is the question of an overpayment; that there is a possibility that the anticipated MTAWE would in fact be higher than it actually is once it is reached. The accuracy of those figures entirely relies on the budget papers put together by the government, so it interests me that you are making an assertion that your government will not be able to provide accurate predictions.

Bearing in mind your experience in employment growth and economic growth, I suppose I can understand why government ministers would be somewhat concerned about the accuracy of their budget paper predictions. But in the general course of things these projections are reasonably accurate, though obviously occasionally they are wrong. The thing is that even if there is a slight inaccuracy, and occasionally this does occur, normally it involves a very small amount and the variation is then taken into account and rectified the next time the benchmarking occurs, six months later.

There is one other matter that I should deal with. The minister seems to feel that, based on our proposal, there would be benchmarking more than twice a year. I wish to make it very clear, Minister, that our proposal is exactly the same as yours in terms of the number of times the benchmarking occurs; it would occur twice a year, the same as it would in your proposal. So the idea that, if our proposition were adopted by the Senate, there would be constant changes occurring and that pensioners would be threatened and concerned and frightened really holds no water at all.

The fundamental point is: should pensioners have their pensions benchmarked so that they are always at least 25 per cent of male total average weekly earnings or should they only be 25 per cent for one brief moment and then for the following six months slip behind, because that is the proposal that this government is putting forward? Their proposal is that, on one day in March and September, pensions would be 25 per cent of MTAWE but for virtually the rest of the year they would be slipping behind. In a period of very high wages growth, as appears to be developing under this government, that slipping behind could be quite substantial. We believe that, if this government has promised that pensions be benchmarked at that level, they should be benchmarked for the whole year, not just for the two days in the year and then slip behind the rest of the time. We believe that they are not really keeping their promise unless they accept our request. I would ask the minister to support this request on the basis that it ensures compliance with their promise to benchmark pensions at 25 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking firstly about the budget papers issue, Senator Neal has been long enough in this place to understand that the term `budget papers' covers a range of papers. Some have always been publicly available and some have always not been publicly available, and Treasury forecasts fall into the latter category. The last Labor government did not make those papers available. It has not been the practice. So when I said that there was not an acceptable transparency, that was an accurate comment and one that I stand by. If you are proposing that it will change under the next government, that is yet another promise that I think you will find difficult to keep in government.

SPEECH.PARA: On the overpayment issue, I think I have already made that very clear. You did not get your forecasts right and there was a $153 million extra bill that should not have been paid by the Australian taxpayer because the forecasts were wrong. I am not blaming you but there were Treasury forecasts on which your government acted. Are you saying that we should just knowingly introduce a system where such enormous inaccuracies and overpayments can be made? You said something about a slight inaccuracy. I would hardly call that a slight inaccuracy. You said it does not usually occur. You only benchmarked twice so you can hardly say `usually' anything. You said something about being rectified six months later. What if the flaw is the other way and the pensioners have not kept up to the standards of the men and women who are in the workplace in Australia over that six months? What if there has been a great growth.

TALK.START.PARA: —They would also be even worse off.

—No, they would certainly not. If there had been a great growth people would have not been brought up for the six months. I think that you really are doing something pretty irresponsible in trying to go down that route.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, let me point out that we adopted the general approach proposed by the Australian Labor Party in the draft amendments that they circulated in the Senate last year. Really, it is the only feasible, responsible, practical legislative approach. Let us hope that the Senate can learn from the 1993 experience. It is not a route that you would responsibly go down. Surely the ALP can recognise that now and I would urge the Democrats to take that very seriously into account.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just had a member of staff get Budget Paper No. 1. The figures that are required for the adjustment contained in our amendment are on page 2/24 of Budget Paper No. 1, a public document. I am really a bit startled by your continued assertion that it is not a public document.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter that I would like to put to you, Minister, is that your office was requested to provide evidence that under your formula pensions would actually ever reach 25 per cent. We have not received any response. Why is that? Is it that you cannot provide that evidence?

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that a response was given to your office, that the pension was already at 25.3 per cent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not receive it but, even if I did, that is not the request that has been made. What we wanted was evidence that under your formula pensions would ever actually reach 25 per cent.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the requests (Senator Neal's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative, subject to reqests.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments and requests; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 12 February, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I wish to state that Labor is supporting this legislation. That said, we do have some significant concerns about some of the provisions. Firstly, the bill is not strong enough in some areas and is clearly inappropriate in others, and I will be addressing these issues in the committee stage with a series of amendments to attempt to improve the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition believes it is hypocritical in the extreme for the government to be bringing forward this legislation concerned with budget honesty. This is the government that has conducted one of the most dishonest budget policies in the history of this country. This is the government that has invented the notion of core and non‐core promises—core and non‐core honesty. This is the government that has significantly reduced the amount of information in the budget papers. For example, in the first Costello budget the complete details of all the specific purpose payments to the states and territories were completely excluded from budget paper No. 3 so there was less information provided to the public and interested shareholders, not more. Thankfully, scrutiny by the opposition ensured that the proper information was included in the 1997 budget papers.

How can the government credibly begin to talk about budget honesty when, in last year's budget, they broke, at a minimum, $15 billion worth of promises? Let me run through some of these. The ABC: the coalition made a commitment that `we will maintain existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC'—that promise was broken before the 1996 budget and it now represents a $209 million cut over four years. Child care: the coalition `has no plans whatever to change the operational subsidy to the community based long day care sector'—the 1996 budget abolished operational subsidies for community based long day care, which will increase fees by at least $14 per child per week.

Health: `none of the coalition's health policy initiatives will entail cuts in funding for public hospitals'—the 1996 budget contained extensive reductions in funding to public hospitals through a combination of cuts to financial assistance grants to the states and cuts to hospital funding grants totalling around $800 million over four years. Labour market programs: the coalition `will maintain expenditure on labour market programs in real terms'—the 1996 budget cut these programs by $1.8 billion over four years.

Older Australians: the coalition `will maintain all current Commonwealth concessions for older Australians'. What has happened to the Commonwealth dental health program? It ceased on 31 December 1996. This program provided basic and emergency dental care benefits to health card and Commonwealth seniors card holders. Research and development: the coalition `will maintain support for R&D through the 150 per cent tax concession'—the coalition praised R&D syndication before the election but R&D syndication was abolished before the 1996 budget; the tax concession rate was reduced in the 1996 budget to 125 per cent.

Regional development: the coalition `will maintain regional development funding of over $150 million over four years'—the whole program was abolished before the 1996 budget. States and territories: the coalition `will provide a fixed share of Commonwealth revenue to the states and territories in a way which is revenue neutral and which would guarantee current services'—a promise broken at the June Premiers Conference when financial assistance grants were cut by $1.5 billion over three years and specific purpose payments were cut by three per cent annually; the 1997 Premiers Conference confirmed this broken promise.

Taxation: `there will be no new taxes and no increases in existing taxes under a coalition government'—this promise has been broken on many occasions. For example, the 1996 budget contained the Medicare levy surcharge of one per cent for some taxpayers without private health insurance, and the infamous superannuation contributions surcharge tax of up to 15 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —Infamous! Have you read the Australian ?

—Calm down, Senator Kemp, you will hear a lot more about the super tax in the next year; that will become evident. On universities, the promise to maintain the level of Commonwealth funding to universities has also been broken in terms of operating grants which were cut before the budget by $623 million over four years. Additionally, universities will suffer reductions in other funding that will mean that the total amount to be cut from universities will come to over $2 billion over four years.

SPEECH.PARA: This legislation should have been referred to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in accordance with a previous recommendation, recommendation 19 in report No. 341, that any fiscal reporting bill such as this bill should be referred to the JCPA subsequent to its tabling. The government ignored this recommendation when the legislation was introduced. The shadow Treasurer attempted to refer the bill to the JCPA, but was defeated by the government.

Accordingly, to ensure some level of close scrutiny, the Senate has referred the bill to the JCPA. Unfortunately, the reporting time imposed on the reference to the JCPA was too short—a point made by the chair, Mr Somlyay, in his forward to report No. 341. So only a cursory examination of the bill by the JCPA was possible. Nevertheless, the JCPA did point out some salient points about this bill, one of which is that this so‐called charter is non‐enforceable. Subclause 3(ii) of the bill specifically states that the bill is not judicially enforceable. So this trend of non‐binding regulation by the government continues.

The other prominent non‐binding regulatory initiative of this government is the code of conduct of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). We know that it is not enforced unless the opposition actually enforces it. We know that the Prime Minister only lives up to his code when we find out that someone has breached it and we bring it to public attention.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or a whistleblower.

—Yes; I agree. Any pretence that this legislation is creating new enforceable standards of disclosure and hence better conduct of fiscal policy is completely false as the bill ensures that no enforcement is possible. So this legislation is more appearances than substance. Nevertheless, the measure is worth support as long as its shortcomings are acknowledged and addressed.

BREAK.PARA: Before discussing some of the flaws in the legislation, I will turn to the actual proposals in the bill. Basically, the bill seeks to build upon the general fiscal disclosure regime developed under Labor, with some further reporting requirements partly based on the model operating in New Zealand.

It is crucial to understand that this legislation is basically codifying the practice of full disclosure established by the previous Labor government. Labor supports this bill in principle, however we have very serious reservations about a number of proposals in it. I will return to discuss these aspects later in my remarks and in the committee stage. The major components of the fiscal and economic disclosure regime are, firstly, comprehensive budget documentation and information which outline the government's fiscal and economic strategy and, secondly, updating this information with a mid‐year review process and a final budget outcome statement subsequent to the end of the financial year.

In addition, the bill proposes, firstly, a five‐year inter‐generational report which will assess the long‐term sustainability of current policies, especially in the context of expected demographic changes. Secondly, it proposes a pre‐election fiscal and economic report to be prepared by senior economic bureaucrats and, thirdly, a prescriptive regime on the costing of policy commitments by government agencies during an election campaign. The fiscal strategy followed by the government is to be based on principles of so‐called sound fiscal management, which are contained in clause 5 of the bill. As you would expect, these are broad motherhood statements which are meaningless in the context of actually formulating a budget.

I will now turn to some of Labor's more broad concerns about this legislation. With respect to economic forecasts, the bill provides, in some respects, for even less accountability than that recommended by the government's own Commission of Audit on the question of the charter. For example, the commission recommended making the economic forecasts in the budget, the mid‐year review and the pre‐election report the responsibility of economic bureaucrats instead of being at the discretion of the Treasurer. The government has agreed to this only in respect of the pre‐election statement, not the budget or the mid‐year review. By contrast, New Zealand requires certification of the economic forecasts by relevant bureaucrats for all parts of the budget cycle. Why is the Treasurer (Mr Costello) not prepared to submit himself to the same levels of honesty as required in New Zealand?

This proposal is in stark contrast to Mr Costello's practice whilst in opposition. He asked the then Treasurer that the 1995‐96 economic forecasts in the 1995‐96 budget be certified by the Secretary to the Treasury as being prepared without political interference. This was duly done in writing. As usual for the coalition, there is one standard in opposition and a completely different one in government. There is no equivalent provision in this bill to bind the Treasurer to undertake the practice that he required the Labor Treasurer to undertake. Why is there this inconsistency? Why won't the Treasurer subject himself to the standards that the former Labor Treasurer did?

The second area of the bill that I wish to mention is that of fiscal principles. The Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the JCPA, has considered the issue of fiscal principles and in report No. 341, paragraph 3.224, it stated:

However, the Committee does not see a need to formulate binding statutory principles of fiscal responsibility. In any case, such fiscal principles would be so imprecise and so wide open to interpretation that there seemed little point prescribing them in legislation. The Committee is also wary of the idea that there are enduring fiscal principles.

That is, this parliament's expert financial committee has said that these principles are meaningless. Whilst we do not oppose these provisions, we note that the insertion of these principles into the legislation is simply window dressing; it will have no practical effect.

Apart from their generality, the principles of sound fiscal management are seriously deficient in terms of micro‐economic management, with their singular focus being on financial outcomes. They make no allowance for employment goals, income growth, productivity targets, the income distribution policies of the government or a myriad of other important goals of economic policy.

Perhaps the worst example of meaninglessness is principle D, which binds the government to maintain the integrity of the tax system. We know this government has no intention of doing that. For example, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) announced, by way of press release, in the 1996 budget that the government will not be proceeding with significant anti-avoidance legislation foreshadowed by Labor concerning alienation of personal services income and the avoidance of the PAYE provisions. Those provisions were to be aimed squarely at arrangements undermining the integrity of the personal income tax base, which the tax office confirmed in estimates last year to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars per annum.

So, by definition, the Treasurer has already breached his own principles. But, of course, it does not matter if the principles are breached because, as I have already observed, there are no penalties for non-compliance with the bill. So these are the tough new rules, which the government has already broken, for which there is no penalty for contravention.

One possible way to strengthen these provisions would be for the tax office and Treasury to make independent annual statements concerning threats to the integrity of the tax system and for the Treasurer to be judged against action to deal with these threats. I will be addressing this issue in more detail during the committee stage. The key issues here, obviously, are resourcing for the tax office and the adequacy of existing legislation to protect the tax base, both of which are squarely within the responsibility of the Treasurer.

I will now make a few points about the government's record. The first point to make on this bill is the utter farce of the government's stance on the question of budget disclosure and transparency. The long list of government budget broken promises last year make nonsense of any claim to budgetary honesty. The government has literally broken billions of dollars worth of budgetary undertakings which were made prior to the last election.

The no new taxes pledge has been broken repeatedly with tariffs being imposed on hundreds of items previously free of tax. The superannuation tax is clearly a new tax. Families face increased pharmaceutical costs, increased child-care costs and increased state taxation due to the cuts in grants to the states. Students face crippling HECS debts and repayment schedules. The aged will face daily fees for nursing homes and may have to sell their house to pay an up-front fee. Labour market programs have been savagely cut. Industry policy has been ignored as export assistance and other incentives have been cut.

I would like to refer to Labor's record. The proposed reporting regime builds on Labor's introduction of much more open and transparent budget processes. For example, we introduced the publication of three-year forward estimates of outlays and revenue, the publication of an annual tax expenditure statement, the massive improvement in the information provided in the budget papers and the publication of financial impact statements within all explanatory material for new legislation.

Despite the rhetoric of the coalition, Labor has the best record of reform of budgetary processes and fiscal disclosure of any Commonwealth government. The excellent record of the previous government in this regard was alluded to in evidence before the JCPA hearing. For example, Professor Mark Robinson stated:
No legislation can compel fiscal responsibility . . . The most positive view of the Bill is that it is merely the latest in a long series of incremental improvements in fiscal reporting requirements.

This is a fair view of this legislation. It sounds impressive to those not fully acquainted with the minutia of budget policy, but it really delivers very little in concrete terms beyond what has already become established practice under Labor.

Indeed, I note again that the government is not as interested in budget honesty as it professes. Last year, it omitted significant information previously provided by Labor, including the comprehensive report of the proposed specific purpose payments to the states, which is normally contained in Budget Paper No. 3. This caused difficulties for states in the preparation of their own budgets and severely disadvantaged members of the public and other stakeholders interested in Commonwealth-state financial issues.

The coalition also raises the canard of asset sales in their own justified assault on Labor's integrity by claiming that we fiddled the books with regard to accounting for asset sales. Nothing could be further from the truth. Labor always followed the appropriate rules and disclosed underlying as well as headline results.

Despite its rhetoric, the government has included significant assets, including property sales of around $1 billion and the recently deferred sale of the telecommunications spectrum, in the so-called underlying budget bottom line even though it vigorously criticised Labor on its similar practice with regard to the issue of asset sales. I think we can also recall the one-third sale of Telstra—the process of which is continuing at the moment—and the diversion of a significant proportion of the sale of that asset, effectively, into recurrent expenditure, vis-a-vis the environment fund and the reduction of expenditure in the environment by a figure of $½ billion in other areas of the budget. If you can redefine, through the sale of an asset, expenditure into the environment as a capital, you can redefine any part of an asset sale proceeds as any part of recurrent expenditure.

In respect to other information, this supposedly honest government continues to refuse to provide, among other things, forecasts of national saving—notwithstanding the state of centrality of savings to its entire macro-economic strategy. Why won't you provide this key information to the Australian people? Why won't you provide your forecasts of the rate of unemployment in future years to the Australian people? Why won't you publish the economic forecasts of the Reserve Bank, as was promised before the election? The answer to these is obviously that the government is embarrassed by the future forecasts of things like the levels of employment and unemployment, the level of national savings and so forth.

The pre-election costings regime is seriously deficient in a number of respects. Costings of opposition policy can only be undertaken at the discretion of the Prime Minister. This is unbalanced and clearly advantages the incumbent government. Only costings of previously announced policies is allowed—that is, policy decisions would have to be made on the basis of incomplete information and be announced. The pre-election report requirement also appears to be in need of refinement, for example, by requiring the report to be released earlier than the specified 10 days.

So whilst the opposition does not oppose this legislation in principle, we are wary of its effectiveness and are also concerned about the fairness of some of its provisions. It should have been more carefully considered by the JCPA. However, this was stymied by the government. I conclude my remarks by foreshadowing now that the opposition will be moving a number of amendments to improve the workings of the bill and to improve the transparency of the budget process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer (Mr Costello) is to be congratulated on bringing the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 forward. This legislation is welcomed by the Australian Democrats as it does represent an essential reform: it aims to improve fiscal policy outcomes by providing a framework for the conduct of government fiscal policy. The Australian Democrats have pushed for reforms of this kind for a very long time, as political history has indicated that no party has had the capacity to tell the fiscal truth to the electorate because of the failure to have them objectively costed.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 1982 budget, an election budget, the then Treasurer, Mr Howard, forecast a surplus of $230 million, which blew out to a deficit of $4,473 million. The post-election revelation of the budget deterioration allowed the new Labor government to junk virtually all their election promises. Since then that practice has become pretty much a recurring picture. Governments have deliberately painted a rosier than truth picture of their finances, which only seems to be corrected after elections. Thus, in 1992, Paul Keating produced his now infamous One Nation forecasts, which claimed that the deficit would repair itself. On the back of this, he and Dr Hewson went into the 1993 election campaign with the most outlandish and unfunded tax cut promises.

The Democrats said at the time that the tax cuts were not funded and were not fiscally responsible. Democrats leader Senator Kernot moved in the Senate to cancel the cuts on the grounds of fiscal responsibility. But the coalition joined with Labor to vote in the $4 billion of tax cuts which they both knew were not funded. Three years later the coalition had the gall to gloat over the `Beazley black hole'. If they had voted with the Democrats to stop an unfunded $4 billion in tax cuts, there would not have been a black hole; it would have been more like a black divot, to use golfing terminology.

Over the last four years, fiscal reporting continued to be a very political process. The 1995 budget included a claimed `headline' surplus of $718 million. The real picture was an underlying deficit of $7.2 billion, a point which Senator Kernot tried to make as clear as possible through trying to set up a Senate inquiry into the matter. Again, the coalition joined with Labor to defeat the Democrats' proposal. Why? Because they wanted to rely on Labor's ridiculously rosy economic forecasts to build up their unfunded and unaffordable election promises—$7 billion of them.

With the change of government, we had the now familiar display of the new government junking most of their election promises after a shock-horror revelation about the black hole they had helped create. Ignoring the fact that the black hole was always an exaggeration and was mostly accounted for in the 1996 budget papers anyway and that the actual budget deterioration was about $2 billion to $3 billion, the government used this deliberately misleading fiscal crisis to put in place another round of vicious, socially and economically destructive budget cuts, many of which, particularly in business, labour market and social justice areas, were frankly unnecessary. They were so unnecessary that last year's budget ended up $1.6 billion ahead of forecasts. The private sector assessment agency, Access Economics, says that next year's budget will be over $4 billion ahead.

Fiscal reporting, while it might seem boring, is absolutely essential to an open and accountable budget process. Once again, I record the Democrats' belief that the government is to be congratulated on recognising that and bringing the bill forward.

All this manipulation of figures over the past 15 years has resulted in a massive disruption of government service delivery, billions of dollars of broken promises, unfunded promises being made and deceit on a massive scale, undermining public confidence in the electoral process, in politicians' probity and major mistakes in fiscal policy which have affected national economic performance. To combat this, in 1996, Senator Kernot, in her charter for reform, called for far more openness and accountability in fiscal reporting. This bill does go some of the way towards achieving that. In the committee stage we will be pushing amendments to make it go further.

The bill makes the government and the Treasury responsible for reporting to parliament specified information about fiscal strategy, the current economic and fiscal situation and the outlook over the medium and long terms. It specifies principles of fiscal policy that the government is to consider but not necessarily to implement when developing its budgets. The principal effects of the legislation will be: to introduce greater accountability and transparency in matters; to tilt the balance of fiscal decision making away from the short-term economic and political considerations that have dominated the past and instead focus towards strategic and long-term fiscal objectives; and to provide the electorate with an accurate account of the government's financial position and the pricing of its, as well as the opposition's, policies—all laudable effects.

The charter of budget honesty seeks to achieve these objectives by requiring the government's fiscal strategy to be based on sound fiscal management and for the publication of regular reports setting out such fiscal strategy. The bill also provides for the publication of an intergenerational report at least once every five years, which it is hoped will encourage the development of long-term sustainable and forward government policies.

This legislation puts in place a number of important accountability mechanisms which will help to ensure that members of the public are better informed about the government's fiscal strategies when they go to the polls and vote in federal elections. It will mean that the electorate will be able to determine more accurately the effectiveness of government in its management of financial affairs and the costs and benefits of government policies. It will mean that the media, who are the prime commentators in the area of election reporting, will be able to do some important and independent analysis. Importantly, it will also be possible for voters to weigh the costs and benefits of government policies against those of the opposition and, if our proposed Democrat amendments get up, other minor parties.

The Charter of Budget Honesty Bill is largely modelled upon the New Zealand Fiscal Responsibility Act 1994. Most of the reports and analyses proposed in the charter of budget honesty appear to have been taken from the New Zealand act. The exceptions in the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill are the intergenerational report, the costing of election campaign promises and proposals and the fact that the Australian bill is not binding on the Crown.

The first two of these provisions have no counterpart in the New Zealand legislation, thus it could be argued that the charter of budget honesty will provide a more comprehensive array of fiscal and economic information than does the New Zealand act. For this the Democrats commend the government. Nevertheless, the Democrats believe that one very important distinction between the New Zealand Fiscal Responsibility Act 1994 and the charter of budget honesty is the fact that, contrary to New Zealand, no rights or obligations arise under the government legislation. This may mean that the so-called advances of the Australian legislation will be cancelled out by this retrograde feature.

Clause 3(2) of the bill states that the charter of budget honesty is not judicially enforceable. The charter is therefore much like a code of conduct, which does not have any enforcement procedures or penalties—a situation which clearly is unsatisfactory. Voluntary codes, as we all know, are often ineffective.

In the current legislation there is no penalty should a party fail to provide pre-election reports and costings, and there is no penalty should a party breach its pre-election reports, costings or commitments. Yet, if you read anything concerning the electorate's view of politicians, you will see that there is an utter need and desire for politicians to speak the truth and to keep their word.

The only sanction currently available for when a government ignores the need to comply with the provisions of the charter of budget honesty rests with the parliament. That is an unsatisfactory situation given that the government of the day will have a majority in the parliament. By contrast, the New Zealand Fiscal Responsibility Act 1994 is binding on the Crown. This means that, if the New Zealand government does not comply with the requirements in the act, any citizen has standing to initiate an action in the courts. In our view, this demonstrates a serious commitment to the provision of information and accountability of the government to the electorate—a commitment which the Democrats and I were disappointed to see was not present in the legislation before us.

The remedy of enforcement where there is a failure to act is denied Australian citizens in the charter bill, which effectively provides a shield of immunity to any claim on public interest grounds, preventing the disclosure of information. I believe that this limits the effectiveness of the charter as a mechanism to improve scrutiny, transparency and fiscal accountability. Therefore, our most important amendment will be to make this act binding on the Crown.

The Australian Democrats propose to amend the bill to provide that it be enforceable against the Crown, as in the New Zealand jurisdiction. In the absence of such an amendment, I believe this legislation would be inconsistent with its own purpose: on the one hand, this bill is proclaimed to be an important contribution to the government's accountability efforts; on the other hand, the government cannot be held accountable to the provisions in this legislation. I urge the government, the non-government parties and the independents to consider this inconsistency and to support the Democrats' amendment in this regard.

The Charter of Budget Honesty Bill puts in place better public sector accounting methodologies. The current methods provide inadequate information. The fact that these methods have continued to be used points to the politically convenient nature of these provisions in that they provide very little information and consequently could be politically expedient.

These poor public sector accounting methodologies are no longer satisfactory. The electorate of today demands that they be provided with sufficient information which will enable them to make an informed vote. This is the right of the elector, and indeed it is the responsibility of the government, the parliament and the Senate to provide the electorate with that information.

The government's accounts must be taken to the next level of international best practice. Setting in place the requirement for pre‐budget opening of the books and a post‐budget review of fiscal strategy will make government more open, more transparent, more accountable and more respected by the electorate.

The Democrats will also be moving amendments to bring about the consideration of social and environmental implications and the effects of policy decisions. These are issues which are vitally important to many members of the community and many future members of the community, and therefore form an essential basis to their voting behaviour and to their lives in Australia. The provision of this kind of information will better assist the electorate in their assessment of the government and opposition parties' policies.

I will also be seeking the support of other senators for the inclusion of a requirement that any costing that is reported includes an indication of the assumptions, limitations and qualifications of any modelling process used in the reports. This should ensure that any biases or distortions which certain models may create will be subject to public criticism, analysis and debate.

The charter of budget honesty should make a useful contribution to improving policy making, economic sustainability and public accountability in the Australian jurisdiction. The pre-election and post‐election reports, along with the intergenerational reporting requirements which will assess the long-term sustainability of current government policies, as well as the accompanying reports by the secretaries of the departments of Treasury and Finance, will all contribute to fulfilling the aims of this legislation—to produce better financial outcomes.

The bills information requirement should considerably improve the chances of framing fiscal policy debate over a longer term horizon and with a concern for integrating sustainable fiscal policy within wider development strategies. In reviewing these strategies, our Democrats amendments will specifically require social and environmental impacts to be taken into account. I reaffirm the Democrats' approval and gratitude to the government for bringing this bill forward, and I hope that our amendments will result in its considerable strengthening.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —The Charter of Budget Honesty Bill focuses on introducing accountability along very narrow lines. It should be seen as part of the government's push for the dominance of narrow definitions of `public interest' and `accountability'. My definition of `economics' is related to the origins of the word, but I did not bring that information with me. My understanding is that it is based on the domestic economy—that is, the way people make decisions about how they live, work and make ends meet.

SPEECH.PARA: In the end, what we have now is the economy and in fact certain markets telling people what to do rather than people simply using the economy to meet their own needs. If you like, this bill is the epitome of people being told what to do by somebody else.

The use of fiscal accountability implies that fiscal benchmarks are the most important or perhaps the only relevant criterion for judging policy. This implies certain values. It pre‐ empts discussions and forces conclusions in certain directions.

It is also reductionist in the extreme. That is, it pulls down the total of social decision making into discrete bundles. It basically looks at short-term outlooks and indicates that it somehow links with other elements within the community. In fact, it does not. Pulling those things apart often gives you a very distorted view of the world. It blocks out the links that are made between taxation decisions and spending decisions with most other elements in society which many other people think are more important.

It ignores entirely the whole momentum established internationally against such narrow economic accountability. Overseas there has been a great deal of discussion about widening the accounts basis. It talks about integrating environmental and economic accounting and social impacts—longer term as well as the short term. In reality, if we reduce our productive base, all the accounting in the world with a narrow economic base will not give us any form of truth in terms of outcomes.

In the original models of the classical economists, production came from the factors of production: land, labour and capital—natural resources, human resources and invested capital in the modern terminology. The national account structures have tended to concentrate on fixed capital and labour, neglecting natural resources. In accounting terms, income is consumption which does not reduce future consumption possibilities. That is, it does not cut into the asset base.

A key aim in the national accounts is to measure national income, particularly change in national income. Adjusting the national accounts to take account of resource use is a natural thing to do. Income which undercuts the resource and asset base which produces it is clearly not economically sustainable. That is, if your production poisons and destroys the use of rivers, which are therefore part of the ecosystem and part of the rest of the production base, you are going backwards.

If part of the national accounts indicates that we have spent a whole lot of money trying to fix up the problems we have created with the environment, that should not necessarily be counted as a plus or a growth. If we are depleting the resources at a greater level than that at which we are getting any benefits from them, that should be included. We should have an idea of what the reality is. We should not get to the situation which is happening in the region now, where inappropriate development has suddenly meant huge economic social and health costs because that was not factored into the decision making process.

The social effects or social implications could include the changes to distributional equity—rich and poor regions—changes likely to affect demographic factors, including rural urban populations, or whether urban neighbourhoods are becoming less diverse, with a population correlating to given incomes. They could include the impacts on demand for employment and availability of diversity of employment opportunities; the impacts on changes to employment in terms of the availability of jobs at various skill levels and the likely results of change to the real value of remuneration for a given amount of work of a certain type. They could include implications for women, youth, the ageing, migrants, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, families or other social groups or classes.

If you had that kind of information, you would realise why there are extra pressures and more scapegoating when things go wrong. Implications for the future sectors of industry or services include implications for the balance between small and large businesses or between Australian and foreign owned or controlled businesses. There are implications for rural or urban people in relation to employment opportunities, cost of living and access to social, educational service or cultural resources. It is not much good if we have good dollar figures but all of these things are going backwards.

There are implications for the education or knowledge base of Australia's society, including but not limited to implications in respect of access to information or training or teaching or the general state of intellectual culture. There are implications for culture, including the impact on the arts—visual, literary and performance—affordable access to training and venues, affordable access to events or showings or the implications for development and fostering of Australian culture and the diversity of cultural or artistic productions in Australia.

There are implications for policies in respect of likely changes to factors which affect the level of crime, poverty, homelessness, disease, suicidal or psychological problems. Once again, when we have dealt with these issues, we tend to look at them in a reductionist sense, not in terms of how they have been affected by other changes, including budget changes. There are implications for the ability of communities to effectively make decisions concerning their lives. This is important. It includes the regulating of activities or the setting of civil goals and acting collectively to pursue them through establishing civil projects under their control, including the implications for the powers, structures, responsibilities and ability to attain revenue for various tiers of government. This all sounds familiar, doesn't it?

The environmental considerations should include such things as impacts of policy measures on the diversity and integrity of ecological systems, the impacts on natural abundance, the change in the stock of natural wealth, the implications in relation to the conservation of wildlife, species and areas protected as wilderness or unspoiled habitat and sufficient buffer zones to maintain their status as natural biomes.

The environmental considerations should include the implication for the long-term survival of species and assurances that there is enough habitat remaining to allow homes for breeding populations of size sufficient for long-term genetic sustainability. They should include the implication in relation to the provision of parks and areas where people have access to nature for recreational and emotional reasons and for the nurture of the spirit now and in the foreseeable future. They should also include the implications for conservation and sustainable use of natural economic resources, such as soil, forest, rangeland, fisheries and tourist venues in areas of human activity.

BREAK.PARA: The environmental considerations should include the implications for the retention of water quality and the abundance of groundwater resources, river and estuarine environments and the quality of near shore waters, including their ability to maintain existing ecological communities. They should include implications in terms of exposure to damaging substances—that is, pollution in both natural and predominantly human environments—and the implications of policies which may result in changes of species distribution on a broad and/or long-term scale. This will be important in relation to climate change, and it includes things which may result in the introduction of non-native species or the creation of effectively new species through genetic modification or the creation of selective pressures favouring mutation.

The environmental considerations should include implications for widespread or long‐term changes of ecological systems—that is, the pollutants causing acid rain—global climate change and oceanic driftnetting. They should also include implications of policies likely to cause changes in non‐Australian ecosystems, such as the support for the Nam Theun 2 dam and other Mekong‐Sekong dam projects or measures, including unsustainable logging, that affect trade base in unsustainable exploitation of ecological systems in other nations.

Just recently, the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade was commissioned to write a report effectively saying that the world as we know it will end if Australia supports greenhouse gas. But it was very narrow. We would like to say that the world is watching Australia in its pathetic attempts to try to use reductionist methods not to link in environmental, the social and the economic considerations. Instead, what they are doing is simply going to certain industries and asking, `What is going to be the effect on you?' without looking at the fact that there is clear evidence that taking positive steps will create more employment rather than less.

What I am saying here is that Australia is going in the wrong direction. I find this Charter of Budget Honesty Bill a problem inasmuch as it is suggesting that what the government is presenting as far as budget is honest; that what they are presenting—which is a very narrow view of life—is actually being honest to the Australian public about what is important, not just now but for the future. That is my problem. There should be honesty about what governments are doing and its effect on our ability to meet our needs in the future, not just in the narrow view of the present. I think there is a problem with the way the whole thing has been constructed.

In very brief terms, I will indicate that, in general, I support the intent of the Democrat amendments, although I have some problems with the amendment to bind the Crown. I do not think we should be potentially asking the Senate to add on elements of environmental and social accounting but, first of all, saying that we will bind the Crown no matter what it is they say budget honesty is all about. But we will look at that further during the committee stage. I will also be looking at whether or not the wording is appropriate in all of those amendments.

I think Australia has to realise that we are in fact part of the planet. Australians are being asked to decide on just about every issue—social, environmental, educational, aged care and so on—based on a narrow set of figures which do not necessarily relate to the real picture. They are basically being told that markets far away from them—speculative money markets in Europe and the United States—have more power than anyone else in Australia.

I think we have to start realising we are part of the planet, not just part of a speculative money community. There are more and more people in the world saying that there are other values. It is about diversity and it is about people being able to meet their actual needs, not just the needs of a narrow market focus. It is time that we started looking at the actual accounts.

Even a true economic rationalist would say you have to take those costs into consideration before you are able to make a market based decision. This is not even included in what the government is proposing and I do not think I want to sign my name to something which, in my view, is dishonest and then say we have to make governments stick to it.

My view is that the role of parliament and the role of the Senate is to present the views of the community as honestly as possible, but to present the views of the community. I do not believe in the recent trend that some view of fiscal restraint should be used to beat people over the head and to rip and tear at the basic fundamentals of life of many people who have no other means of survival—and then use it as an excuse to further reduce revenue from those people who can afford to provide it. I think there is a real problem with the reductionist nature of this proposal. I have a problem with jumping on the bandwagon of something which, in my view, is patently dishonest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add my support to this Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 , congratulate the government for bringing it forward, congratulate the opposition for tightening up on it and, in particular, congratulate the Democrats for expanding the terms of reference to include social and environmental impacts.

SPEECH.PARA: Policies are not just about money, elections are not just about money, governments and parliaments are not just about money and the electorate would expect us to be taking into account all the other values that make up life, as Senator Margetts has just said.

I would like to foreshadow that in the committee stage I will be moving to amend the Democrat amendments so that all participants in elections can avail themselves of having their policies vetted. I think it should be expanded beyond Labor, Liberal and Democrats to all players, so that this assessment of policies and costing of policies of all parties can be available to the electorate.

I have a query about the compulsory component of the Democrats' submission, in that if all policies are to be assessed on the basis that the information must be provided 21 days before an election, on the face of it this would mean that policies could not be devised in the last three weeks before an election. All of us who have been involved in election campaigns know that the last three weeks is of itself a very prodigious generator of election policy. That said, this legislation cannot be seen as anything but a step in the right direction for the people who count most, and that is the voters of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you to all senators who have contributed to the debate on the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 . I thank Senator Brown for giving the government a pat on the back for bringing this bill forward. It is an important part of the government's election commitments. The commitment to a charter of budget honesty was a cornerstone of our economic and fiscal policies. When the truth about the state of the books became known shortly after the election of the Howard government we resolved to ensure that the sort of deceit that took place in the 1996 election could never occur again. Our resolve was rebuilt to ensure that this legislation was put in place. We appreciate the contributions of those who have indicated their support for it.

SPEECH.PARA: The core of this legislation is to ensure that the pre-election fiscal and economic outlook is made available to the public, that the public are fully aware of the state of the budget at that time, and of forecasts for the fiscal and economic outlook. The more that the people who vote in elections know about the state of the economy and the state of the books, the more informed judgment they are going to make about the credentials of the parties they are going to vote for. It is wrong for someone to go to a ballot box and cast a vote based on information which is patently incorrect. That occurred at the last election. We were told right through the election, right up to polling day, that the books were balanced and that, in the event that the Howard government was elected, we would inherit a set of balanced accounts. I think there was even some talk about a small surplus.

It is now history that we inherited an annual average budget deficit of in excess of $10 billion. That has made the government's job in the first 18 months extremely difficult. We have had to deliver budgets which were a lot more difficult to prepare, a lot more difficult to deliver and a lot more difficult to get through the Senate than we would have hoped had the Australian Labor Party government under Mr Keating, Mr Willis and Mr Beazley, as the finance minister, been telling the truth to the Australian people prior to the last election.

We inherited deficits run up by the previous Labor government of $70 billion in five years. Most Australians are beginning to realise more and more, because there is more transparency, particularly under this government, of the budget processes, that this money does not grow on trees.
