You do not just write a bottom line deficit of $10 billion and that suddenly appears out of the clouds or from a tree with money growing on it. It does not magically get delivered from overseas and they do not want it paid back. When you spend $10 billion more than you receive in revenue you have to get it from somewhere. It is borrowed. Next year's budget has to pay back some of the interest on that. Ultimately, when you run up $70 billion worth of cumulative deficits in a period of five years you run up a massive interest bill. So before you spend any money on schools, universities, health care or anything else you pay interest on these loans.

The legacy that Labor left to Australia in its last five years alone was a $70 billion Bankcard bill. It was called `the Beazley bankcard'. It was a nice way to of trying to get the households of Australia to understand what we did inherit. It is accurate to compare it to a household using their Bankcard or their Visa card or borrowing money in other ways to pay for the household grocery bill. It is no different to any of us going down to Coles week after week, or Woolworths or wherever we shop and saying, `Here is the Bankcard,' and never actually getting around to paying it off. At the end of a couple of years those of us who have run up Bankcard bills or Visa card accounts know that sooner or later you have to pay it back and in the meantime you have to pay interest, and of course that hurts.

The coalition is determined to turn that around. We are determined to have a balanced budget through the business cycle. We have brought down budgets which seek to deliver a small surplus by next year. The latest information is that we are on track to achieve that, and we hope we do. I noticed in Senator Sherry's contribution to the debate, which I watched over the TV monitor, that he was talking about this government's dishonesty in breaking election promises. This government has delivered virtually all of its promises. Until Senator Sherry or Mr Beazley or Mr Crean or former Senator Evans come into the parliament and say to the people that they are sorry for what they did to this country, I do not think they will be taken seriously. They certainly will not be taken seriously by this government. We have on the front bench of the opposition people who said: `We are going to deliver l-a-w tax cuts. It was not George Bush saying, `Read my lips'. It was the Prime Minister, a Labor Prime Minister, saying: `These tax cuts are law—l-a-w, law.' And they never got delivered.

We had the Prime Minister prior to Mr Keating, another Labor Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, saying: `There will be no capital gains tax,' and within months we had a capital gains tax. He said, `There will be no increase in the Medicare levy.' There was an increase in the Medicare levy. We had a whole campaign in 1993—a campaign I will never forget—where we had we every single minister, Labor minister, running around saying: `You cannot put up indirect taxes. Indirect taxes are terrible for low income earners. We cannot have indirect taxes. We do not want a goods and services tax. We do not want increased taxes on goods.'

Within days of getting re-elected, Mr Dawkins, the then Treasurer, another Labor Treasurer and a colleague of Senator Sherry's and Mr Beazley's, brings in the biggest increases in indirect taxes in Australian history—increases of 20 per cent in the prices of some groceries that low income earners across Australia have to pay. There were increases on soft drinks, biscuits, toothpaste, toothbrushes, toiletries, toilet paper and baby products—increases of up to 20 per cent across a whole range of goods which are used by low income earners across this country, after these people had run around the country scaring them.

BREAK.PARA: So, Senator Sherry, please do not come into this Senate and start talking about broken promises. However, I do invite you to do so if first you have come into the Senate and said, `I apologise for all of that; we made some mistakes as a Labor government.' Not a single former minister of the previous Labor government has walked into this or the other place, or been on the Sunday program and said to the public of Australia, `By the way, we might have actually made'—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Judi Moylan?
—Judi Moylan was not a minister in the previous government, Senator Conroy.
—She is in this one, though.
—She is, and a very good one.
—Is she making any mistakes?

—I do not think so. I think she is doing a very, very good job. I will tell you who made a mistake—Barrie Cassidy from the ABC. He sought to deliberately mislead the people of Australia. But that may be typical of the ABC. That may be why the ABC, as a current affairs channel, has fallen so badly behind the commercial channels in TV current affairs.
—Are you going to make a statement?
—I just did.
—Order! Senator Campbell, it probably would be helpful to the chamber if you addressed your remarks through the chair.

—I will indeed, Mr Acting Deputy President. Also, I will ensure that I abide by the standing order in relation to relevance, even if I am taken way off the track by Senator Conroy, who seeks to divert me from my course—I will not be diverted again.

BREAK.PARA: We will take those opposite seriously when a former minister of the previous Labor government, particularly Senator Sherry, comes into the parliament or goes to the public of Australia and says, `Look, we actually made a mistake,'—even if it is just to admit to a small mistake, `Sorry, we got the recession wrong, we pulled the wrong lever,' and makes an apology about that.

We have not had an apology for the recession yet. We have not had an apology for $70 billion worth of cumulative deficits which, basically, will burden the next generation of Australians with massive interest repayments. We have not had an apology from the Labor Party yet for what they did to the Australian economy and the fact that they put 400,000 people out of work in the recession of the early 1990s—they just wiped out 400,000 jobs. The net number of jobs in the Australian economy was reduced by nearly 400,000, and it has taken years even to get back to those pre‐recession employment figures.

When those opposite make an apology, we will then take seriously their talking about this government and its record. We have delivered on our pre-election commitments. We are waiting for them finally to get their act into order and boldly go to the people of Australia—just as I remember their doing in the 1990 election, saying to the Commonwealth Bank employees, `We will not sell the Commonwealth Bank.' Mr Acting Deputy President, you will remember that campaign; I am sure you were there at some of those rallies. I saw the Commonwealth Bank employees standing outside of the Commonwealth Bank head office in Forrest Place in Perth, saying, `Don't vote for the Liberals, they're going to sell the bank' and representatives of Labor saying, `We'll never sell it.' Who was it who was going to roll in his grave?

TALK.START.PARA: —Ben Chifley.

—Ben Chifley was going to roll in his grave. What happens? Within just days of the election, the Commonwealth Bank is on the block. And who voted for it? All those opposite. So let us just get a little bit consistent, Senator Sherry.
—Not your namesake; he wasn't here.
—Senator George Campbell would not have voted for it; he would have crossed the floor, I am sure.

BREAK.PARA: We believe that, for all of those reasons, we can look forward to ensuring that those sorts of deceptions at election time do not continue. We note that there are a range of amendments to the bill. The government has had a look at the amendments that will come before us. We will not be accepting or supporting any of them at this stage.

We believe that the Democrat amendments inappropriately broaden the bill to include matters that do not pertain to fiscal principles. I have heard the arguments of Senator Margetts in relation to other principles that should be taken into account when looking at the nation's balance sheet, and I think she makes some important points about ensuring that environmental and other values are a part of the decision making process. But I do not think that goes close to being a sensible way of achieving that objective within the charter of budget honesty legislation. We also believe that the ALP amendments are inconsistent with the traditions of our system of government in Australia.
In conclusion, I reiterate that the bill sets out, in very clear terms, the government's commitment to the charter of budget honesty. I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I move item 1, on revised sheet 664 before you:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clause 3, page 2 (lines 3 and 4), omit subclause (2), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2) This Act binds the Crown in right of the Commonwealth.

SPEECH.PARA: The existing clause in section 3, Charter of Budget Honesty, states:
Nothing in the Charter of Budget Honesty creates rights or duties that are enforceable in judicial or other proceedings.
Our amendment, in contrast, states:

BREAK.PARA: This Act binds the Crown in right of the Commonwealth.
This amendment really says: are you really serious as a government; are you really prepared to put yourselves on the line about this matter?

Mr Chairman, I draw your attention to the Bills Digest No. 85 from the parliamentary information and research services. I must say that, although probably others senators have, I have seldom had the opportunity to thank the Parliamentary Library for the consistent quality of the material they put before us to assist us. This document is yet another example of the very high standard observed by the people and institutions which serve the Senate. So I record my gratitude for that and other past documents.

In my second reading address I spoke at length on this matter of enforceability. This Charter of Budget Honesty Bill provides that the charter of budget honesty does not create rights and duties which are enforceable in judicial or other proceedings. As a consequence, where there is a failure to publish the reports to fiscal strategy required by the charter, there would be no redress in the courts of law or in administrative appeals tribunals.

In the opinion of the Australian Democrats—and, indeed, of the New Zealand government when they looked at their own equivalent act—this is not acceptable. It is contrary to the very intention of the legislation which, briefly, is to provide for much greater accountability of government and opposition in fiscal matters. A Treasury submission to the JCPA—the joint parliamentary committee—inquiry into the whole of government reporting and fiscal responsibility legislation in 1995 also raised this point: that there is no legislative requirement for the tabling of budget papers and that the content of the budget papers is the prerogative of the government of the day.

The explanatory memorandum to the bill offers no explanation as to why no enforceable rights or duties are created by the bill despite the fact that the legislation which it is modelled on—New Zealand's Fiscal Responsibility Act 1994—contains just such a provi sion. The legislation avoids the risk of unconstitutionally restricting the executive power of the Commonwealth through a legislative measure. By not setting targets which governments must meet, the bill makes provision for the executive to follow whatever fiscal strategy it deems necessary, without being fettered in any way by the legislature or the judiciary.

I must emphasise at this point that I am not interested through this amendment in tying the government in any way to a particular fiscal target. I think that would be unwise. What I do seek to do is to ensure that the government fulfils its obligations to report to the parliament under the charter and that, as is consistent with the principles of accountability in this bill, any person may seek to enforce those obligations, should the government fail to do so.
The parliamentary library's publication, which I referred to earlier, specifically said:

Hence the provisions in Sub‐clause 3(2) of the Bill may be considered to be overly protective of the Executive Government at the expense of Parliament and the public, particularly as it extends to all aspects of the Charter of Budget Honesty including its fiscal reporting requirements and pre‐election costings which do not impact on the discretion of the Executive Government in caretaker mode to run the national economy.
That is from page 9 of that document. On page 10, it goes on to say that the bill:

. . . may be better served by building into the Bill the duty and right enforceable in judicial or other proceedings, for the publication of the reports, including pre‐election reports and policy costings listed in the Charter of Budget Honesty.
That is an independent view, and it is one with which I accord.

As I stated in my speech on the second reading, the Democrats have a long history of calling treasurers and their representatives in the Senate to account for the inaccuracies—which sometimes have been gross, as is admitted by both major parties in finger‐pointing at each other—of the budget forecasts of past governments. If this is any indication of what can occur despite parliamentary scrutiny and despite the ballot box in the past, it is certainly no recommendation for being satisfied with a charter which is less than enforceable. If no‐one has clean hands and if the previous situation was such that you could not enforce clean hands, the bill as expressed will not allow clean hands to be kept, because it is not enforceable. It was not enforceable in the past, and it will not be enforceable in the future. To a large extent, this fact—that the bill is not binding on the Crown, in contrast to New Zealand's bill—is its major weakness. It will, to some extent, gut the very good intentions of the government in bringing forward the bill.

In the second reading speech, the Treasurer (Mr Costello) simply stated that the effect of the bill would be to enhance the accountability of the present Commonwealth government as well as of future Commonwealth governments. I submit to the Senate that, if this is the true intention of the government, this legislation can only be strengthened by agreeing to this amendment.

I expect some members of the Senate to respond to this amendment by saying that, despite the lack of enforceable rights and duties, there is a sanction which rests with the parliament and ultimately with the electorate. I do not disagree that the parliament and electorate do have sanctions. Their problem is that whoever they choose in government has behaved in the same way. That is why they no longer respect the institutions of either the government or the opposition. Neither do they respect the politicians who populate parliament and the Senate. If we can introduce the New Zealand system whereby rights or duties are enforceable, we will go some way to reassuring the electorate that this is not a Clayton's bill; that accountability will genuinely be delivered.

The crucial premise for parliamentary scrutiny and accountability is information. If the government fails to provide pre‐ and post‐budget statements and intergenerational reports, the parliament lacks the information it needs to call the government to account. It is for this reason that I believe this amendment is the most fundamental one we have put. It is fundamental to the effective workings of the legislation.

This amendment of ours goes to the very heart of the problem of honesty and accountability. It has been tried and tested in another country with a similar tradition to ours—New Zealand—and it has been found to be appropriate, applicable and workable. I would suggest to you that, based on the independent analysis available to us through the parliamentary library and through precedent, this amendment should be accepted by the government parties, the non‐government parties and the Independents in the Senate. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought I would respond to Senator Murray's contribution early in the debate. The government does, as Senator Murray has anticipated correctly, have some concerns with this. We believe that under the Charter of Budget Honesty there will be enormous political pressure to comply with the act. The bureaucracy will have to comply with it, because it will be the law of the land.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, compliance will be encouraged by political and community debate about these issues and political and community debate on these issues will, as a result of the charter itself, be significantly enhanced. Senator Murray would have seen the debate that took place during the Western Australian election, for example. These concepts of budget honesty and getting the books opened at an early stage were quite a positive thing in the WA campaign. From my brief readings, in South Australia similar things have occurred where both governments have come out very early, published the books and said, `We will give you accurate costings on all of the policies.' It has put an enormous discipline on oppositions as well. The taxpayer is the winner in the debate when you have the books open because you cannot have the old way of having an auction at the election, where politicians who are bidding at the auction are bidding with the taxpayers' money and they always end up paying. That is the great benefit of it. So the government does believe that debate will be enhanced by this legislative measure.

Furthermore, there is a very strong reason for worrying about the fact that the potential for legal disputation could be counterproduc tive. Legal action could be taken in an election in a way that was purely motivated by political purposes. I noted you said `any person'. I presume, under your definition, that when you said any person would have standing in these matters you meant that anyone who wanted to stop the production of these documents or challenge the content of these accounts would have standing before a court. I do not know that this has occurred in New Zealand and I am not personally familiar with the New Zealand provisions; I am sure Senator Kemp and others will have an intimate knowledge of the workings of the New Zealand legislation. I know that those who were closely associated with the production of the policy in this matter, including Senator Brian Gibson during our days in opposition, and who did travel to New Zealand looked at these matters very closely at the time. The people who did put this policy together are aware of that experience.

I can foresee the abuse. Your amendment is very well intentioned—I have absolutely no doubt about that—but less well‐intentioned people could abuse these provisions in a blatantly political way, in a counterproductive way and in a way that is against the intent of this legislation, which is to get information out there to the people of Australia, and to commentators and other economic analysts so that they can analyse these documents and help to inform the Australian people about the state of fiscal affairs. For those reasons, which I think are sound, we will be opposing the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this amendment. Senator Murray has given cogent reasons for it. Of course, you cannot get a better reason than a practice which has been shown to be working elsewhere, which in this case is New Zealand. I do not have the fears that Senator Campbell has that litigious people will, in an election campaign, take action for the sake of it. I do not feel that the courts are going to be so irresponsible as to take frivolous actions and turn them into election‐stopping legal manoeuvres. If there were any effort to do that the public would react badly against the people who were taking the action; after all, it would be action aimed at truncating political debate. Presumably, if it were frivolous and without much basis, it would rebound on the people who tried it. It is working in New Zealand; it should work here. In any event, if it were the intention of the government of the day to live up to this charter, they should have nothing to worry about.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just come late to this, but we are debating a bill for an act to provide for a charter of budget honesty. Clause 3 of that bill says:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) The Charter of Budget Honesty is set out in Schedule 1.
(2) Nothing in the Charter of Budget Honesty creates rights or duties that are enforceable in judicial or other proceedings.
The amendment before us is from Senator Murray of the Australian Democrats. It removes that last line about enforceability and submits in its place a new (2), which reads:
This Act binds the Crown in right of the Commonwealth.

The issue before the chamber is whether the provisions of the Charter of Budget Honesty are enforceable or binding or whether they are not. The government, which has made a great play about this Charter of Budget Honesty, has a bill in which the provisions are not enforceable; the issue for the Senate is whether we make them enforceable. Speaking for the opposition, we will vote for the Democrats amendment to make them enforceable.

If you have a charter for budget honesty but you have a clause which makes it unenforceable, what have you got? Basically you have an illusion of budget honesty, not a charter of it. Or, if you wanted to put it another way and use the contemporary political lingo of this government, you have core honesty and non‐core honesty: issues that are important and issues that you promise people you will carry through but later deem not to be important and do not carry through. It seems to me to be fundamental that, if you are going to set yourself up in government and enact laws that require honest disclosure, there ought to be a provision to make them reliable and enforceable—not a hole that you could drive a coach and four through that lets someone off the hook. Since this applies in an election context, it may well let them off the hook after the results are in, and the Abraham Lincoln observation that you can fool all of the people for some of the time will have occurred. So the opposition will be supporting this amendment.

On the broad bill, the government have spoken quite a bit of breast‐thumping, self‐congratulatory rhetoric about how they are going to straighten out the process by bringing forward this bill on the Charter of Budget Honesty. What they have in fact done is just this: they have encoded in legislation the practice that we in government followed. They have really not brought anything new to it; what they have done that is different is to put it in a bill. That is not something that we oppose. We support that concept, and we support, and have practised when we were in government, a proper disclosure regime and a proper transparency of what the circumstances are in a Commonwealth budget. This is going to be continued, and it will be continued through a bill.

The opposition has some reservations about some of the provisions here, and we will deal with those when the opportunity for us to move amendments arises. But, in so far as this amendment is concerned, we think it is a well wrought amendment. It is an amendment that actually gives some honesty to the title of the bill by requiring that this act does bind the Crown, and it is therefore acceptable to and supportable by us. I commend it to the committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very difficult issue in some ways, because I do not believe you can legislate for honesty. You can usually guarantee that when you want to portray someone who is wanting to do something shifty, like a used‐car salesperson, you talk about—I was going to say `honest John', but I did not really mean to put a specific name to that—honest Joe's used cars. You will often find that those people who wear that across their sleeves are using it as a smokescreen.

SPEECH.PARA: I am worried about whether, firstly, you can in fact legislate for honesty. You can potentially legislate for accountability but I do not know that you can legislate for honesty. What we are in fact doing is leaving it largely to the judgment of Treasury as to what is an honest accounting system, and I do not think we have had much indication from Treasury that they understand the wider issues involved with the depletion of resources and the issues which are in fact important; not irrelevant but vital to whether or not we survive and vital to whether or not we are able to make a living in the future, not just in the present. If we bind the Crown to what I think is a further acceptance of a covert political agenda that economics rules okay and, more than that, that speculative markets—that is, greed—rules okay, rather than look at what the total outcomes are, not only are we not legislating for honesty but we are actually legislating for a dishonest approach.

One specific example that springs to mind is in relation to the sale of assets. We can always put down for this year, next year or even for the next few years what the book value will be for selling off a major public asset. But over time there are other implications—there is a loss of revenue; there is the loss of control that people have in their own community; and the loss of accountability and so on, which we are seeing the government assisting by saying that industry can have commercial‐in‐confidence protections, that it does not have to keep people's information private and that, basically, it is only the contracts that can be broken or renewed from time to time.

I think in that sense we are moving away from honesty. We are actually moving to a position where people know very little about how taxpayers' money is spent, and I have a very strong feeling that, if we are binding the Crown in this particular, illusory bill, we are in fact binding us all to a pig in a poke. We will have the Telstra myth sanctified: whatever the Treasury is asked to come up with in terms of short‐term outcomes—for instance, with the sale of Telstra—is somehow considered to be sacrosanct in that we will form our policies on what is a very narrow view. In my view, that fails to be honest.

So, although I recognise that there is a desire to look as if this parliament is forcing the government to be honest, I come down on the other side by thinking that, if I agree to amendment No. 1, I would be approving of its general intentions when I actually believe that we would be putting into legislation a fundamental dishonesty. On that basis, I am unable to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I have listened carefully to the remarks that senators have made, and I appreciate them. I note that Senator Margetts will not be supporting this amendment, perhaps for reasons that are different from ours, but that is still welcomed. In relation to Senator Cook's comments, I cannot allow one of them to go unremarked upon. This concerned the implication that, if Labor had had their 14th year in government, all these things would have been done; that we had to wait 13 years for sudden action in the 14th. A variant of this argument is that this measure is doing what Labor has always done.

SPEECH.PARA: Correct me if I am wrong, Senator Cook, but I did not get hold of the release of the pre‐election economic and fiscal outlook report—maybe I missed that in the run‐up to the election. In fact, I thought the big issue was that that was being hidden. If you can correct me, I will be happy to acknowledge the correction, but for you to get up in here and waffle on and suggest that we are putting into effect what you were already doing is just a joke—it is a total and absolute joke.

Senator Cook, can I see you after we finish this debate at a quarter to one so you can give me a copy of this fundamental report, which, you allege, puts into effect what you were already doing? You cannot, of course, do that. This is one of our very important initiatives, and we also have a very enhanced midyear report compared, I think, with the five pages or so that you dropped down from time to time. We are not putting into effect what you were doing. One of the great stimuli for this whole thing was the cover‐up by the Labor Party, and that should never be forgotten; we will not forget it and the public will not forget it.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Murray's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chairman—sorry, Mr Chairman—
—If you didn't read your speeches, you would not fall into that error, Senator.
—Firstly, Mr Chairman, I was not reading a speech, I was looking at the running sheet and, secondly, I had my head down.
—Quite.

—May I say, with the greatest of respect, that I expect to be treated with courtesy by the chair, because I always show the chair courtesy. Mr Chairman, I am referring to item No. 2 on running sheet No. 664 revised. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Schedule 1, clause 3, page 6 (after line 2), after the definition of Leader of the Opposition , insert:

minor party leader means the leader of any party with at least 5 representatives in the Parliament. If the party has representatives in both Houses of the Parliament, the leader is the person nominated by the party's representatives in the Parliament to be the leader for the purposes of this Act.

This amendment refers to our desire to include parties in excess of five persons in the parliamentary structure to be included in this process. The Democrats have not done that out of a desire to exclude parliamentary representatives from the process of the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 . We have done so on the basis of a precedent whereby party status is determined in this place at a limit of five. We have assumed that five persons would be therefore acceptable here as a mechanism for the identification of minor parties. Our amendment, item No. 2 on schedule 664, revised, reads:

. . . minor party leader means the leader of any party with at least 5 representatives in the Parliament. If the party has representatives in both Houses of the Parliament, the leader is the person nominated by the party's representatives in the Parliament to be the leader for the purposes of this Act.

I note that Senator Brown has foreshadowed an amendment, on sheet No. 688, amending our own amendment. I should indicate to Senator Brown that I would prefer if that were not moved cognately but subsequently, because if our amendment goes down then, obviously, there is little chance of it succeeding. If our amendment were to succeed, Senator Brown, I would foreshadow to you, to give you some time to perhaps consult with your office, that we would accept that amendment, but with the addition of the words `and also have federal parliamentary representation'.

The reason we do that is that we have been given figures that, since 1911, nearly 500 minor parties have been created in this country. There are a great many minor parties available at any one time. The chances of surviving and, indeed, of getting federal representation are very limited. Because of that, we do not think this approach, whilst democratic and participative in the wider sense, should at this stage be opened completely. I foreshadow that for you, Senator Brown, so that you can consider your position.

The purpose of this clause is to include minor parties in the costing of election commitments. It is consistent with a principle of democracy that parties be able to fully participate in the process. In this way, minor parties may provide the electorate with the costings of alternative election commitments to those of the major parties. This provides the electorate with information and, once again, is an important step towards informing the electorate so that they can vote on the basis of accurate information.

You would be aware, Mr Chairman, in your capacity as a politician that the Democrats are a minor party; we achieve 11 per cent of the vote. However, we do not have 11 per cent of the resources, 11 per cent of the donations or 11 per cent of the funding that is available to political parties overall. Access to this kind of process would be of extreme assistance to parties such as ours. On the basis that it is our belief that political parties so recognised in the parliamentary process should be able to participate in the charter of budget honesty, and on the basis that it contributes to a better electoral process, I commend my amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I am mindful of the fact that the previous amendment before this chamber has just been lost. That was an amendment which required that the provisions of this bill in fact be enforceable. The name of this bill is the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 . Perhaps now that the provisions of this bill are not enforceable, we could rename it as the optional charter of budget honesty, or the almost charter of budget honesty, because no longer is it necessary to comply with the terms of it if you do not wish. With the removal of enforceability, I am not quite sure what we have got here or what significance the government thinks this bill will have, given the optional nature it now assumes.

SPEECH.PARA: I do note, for the record, that the government used its numbers in order to create the optional character that this bill now assumes. Here they are, on one side of the chamber, bruiting aloud about how they are going to clean up the act of government in Australia and make things more honest but, when you look at the fine print, what have they done? In the fine print, they have made it optional. So you can be optionally honest under this bill that the government has before us.

However, the amendment that has just been moved by the Democrats is an amendment that we in the opposition have given some attention to. This amendment is about what is a political party that can have its election promises costed by Treasury and disclosed to electors before an election. The Democrat amendment would have the effect of making the Democrats a party within the meaning of this bill—

TALK.START.PARA: —And the National Party.

—And the National Party. I take that worthwhile interjection. They are, in effect, a minor party in their own right. They only assume a larger presence in the political life of Australia because they are in coalition with the Liberal Party. But they are an independent party and they could have their promises independently costed by Treasury.

SPEECH.PARA: But the cut‐off line in the Democrats' amendment is for a party of at least five members. I note that in this chamber there are two members of the Greens, although they are two separate parties under the heading Greens—Greens (WA) and Australian Greens, as I understand it. If this amendment were carried, the Greens could not have any of their election promises costed by Treasury within the meaning of this bill.

I also note that the Greens have foreshadowed an amendment that would have a wider ranging impact. If the Greens' amendment, which is foreshadowed but not currently before us, were carried then the impact would be that any registered political party in Australia could have their costings made by Treasury. I must say, speaking for the opposition, that I would like to hear a little more argument and a little more justification from both the Democrats and the Greens about their amendments before I could rule on what our position response to them would be.

But, for guidance sake, let me say that I think it is unreasonable for any political party, whether or not it has members of parliament at all, to access the provisions of this bill and tie up the resources of Treasury in costing whatever promises they make. Let me give you an example. I think in the last ACT election, and it may have been in the last federal election, there was a party registered from which fielded candidates contested the election as the `Sun Dried Tomato Party'. This was obviously a joke party; it was not serious. They seized the election campaign as an opportunity to poke fun at the political system and enjoy themselves.

One could imagine that they would wish to extend the joke and develop, shall I say, idiot policies, submit them to Treasury for costing and have a great guffaw at public expense when the figures came out. I do not think that is desirable. I do not mind them running in an election, but I think dignifying them with anything greater than what they are is not a responsible expenditure of public funds.

My feeling is that there ought to be some sort of cut-off line. If you have members in the parliament, then you are serious, you have a voting support in the community to put you here, and you have some sort of claim to say, `We are a serious organisation. We're making serious promises. We would like those promises costed.'

So there may well be a case to lower the threshold figure in the Democrats' amendment from five to one and thus pick up the Independents and the Greens who are in this chamber. But my feeling at this point is not to go any further than that. I note there is no amendment, before us or foreshadowed, that would enable that to occur. I would not mind hearing from the minor parties on this matter a little longer before I finally say where the opposition stands. That is the direction in which we tilt at this point in the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —As the mover of the motion, I will take brief precedence over Senator Brown. It is my assumption—and perhaps when the government responds to this amendment they can confirm it—Senator Cook, that if this bill becomes an act and if, for instance, the Labor Party moves back into government, the coalition has a parting of the ways and the Liberal Party becomes the official opposition and the National Party becomes a minor party, the minor party, the National Party, would be excluded from the process of election costing—that, in fact, they only have access to this costing for as long as they are either in coalition in government or in coalition in opposition.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is a very important point. I do believe the National Party interests have to be considered in this matter. It cannot be automatically assumed that they will always be in coalition with the Liberal Party. If that were so, then they would become a merged party. The fact is that they have a distinct identity. That is the first important point to make.

The second important point I make is that we have accepted in our amendment the precedent that five parliamentary members is the cut-off point to achieve party status. As you know, that party status results in the provision of additional staff and facilities, which assist parties in the exercise of their parliamentary duties.

However, what I have said is that, with regard to Senator Brown's foreshadowed amendment No. 1, if Senator Brown were willing to exclude parties and independents which did not have parliamentary representation—because there are so many of them and because some of them, frankly, might be regarded as somewhat light‐hearted about election prospects—we would certainly have no objection to extending this process and facility to all parliamentary members within both the House of Representatives and the Senate. But, because that is not yet before us, I would prefer that my amendment be dealt with first. I will foreshadow that if Senator Brown did amend his amendment as I have proposed, the Democrats would support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I agree with Senator Murray's proposition that we take his amendment first and then my amendment to that amendment if it is successful. I will be voting for his amendment, which would enable the Democrats' election policies to be assessed for the benefit of the electorate.

SPEECH.PARA: My amendment extends to other parties which have representation in this place. As Senator Cook said, that is the Greens (WA), the Australian Greens and the two independent senators, Senator Harradine and Senator Colston, who, if I am not wrong, represent registered parties themselves. It does apply to people in the House of Representatives, as Senator Murray says, who also represent registered political parties.

I would prefer that it was open. I would prefer that anybody standing for election could have their policies scrutinised in this fashion. Let us face it, the cost of policies will lead to some interest and publicity at the time of the election campaigns.

As somebody who entered parliament during the Franklin River campaign as an Independent and who has seen the growth of the Tasmanian Greens and then the Australian Greens into a fully‐fledged national entity, working in parallel with the Greens (WA), I am well aware of the disadvantage to people who want to get into parliament but who do not have parliamentary representation. It is enormous. Estimates at the last election were that if you had a seat in parliament, although election campaigns cannot be run out of offices, it was tantamount to a $50,000 advantage.

BREAK.PARA: The media takes much more notice of people who are in parliament than people who are not in parliament, unless they are some great celebrity or for some other reason. It means that perfectly legitimate aspirants to the parliament who do not share the views of the bigger political parties are at an enormous disadvantage. That is why I believe that anybody who is bringing forward policies at election time should be able to put those to Treasury to have them scrutinised, to have them evaluated and to have them put before the public for what they are.

However, like Treasury, I can count and I hear the weight of the numbers here, and I know that my amendment as it stands is not going to survive. Therefore, I indicate to Senator Cook and Senator Murray that if Senator Murray's amendment gets up to allow the Democrats and the National Party, along with Labor and Liberal, to have their policies vetted in this fashion, I will accept Senator Murray's amendment. I am looking at having specific words which would carry out the intent of his amendment incorporated into my amendment so that we can extend the potential for scrutiny of election promises beyond the bigger parties to the Greens and to the Independents in this house and in another place—in other words, to anybody who has shown electoral support in the past or who has had somebody represent them as a party in this parliament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —We will not be supporting this measure. It is always a matter of judgment how far one goes. We think that what we have done in this charter is a very big step forward. I refer to the issue of allowing minor parties to have costings done. These are often very extensive policies. In fact, from time to time, in yesteryear, I used to do a bit of costing of the Democrat policies myself. There was the very famous alternative budget of Sid Spindler, which the Democrats used to bring down in the old days. Both sides of the chamber used to wait very anxiously to see what the Democrat alternative budget would propose. When former Senator Spindler brought that budget down, we eager ly rushed forward with the press, grabbed our copies and debate then ensued.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think that we have those alternative budgets now. That is a pity. In the light of this new accountability and new exposure, we hope that the Democrats will be bringing down their alternative budget in the coming years so that we can see very clearly what the Democrats are proposing.

The point I am making is that the Democrat policies, at least from my experience of previous years, are very comprehensive and quite huge. I believe that the costings of those policies would tie up huge resources in the department. Again, it is a matter of judgment just how helpful and practical that would be. Given the tasks that the department already has as a result of the measures in this budget, if we extend that further to the minor parties and to the Greens, we will impose a very substantial burden.

I know that Senator Brown is very productive. I do not always agree with him; in fact, I do not often agree with him. If the truth be known, I rarely agree with them. I have no doubt that Senator Brown will be producing a very comprehensive set of policies—

TALK.START.PARA: —We always do.

—He always does. Senator Brown is one member of this esteemed chamber, but the amount of work that the department could well be committed to do could be similar for the very major parties in this chamber. I think there is a practical issue here which means that at some level the line has to be drawn. Therefore, we will be opposing this amendment. What we are doing in this charter of budget honesty is bringing in new improved accountability, ensuring that the public is properly informed about the policies of the parties which are likely to win government and ensuring that that can be done in a practical manner.

SPEECH.PARA: The extension that the Democrats propose, followed by Senator Brown's amendment, simply is not practical. It will tie up huge resources in the department. With due respect, ultimately it is unlikely that in the foreseeable future the Democrats or the Greens will be forming a government in this country. I do not want to be accused by Senator Murray—he is eager to speak to this—of being arrogant, but the value of those costings clearly is less than the public knowing what the major parties are seeking to do. We do not believe that what you are proposing is practical. It will tie up significant public resources, and it will not be supported by the government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) that we put this question to him concerning the National Party: if the National Party is not in coalition with the Liberal Party, will the National Party be excluded from this process?
—Senator Murray, we note your concern for the National Party, but funnily enough National Party senators have not pressed this matter on me.
—They were checking their travel allowances.
—I would not raise travel allowances today if I were you, Senator Cook of Cook's Tours. I would be a bit careful about it. I will not get diverted on that issue, although I may well wish to.
—I will table my letter from the auditor—I am all clear.

—Very good, Senator; I guess you hope for your sake that that ends there. Let us not get diverted. The terms in the bill before us relate to the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. They do not refer specifically to the National Party or Liberal Party. It is a hypothetical case. It is not a matter that the National Party or indeed the Liberal Party are worried about. We believe this is a sensible position in the way we have defined it in the bill, and the positions are well understood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to counter the idea that a measure like this should be the prerogative of the old parties. Democracy in Australia is in a very robust and flexible situation. The two-party system is breaking down and new parties are appearing right across the spectrum. I think most Australians like that and want to have more choice. But that choice will not be enhanced by restricting measures like this to the two old parties. It must be expanded.

SPEECH.PARA: I note from the tone of the contribution of the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, that these Treasury assessments can be seen as a positive thing for parties facing election, that they will be wanting to get them assessed. It is a selective thing: you make your choice, put your policy forward and have it assessed. I think the parties are going to want to have that done with policies they reckon can stand the scrutiny, so they come out looking pretty good to the electorate. If that is the case, why should that advantage not be given to the Australian Democrats, the Greens or other entities standing for election?

TALK.START.PARA: —Or the National Party.

—Or the National Party, for that matter. Senator Kemp said that the National Party have not approached him; maybe they do not want to have their policies put forward for scrutiny. I imagine the time will come when they will.

SPEECH.PARA: While the Senate is not going to accept my proposal that all parties facing the Australian electorate should be able to have their policies scrutinised in this fashion, I think that at least the notion of democracy, the evaluation that every vote is equal and the right of everybody to vote for other parties and to vote away from the government of the day ought to at least enable parties which have a presence in the parliament to have their policies scrutinised in this fashion.

I can understand the argument that Senator Kemp is putting forward, but on democratic terms it does not stand the rigour of analysis. It weights the odds in favour of the government and the opposition of the day and against the interests of the electorate, which wants to know whether the policies put forward by other parties are dinkum and will stand scrutiny as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that we are moving into a degree of farce. We have not yet hit high farce, but we are in partial farce at this stage. I say that because we have just had the government use its numbers to vote down a requirement in this Charter of Budget Honesty Bill that there be enforceability. So now this bill is optional—we can have optional honesty. Also, we now have had a very well crafted question from the Australian Democrats to the government about the National Party. The answer is that the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition refer their party promises for costing by Treasury. But, as the bill is now set, the National Party in fact is excluded from doing so.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know, particularly us in the Labor Party, that in an election the Liberal Party appeals to a certain part of the Australian electorate, and the National Party—the former Country Party—appeals to another set of the Australian electorate. But in government they govern as one party, as a coalition. If the Prime Minister chooses, he would refer only the policies of his party, as the majority coalition partner, for costing. Therefore, the extravagant promises that are often made by the National Party to rural Australia would escape costing and scrutiny.

If this bill proposes that the true cost of the promises made by political parties at an election be honestly disclosed, then all the political parties should be costed. It should not be just one party, the Liberal Party, and another party, the Labor Party, because then you could not judge what the true cost of a coalition—between the Liberal Party and the National Party—might be to the budget.

This is now farcical because you are saying, `It suits us to exclude our junior coalition partner.' I have to say to the government that you have embarked on this course, you have thumped your chest about a new order of government accountability to the people—all laudable things and good things to say—but, when one turns to the fine print of what you are proposing, it collapses like a house of cards. You can drive a coach‐and‐four through this. This becomes a charter for budget dishonesty if you do not have the full accounting of all the promises made by the major parties and by all the parties in the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying it should be compulsory? Because you have not proposed that.

—I voted a moment ago, Minister—and you voted against me and won because you had more numbers than I did—to make the provisions of this bill enforceable. The way that you cast your vote makes them optional.

BREAK.PARA: You have asked me where we stand. We stand for what we supported in the previous vote from the Democrats—that is, enforceability. I am also saying—and let this be very clear on the record—that it is not good enough for just the promises of the Liberal Party and the Labor Party to be costed, because we do not know what the true cost of a coalition promise is if the National Party is excluded. We do not know what the costs of the Democrats' promises might be. We do not know what the costs of the Greens' promises might be. We do not know what the costs of the promises of Senator Colston might be if he runs as the Queensland First Party in the next election.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or Senator Tambling.

—I am coming to him. We do not know what the costs of the promises of Senator Harradine, who runs as the Harradine Group in Tasmania, might be. And we do not know what the costs of the promises of the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory might be.

BREAK.PARA: The thing about truth is that you have to have it absolutely; you cannot have it partially. If you only have half the truth, you do not actually have the truth. If you only know what the Liberals and the Labor Party say, the electors of Australia do not know what the choices are across the board. I am sufficient of a democrat to say that they ought to.

Given the views now put by the Democrats on this motion that they have moved and the views put by Senator Brown on behalf of the Greens, I am of the view that he will collapse his amendment that he foreshadowed in relation to parties with members in parliament. That is what I understood Senator Brown to say. I note for the record that he nodded his head in an affirmative fashion when I asked him that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right.
—Because of that undertaking, we will vote for the Democrat amendment and for the amendment that Senator Brown has foreshadowed in a new form.
—It is disappointing that Senator Cook seems to have missed the—
—Persuade me. Don't insult me; persuade me.
—Senator Cook, are you arguing that the costings of all policies should be compulsory? Is that what you are saying?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The way this bill is structured is that it is for the Leader of the Opposition to submit his policy to the Prime Minister, who may then refer it to Treasury in whole or in part as he chooses. We have put an amendment down because we do not think that the Prime Minister should decide what part of an opposition's promises should be costed by Treasury. I do not care who the Prime Minister is or who the Treasurer is.

SPEECH.PARA: The structure of the bill that the minister has put accretes the power to the Prime Minister. What I am saying, in supporting the amendment from the Democrats, is that the Democrats should have the option, the Greens should have the option, Senator Colston, Senator Harradine and Senator Tambling should have the option of submitting their promises and having them costed. In truth, while it is optional, I think the electors of Australia will want to see what the parties are promising and what the costs of those promises are.

While it is an optional action by each party to make the submission, the practical reality is that, if a party does not submit its claims to be costed, voters in Australia will say, `What have they got to hide? How do we really know how much they are going to cost?' I do not think you need a compulsory provision in there. The electors can decide that. The electors of Australia are pretty wise people.

TALK.START.PARA: —I'll say!
—I revert back to the Abraham Lincoln thing: you can fool all of the people some of the time and some of the people all of the time but not all of the people all of the time.
—And that's what happened to you.
—Your time will come. I do think the amendment before the chamber ought to be supported in the knowledge that the Greens' amendment will follow it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cook has just argued both sides of the track. In his first contribution he was worried that the National Party or some other party may not put forward their policies for costing. Then I asked him whether it was compulsory. He agreed that the Labor Party did not believe it should be compulsory costing. Then he argued that, if they did not put forward their policies, they would bear an electoral cost. If you look at the Hansard and the logic of what you have just argued—
—No, read your bill.
—I am trying to analyse the arguments that you have put forward in the last five minutes. You have argued both sides of the track.
—No.

—Yes, you have. You have argued on the one hand that a minor party may not put forward their policies and therefore will escape scrutiny. That was of concern to you. You raised a total furphy in relation to the National Party. You stood up and argued that first up.

SPEECH.PARA: Then I said, `Do you want to make it compulsory for all policies to be costed?' and you said no. Then you said that, if they do not put up their policies, they will pay an electoral cost. The first argument is that they will get an electoral benefit by not putting forward their policies. The second argument is that they will bear an electoral cost. Your logic is all over the place. It is a big problem if you do not argue from principle, Senator Cook.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read your own bill.

—I am talking about the arguments that you have put forward. All I can say is that you have argued the contrary case within the space of about five minutes and, frankly, it shows the problem you face if you do not argue from principle. If you are trying to score some very short‐term political points on this, I have to tell you that your performance here has not been particularly edifying—particularly as you were an almost‐distinguished minister in a very non‐distinguished government.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are saying here is that it matters not if you have one person, say, a Green from Tasmania—Senator Brown may be misdirected but he is productive in the sense of producing vast amounts of paper and policies; his researchers do that for him. The amount of time that Treasury may spend in this pre‐election period on doing an analysis of Senator Brown's policies—one person in this parliament—may well be exactly the amount of time that would be required to be spent on the Labor Party's policies.

That is simply crazy and I am astonished that the Labor Party would think that is fair. Senator Murray has a slightly better case to put. I do not agree with it, but Senator Murray may argue that there are seven Democrats in this parliament—I guess it is no coincidence that the cut‐off point was five. We would never accuse the Democrats of self‐interest, Senator Murray, let me tell you.

I think what is being put forward here lacks commonsense, it will tie up huge resources and, if Senator Brown puts forward policies which require exactly the same amount of work as the Labor Party requires on the costing of its policies, I believe that is not a productive use of public resources. In the election context and the pressure to get material out, it is certainly not, and I am very surprised that the Labor Party would support this. I am very surprised and I suggest that you should have a further reflection on it and consult with your own party. It may not be in my lifetime, but Labor may get back into government some day. I hope, for the sake of our great nation, that is not true but there may be an occasion.

BREAK.PARA: The fact of the matter is that you have got to think in terms of practical public policy, and it is not practical public policy that one individual in the federal parliament should be tying up vast amounts of resources in a particularly difficult and pressured period—the same amount of resources as the alternative government. It is simply not good, practical policy.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —We can see that there are merits in allowing some access to Treasury resources to cost out proposals, especially before an election, which will have a budget implication. But one of the problems I have is that I belong to a minor party in the Senate which has an ideological viewpoint in relation to parliamentary representatives and the terminology of leadership.

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that parliamentary representatives are functional positions and I, for instance, as a representative of the Greens (WA), am an authorised representative of the Greens (WA) within the parliamentary process. In that sense, it is a functional rather than a leadership role.

We may—by virtue of the fact that we are here and have access to the information for making decisions—make decisions before many other people make them or know about issues. However, I feel that, in order to support amendments in relation to leaders of minor parties and not exclude parties like the Greens (WA), it could be either `minor party leaders' or at least `or authorised representatives'. Otherwise you have got a group of people who, because of their own beliefs in non‐hierarchical structures, are excluded from the system.

TALK.START.PARA: —We Greens have some flow of thought which you do not always see elsewhere in the chamber. I have asked for the wording of the amendment coming down the line to be such that it will take into account, at least to some degree, Senator Margetts's concern.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it shows you the difficulties we are having with this already—the pretty pass we have already come to. I do not know what the Labor Party view is of `an authorised representative', or how you define that. That is going to be difficult. That will test the parliamentary draftsmen, I can tell you.

SPEECH.PARA: What we are seeing is legislation simply made on the run without proper regard to the realities. I always enjoyed costing the Democrat policies and it used to lead to a lot of vigorous debate in this chamber. In an ideal world, you can argue that the proper costing of those policies would make sense because it may well expose what I would see as a fiscally irresponsible approach to public policy.

In reality, we are dealing with the hothouse of an election period and departments will be under pressure to produce fair and comprehensive material. We are now saying that we may have all of the Democrat policies which have to be costed, which are extensive, or used to be extensive; I am not sure whether you are still heading down that track but there are very extensive policies from the Democrats. Equally extensive and comprehensive policies will be put forward by both Greens. All of this will absorb huge amounts of departmental resources and I think a judgment has to be made.
Consideration interrupted; progress reported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —In recent times the issue of travel allowances has been given a public airing. In particular, the Labor Party have sought to air some parliamentary dirty linen. Honourable senators would understand why I was surprised when a constituent rang me the other day to advise that the deputy Labor leader in the Senate, Nick Sherry, was not into airing dirty linen; he was into airing the whole mattress. I asked my constituent: `What on earth could you possibly mean?' But allow me to explain. Last weekend the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), who is trying to establish his leadership credentials, was asked to explain why Senator Sherry claimed such an awe inspiringly huge figure for travel allowance. The sole defence proffered by Mr Crean on Senator Sherry's behalf was: `He doesn't own a house'.

SPEECH.PARA: When Mr Costello picked up on this theme and dubbed the honourable senator `the bedouin of Burnie' there was a flush of moral outrage and the honourable senator turned himself from his usual rose complexion to a deep red sherry. The senator, whilst in this flustered state, issued a media release claiming Mr Costello was wrong and that he, in fact, did have a home. Senator Sherry tells us Mr Costello's claim was false: `A simple check of the phone book of north-west Tasmania would have alerted him to my having a home in Burnie', Senator Sherry told us. For the record, I checked the telephone book for the north-west coast. Only your office number is listed, Senator Sherry, who I note is in the chamber.

So begs the question: why did Senator Sherry not correct the public record after Mr Crean made, to use the senator's words, the false claim that he didn't own a house? Senator Sherry, I submit, kept the guilty silence hoping the issues would pass. Why did Mr Crean give false information to defend Senator Sherry? Has Senator Sherry told Mr Crean that he was wrong? Why did Mr Crean say `Senator Sherry doesn't own a house'? The Register of Senators' Interests discloses that Senator Sherry does have a home office. A title search reveals that he owns 3 Hale St, Burnie. Given that this information is on the public record, why did Mr Crean say `Senator Sherry doesn't own a house'? Is it because Senator Sherry brags about the fact he doesn't have a house? Is it because everyone in the Labor Party knows that the home bit is a sham, and Mr Crean accidentally let the cat out of the bag? I am sure, if questioned, the honourable member for Hotham will use his rival for the top job's well-known excuse: `It seemed like a good idea at the time'.

For the record, Senator Sherry, in fact, owns two houses, including one in Canberra. On 27 September in the Advocate newspaper, Senators Sherry and Denman advertised `Labor senators' office' at 3 Hale St, Burnie. I have a copy of that advertisement in case any honourable senator wishes to see it. The advertisement proudly displays the office telephone number, the same one in the phone book.

Coming back to my constituent, he was full of consternation that the two senators were sharing this two- storey terrace house office. `Well', the constituent gasped, `but they are airing a double mattress on the verandah of the first floor'. I quickly assured him that Senator Denman would adhere to a strictly downstairs only policy. The constituent kindly photographed the office home and sent the photographs to me. Given that the bottom floor is office space, the living area must be minuscule. I have photographs of the home office, which clearly show the double mattress being aired on the first floor verandah, and a side shot of the home office.

A side shot of the house reveals not only the lack of depth to the house, confirming that it is very small, but that Senator Sherry likes the company of used caryards—which are proudly displayed next to the side of Senator Sherry's house. He undoubtedly feels at home with them. One can understand that there would be an affinity between them. But no, I am wrong. He doesn't feel at home. That is why he does not bother even putting the bed inside his home—because he does not stay there. That is why he has been giving the travel allowance such a touch along—because if he did stay at Burnie it might stand to reason that the bed would be indoors. The public display of a bed on the verandah did not convince the citizens of Burnie that you actually live in Burnie, Senator Sherry.

I do not criticise Senator Sherry for owning two houses. In fact, I applaud him, and well done. But what I cannot applaud is his guilty silence when coalition MPs are attacked for staying overnight in family homes. For the record, Senator Sherry claimed 420 days travel allowance in Canberra between 22 March 1993 to 24 February 1997. That equals about $58,800. My colleague the member for Braddon (Mr Miles) has publicly stated how Senator Sherry claimed, while staying at his mother's, a total of $43,320 for the equivalent period. Let me say on the record: the rules allow this to occur. But it is a bit rich attacking a coalition member for engaging in a similar practice, egging the attacks on, when you yourself are engaged in the same activity.

The lesson for the opposition is that people have a severe distaste for gross hypocrisy. If you hypocritically attack someone, your own details will be disclosed by feelings of justifiable righteous indignation. Senator Sherry, through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, the people of Canberra and of Opossum Bay are reviled by Labor's two-faced approach on this issue.

Whilst acknowledging that Senator Sherry is technically allowed to stay at his mum's place, I want to visit the extent of Senator Sherry's travel allowance claims. I must say that Senator Sherry's chairmanship of the superannuation committee was very uneventful, except for one thing. You have guessed it: his TA claims. In all, he claimed some 62 days. I have to say that his successor was somewhat more moderate in his claims. But Senator Sherry will say that he was busy. Fine, then let us see where he was busy.

Guess what? Although there was only one day of official hearing of his committee in Hobart, Senator Sherry claimed for 10 nights in Hobart. Undoubtedly, he was furiously taking counsel from all the doyens of the superannuation industry who live in Hobart. However, his problem is that he was continually criticised for his lack of consultation. Ten days would allow you to talk with every agent and, for that matter, every policy holder in Hobart and still have time to spare to talk to your hairdresser about superannuation. Yet, the senator remains so blissfully ignorant about superannuation matters. I wonder if the honourable senator claimed travel allowance for his consultations in the barber's chair as well.

But the ludicrous nature of the claims is that he spent more time allegedly on superannuation in Hobart than he did in Perth, Adelaide and Brisbane combined—combined. Are you really going to tell the people of Australia that there is a little hotbed of superannuation knowledge in Hobart which far exceeds the combined knowledge and wisdom on superannuation that resides in Perth, Adelaide and Brisbane? The ring of truth, credibility, is absent when the figures are analysed. No city in Australia other than Sydney got such an overwhelming dose of consultation on superannuation matters as did Hobart.

But this love affair with Hobart continued when Senator Sherry became the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. He enjoyed that position between 24 March 1993 and 11 March 1996. Senator Sherry, during that time, claimed for 652 days of travel allowance. Of those, 315 were in Canberra and 125 were in Hobart. Altogether for Tasmania he claimed 160 days; that is, 47.5 per cent, or nearly half, of his non-Canberra claims.

With that degree of consultation in Tasmania, Senator Sherry should have understood his portfolio responsibilities; unfortunately, he did not. With that amount of time, he would have had the time to not only speak with every stakeholder in the forestry and aquaculture industry; he also would have had the time to speak to every tree, fish, cow and sheep in Tasmania—and, of course, we know that he did not devote himself to his duties for which he claimed his parliamentary travel allowance.

Yesterday Senator Sherry told this chamber, `I spend the majority of my time in Burnie, and I travel as required.' For the record, Senator Sherry was parliamentary secretary, as I said before, between 24 March 1993 and 11 March 1996—let us say about 1,080 days. Yet we know he claimed 652 days for travel allowance; that is, 60 per cent of his time.

I submit that Senator Sherry has misled the Senate. At best, he could have only stayed in Burnie for 40 per cent of the time. But for Senator Sherry, shadow spokesman for finance and superannuation, 40 per cent is a majority. No wonder we had a $10.3 billion deficit under Labor.

Further, Senator Sherry told us, `Anything my minister, Bob Collins, asked me to do for him, I did, no matter what it required.' It is now obvious: Senator Collins told him, `Stay at your mums's or stay in Canberra; the vast majority of the time stay out of the rest of Australia, hide yourself in Tasmania or in your office in Canberra; we do not want to see you out in the electorate amongst the mainlander constituency because you will undoubtedly lose votes for us.' But if you are honestly trying to suggest to us that Senator Collins told you to spend such a vast amount of your time on primary industry matters only in Tasmania, I have to say to you that I doubt it, and I also doubt that Senator Collins would come into this chamber and say, `I told Senator Sherry to spend so much time in Tasmania on these issues.'

When we came to government, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you well know, the issues of the aquaculture industry were not fixed; the forest industry was not fixed. We fixed those within the first 18 months of our government. If there was a common theme going around amongst the stakeholders, it was that Senator Sherry had not consulted or listened to them. We did; we fixed up the problems. I submit that Senator Sherry has a lot of explaining to do, in connection with his claims for travel allowance, as to why he had this fascinating love for Tasmania.

Mr Acting Deputy President Calvert, as you come from Tasmania, as do I, you would find it very rich that Senator Sherry has the audacity from time to time to make allegations that the north‐west coast of Tasmania is not adequately serviced. He has this pretence, this absolute pretence, of having a home in Burnie which has now been exploded away, absolutely shot away—not by us, but by Mr Crean, the member for Hotham. Mr Crean unwittingly let the cat out of the bag by stating what everybody in this place knows, what everybody in the ALP knows: that Senator Sherry does not count Burnie as his home. Why else would Mr Crean have said to the Australian people, `Senator Sherry does not own a home.'

Senator Sherry, if everybody in your party knew that you were based in Burnie, that you lived in Burnie, why would it be that Mr Crean would say, `He doesn't own a home, and that explains his huge travel allowance'? The only defence offered by Mr Crean was that Senator Sherry does not own a home.

Senator Sherry on his own admission says, `That assertion is wrong'—he is nodding his head in agreement. Therefore, the only defence proffered on your part, Senator Sherry, by Mr Crean has been knocked out, knocked away and dispelled as an untruth. As a result you have been left with no defence whatsoever for your high travel allowance claims.
I am pleased that Senator Sherry is the next speaker in this debate. I look forward to his explanation, as, I am sure, the vast majority of Australians do as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —If there is one truism in politics it is that if you are dishing it out you have to be prepared to cop it. So, with three ministers gone, two highly placed prime ministerial staffers sacked and public servants being stood down or resigning, it is no surprise to me that I am the target of retaliation. What I find pathetic is the insubstantial and blatant lying that is going on at this time.

SPEECH.PARA: The first step in the coalition campaign was to circulate an anonymous scandal sheet to the press gallery last Friday. Just to prove that they cannot get their facts right, they alleged that I live in Devonport. Well, I have got news for my mate Simon Crean and my enemy Mr Peter Costello—I own a home and live in Burnie. The coalition got it wrong. This scandal sheet went on to ask why I was on the Gold Coast so frequently—note that they have dropped this line now—but I have been able to readily produce evidence that I was on official business on each occasion. I can hardly be held responsible for the fact that many of these primary industry bodies use the Gold Coast as a venue for their conferences. No wonder no journalist is interested in that line any more.
Mr Costello, in answer to a question on Monday which had nothing to do with travel allowance, said:
There is one name that is talked about . . . when it comes to claiming travel allowances in this parliament: Senator Nick Sherry.

He goes on to detail my 1995 claims. Leaving aside the fact that, in order to manipulate the figures he uses a calendar year reference rather than a financial year reference, as is usual, it is true that in that year I claimed TA on 66 per cent of nights.

Yet what does Mr Costello say about his colleague the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), who in the first nine months of government claimed 80 per cent of nights on TA? This from a minister who aspires to promotion in the cabinet. This is the minister who, in a statement to the House yesterday, said that all of his claims were made in good faith and within the spirit of the guidelines. This from a minister who then went on later in the day to water down even that tepid defence and to say that his travel claims were free of deliberate and systematic error. Yet this is the minister who will not answer specific allegations, the minister who waffles on in general terms. I, on the other hand, am willing to respond to any specific allegation of abuse. You specify the day and I will specify the nature of my claim.

But the coalition campaign did not stop there. Senator Kemp, in answer to a question on charter travel, found himself unable to comprehend the question, as usual, let alone answer it. So he directed an attack on my TA claims. Like his coalition colleagues, Senator Kemp made no specific allegations. When challenged by way of a supplementary question to detail even one claim for TA which he believed to be incorrect, he too merely waffled for a minute as he usually does and then sat down.

Again, when on the noting of answers he was given five minutes to raise even one specific allegation against me, he failed to do so. But you have to say that the reactionary member for Braddon, Mr Miles, unlike his coalition colleagues, has at least made one specific allegation. In a press release issued yesterday, he alleges that I have claimed TA at the wrong rate. I assert to the Senate that each one of my Hobart TA claims meets the requirements as specified in the Department of Administrative Services guidelines.
Mr Miles went on to query whether I stayed at Opossum Bay. He claims that Opossum Bay is not part of Hobart. The DAS guidelines set rates for capital city claims. The guidelines state:
Capital city is as defined (in relation to its boundaries) by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
The Australian Bureau of Statistics definition states that:

BREAK.PARA: The greater Hobart division comprises the local government areas of Hobart, Glenorchy, Clarence and Brighton and the predominantly urban parts of Kingborough, New Norfolk and Sorell. The division is Tasmania's principal, regional and administrative focus.

In addition, in response to a query from my office, the Department of Administrative Services confirmed some 3½ years ago that Opossum Bay, in the city of Clarence, was within the Hobart travel allowance claim area. To argue any differently is to argue that Parramatta is not part of Sydney, Dandenong is not part of Melbourne and Port Adelaide is not part of Adelaide.
