Mr Miles challenges me to answer the allegations in his press release. I have done so here and I am pleased to acknowledge that Senator Abetz, in reference to this matter, acknowledges `that the rules allow this to occur'. Thank you, Senator Abetz.

This is a government that said there was no case to answer in the Colston matter. This is a Prime Minister (Mr Howard) who said that the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) had his immense confidence and full support. This is a government in which the former Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Peter McGauran) thrice asserted that his claims were valid. On the basis of evidence to the contrary, they have all gone.

I will now return to Senator Abetz's photographic evidence of my home in Burnie, to set the record straight and make it very clear. I purchased the double story terrace in Burnie approximately 3½ years ago. I know it well because I spent approximately a month redecorating it from top to bottom. In the bottom part, in the front two rooms, at personal expense I locate a private electoral office. I live in the living room, the bedroom and the kitchens at the back of that terrace property.

I say to Senator Eric Abetz, I say to all the members of the government, I say to the press gallery: when I return to Burnie on Friday to go to the Burnie show and spend the next week or two on the north‐west coast, you are all welcome to come and visit my home in Burnie and see my office in Burnie. They are both in the same terraced house.

The reason I established an additional Burnie office, at personal expense, was in order to improve the service requirements on the north‐west coast of Tasmania. My electoral office is in Devonport. Unfortunately, on the coast, people from Burnie will not travel to Devonport and vice versa. So I made a commitment to open, at personal expense, an electoral office in Burnie, at 3 Hale Street. It is a property I own and it is staffed by one of my three electoral officers.

That is not dissimilar to what Mr Miles and Senator Watson have done. Mr Miles and Senator Watson have rented a property in Devonport and share staff arrangements. I note Mr Miles's wife works for Senator Watson. But I am not going to get into that sort of dirt; I am not going to get into that sort of area. I am going to stick to the facts. Let us stick to the facts. What I have done in Burnie is fundamentally no different from what Senator Watson and Mr Miles have done on the north‐west coast of Tasmania to improve service to the electorate.

I enjoy the north‐west coast of Tasmania. I love it. Unfortunately, there is a used car yard next to my office and my home in Burnie and, unfortunately, there is a great big woodchip pile in front of it. When I go out onto the verandah of my living quarters, I do see that big woodchip pile.

With respect to the phone number, I have here the north-west coast phone directory. It says: Senator Nick Sherry, 3 Hale Street, and the phone number is 64319986. I also have another number, which is not published, 64319809.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's not in the phone book.
—But Senator Abetz, my home at 3 Hale Street, where I have established a second electorate office, is clearly published and the phone number is clearly published.

BREAK.PARA: As I said earlier, I issue an open invitation to all in the media and all in the government to come and visit this weekend at Burnie. They can walk through my 3 Hale Street residence. They can see that there is a bed there, there is a TV, all my books, all my personal clothes—most of my personal possessions are at 3 Hale Street, Burnie. I make an open challenge: come and see.
I know that the coalition will continue to throw mud at me. All I ask is that they substantiate or specify any claims against me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week in this place, we witnessed an unjustified and undignified attack on one of Australia's eminent economists. The Democrats are well aware that, when a government lacking leadership is in disarray and it flounders, it resorts to underhand and dishonest attacks on parties and individuals. Indeed, with this government, it is becoming more and more obvious that if one dares to disagree—whether an individual or an organisation—the first thing that you usually face is defunding. If they cannot get you that way, then it is simply dismissal or denigration.

SPEECH.PARA: But what we witnessed in here last week during one of the question times was one of Mr Howard's greenhouse henchmen—the fossil fuel apostle, Senator Warwick Parer—struggling to justify this government's foolish climate change position. Senator Parer, who is incapable of attacking the strong arguments against the federal government's shoddy greenhouse record, used parliamentary privilege to attack one of his government's eminent critics on this issue. But Senator Parer did not or could not attack this man's economics; he attacked his spirituality. Senator Parer vilified Dr Clive Hamilton, Executive Director of the Australian Institute. Why? Because, like many Australians, Dr Hamilton believes that the government's greenhouse gas stance is irresponsible and built on shonky research and shonky figures.

Dr Clive Hamilton is not one of the Howard style economists—those who believe in the quick buck mentality and who would happily pummel everything and anything in their way—whether it is the environment or people—for a short‐term economic gain. Rather, Dr Hamilton sees economics in terms of the big picture. He recognises that jeopar dising the environment to fill a few fossil fuel pockets is not the sort of mentality which will secure the planet for future generations, and this is where Senator Parer has a problem.

For the benefit of senators who may not be aware of Dr Hamilton's expertise, I will fill you in from his CV. Dr Hamilton is founder and Executive Director of the Australia Institute, a non‐profit public policy research centre. He is a visiting fellow at the ANU and an adjunct professor at Sydney's University of Technology.

Dr Hamilton, who is trained in maths and economics, has filled a number of positions and they include: senior executive in the Prime Minister's portfolio as head of research in the Federal Resource Assessment Commission; senior economist in the Federal Bureau of Industry Economics; senior economic adviser to the government of Indonesia; and Director of the Graduate Program at the National Centre for Development Studies at the Australian National University. He has served as a member of the United Nations Group of Experts on Least Developed Countries and, this year, Dr Hamilton addressed delegates at climate change negotiations in Bonn. He has been invited to act as a keynote speaker at many prestigious conferences. He has published four books, and is a widely experienced and respected lecturer.
Underlying all of Dr Hamilton's work has been the credo of the Australia Institute, and that is:
. . . to promote a more just, sustainable and peaceful society through research, publication and vigorous participation in public debate.

The aim of the institute is to restore a balance between economic efficiency and considerations of the community, environment and ethics. I think that honourable senators will agree that Dr Hamilton's curriculum vitae is exemplary.

In the midst of his manic diatribe last week, Senator Parer offered Australians his own guidance on who we should believe on the issue of greenhouse gas economics. He suggested that the public listen to ABARE, the apologist for all polluting industries, whose macro‐economic modelling has been bucketed by all and sundry—and I am talking about nationally as well as internationally.

Was Senator Parer seriously telling people to listen to ABARE, whose chief, Brian Fisher, last year, told the Royal Institute of International Affairs that allowing small island states of the Pacific to be inundated with rising sea levels—and for us then to be involved in relocating their populations—while industrial nations did nothing about greenhouse, may be the most economically efficient way of dealing with climate change? Was he seriously telling people to accept the ABARE models, which use wildly fanciful bases for their assumptions, such as a nonsensical $900 a tonne carbon tax? These are models which, I must say, are now being investigated by the federal ombudsman and, as we all know, are substantially funded by the fossil fuel industries.

No. I think people would much rather consider Dr Hamilton's reasonable, rational and responsible economics. So let us look at some of the other people that Senator Parer considers the public should be listening to instead of Dr Hamilton. There is the good senator himself. Senator Parer is a former coal industry chief, who thought gas was not a fossil fuel, a resources minister who shrugged off the greenhouse effect numerous times, and who laughed off rainfall changes as being helpful to farmers. These are comments which show not only how frivolous he thinks the debate is but how little he knows about climate change.

While the rest of the world is working towards a solution, Senator Parer still does not seem to believe that there actually is a problem. Indeed, he is on the record as saying that greenhouse issues will be forgotten in 10 years.

Perhaps Senator Parer would like people to listen to his other colleagues. There is Senator Ian Macdonald, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment—and I am look at Hansard of 26 November 1996—who had to be reminded by Senator Kernot about the difference between the ozone layer and the greenhouse effect.

Perhaps we should listen to that international giant, Mr Alexander Downer—if we are going to talk about personalities, we should mention that he has even been photographed wearing fishnet stockings—who is telling the rest of the world, seriously, that Australia should be allowed to boost its greenhouse gas emissions. What a position to take off to the international conference in Japan at the end of the year. When the rest of the world is sitting around the table looking at how we can come to terms with this problem, and constructively deal with it, we have a minister who is seriously suggesting that we go to that conference with the basic premise that we, Australia, want to be out of step with everybody else and boost emissions.

What about some of the other people your government endorsed at the recent so‐called `Pre‐Eminent International Conference on Climate Change'? There was US Senator Malcolm Wallop—who makes Pauline Hanson look like a moderate—and US Senator Chuck Hagel. I will give some of the background of both of them. Before his political career, Malcolm Wallop jointly ventured oil and gas development projects in Nebraska, Montana and Wyoming. The efforts of these men to derail global greenhouse undertakings in the United States are very well documented. Are these the people that Senator Parer is seriously asking us to put ahead of Dr Hamilton? Really, Senator, I would argue that the credentials on your side of this debate are seriously lacking. Disreputable models and disruptive advisers do not add up to good greenhouse policy.

Senator Parer also has—I hope, like most of us—now seen a statement by professional economists on climate change. Like Dr Clive Hamilton, these economists are arguing that Australia has to do something. I seek leave to incorporate a statement by professional economists on climate change. It is a one‐page statement accompanied by three pages of names.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
A STATEMENT BY PROFESSIONAL ECONOMISTS ON CLIMATE CHANGE

1. A report by over 2000 distinguished international scientists under the auspices of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has determined that `the balance of evidence suggests a discernible human influence on global climate'. As economists we believe that global climate change carries with it significant environmental, economic, social and geopolitical risks and that preventive steps are justified.

2. Economic studies have found that there are many potential policies to reduce greenhouse gas emissions for which the benefits outweigh the costs. Policy options are available that would slow climate change without harming employment or living standards in Australia, and these may in fact improve Australian productivity in the long term.

3. The economic modelling studies on which the Government is relying to assess the impacts of reducing Australia's greenhouse gas emissions overestimate the costs and underestimate the benefits of reducing emissions.

4. Economic instruments—such as carbon taxes and trading of emission permits within and between countries—will be an important part of a comprehensive climate change policy. `Joint implementation' policies, in which Australian firms carry out emission-reduction investments in developing countries, can also play a significant role. Revenues raised from taxes or the sale of permits can be used to reduce the budget deficit or to lower existing taxes.

5. Developing countries will need to take measures to reduce significantly their greenhouse gas emissions in due course. But since OECD countries are responsible for over 80% of increased greenhouse gases in the atmosphere, and are in a stronger economic position to reduce their emissions, they should take the lead in cutting emissions.

6. An appropriate equity and efficiency principle for the distribution of the emissions reductions is one where countries which are responsible for high per capita emissions and which are more wealthy should do more to reduce their emissions.

7. Withdrawal from the Framework Convention on Climate Change could seriously harm Australia's long-term economic and diplomatic interests. It would be damaging to our longer-term economic interests if Australia became locked into a fossil-fuel based economic structure while the rest of the world shifts to low-emission energy sources over the next decades.
Signed by 131 professional economists

PARA.EMPHASIS: Signatories to the Professional Economists' Statement on Climate Change

ROW.ENTRY: Dept. of Natural Resources and Environment
Dept. of Agriculture and Resource Management
National Institute of Economic and Industry Research
Monash University & Chinese University of Hong Kong
Dep. Director, Asia Aust Research Centre
CSIRO Division of Wildlife and Ecology

SPEECH.PARA: All signatories signed in their personal capacities only.
* These signatories made amendments to the statement before signing.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we can see from these names, they come from all states. They come from virtually every university in the country—the University of New England, New South Wales, Wollongong, Adelaide, Canberra, Sydney, Queensland, La Trobe, ANU, Flinders et cetera. Surely, these are the people who we should be listening to. I also think that most Australians would prefer to listen to the 2,500 eminent scientists and experts rather than the nonsensical position of some of those intimately involved in the coal and fossil fuel industries.

SPEECH.PARA: The last point I wish to raise is my deep regret and disappointment that the Senate, a place which should be seen as unprejudiced and open minded, has been the venue for Senator Parer's attack on an individual's most private and personal aspect: their spirituality.

The Democrats and, I dare say, members of Senator Parer's own party and others in this place, absolutely abhor this kind of attack. Whether individuals choose to meditate, seek guidance from a higher being or act on their dreams is totally up to them. It should not be up to Senator Parer or anyone else to deride them. It should not be up to Senator Parer or anyone else to treat anyone in such a disrespectful lmanner, for any aspect of their spirituality.

BREAK.PARA: I ask Senator Parer to exorcise some of the clearly evident demons of his own before he goes searching for those in others. I ask him and his colleagues to stop the greenhouse nonsense; stop peddling the mistruths and the half‐truths; stop listening to a couple of industries; and start doing what is in the best interests of all Australians. Stop the name calling, sit down and, before it is too late, seriously look at Australia's best interests as well as our best interests as a global citizen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to raise important issues with regard to the state of health in Northern Territory Aboriginal communities.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst many of the programs and government initiatives, at both the territory and Commonwealth level, have improved the health of Aboriginal people over the years, the results are still unacceptable. The problem is complex and difficult to solve. The federal coalition government and the Country Liberal Northern Territory government have put in place successful programs such as the strong woman, strong baby, strong culture program; a food and nutrition audit; living with alcohol programs; and the Northern Territory food project aimed at educating and improving the health of Aboriginal people. But still, unfortunately, many health problems continue to exist in Aboriginal communities.

A fundamental and vital factor affecting the health of Aboriginal people in these communities is diet. The food eaten, the amount of alcohol consumed, the decreased use of traditional bush tucker, the high level of sugar and many other dietary influences contribute to the poor overall health in many communities.

A major influence on the diet and health of people in Aboriginal communities is always and inevitably the community store. Lee, Bonson and Powers, from the Menzies School of Health Research, comment in a journal article entitled `The effect of retail store managers on Aboriginal diet in remote communities' that, in many Aboriginal communities, there is only one community store providing over 95 per cent of the total dietary intake and—

. . . one way to avoid arbitrary variations in store managers' individual ordering patterns, and to ensure that the food supplied reflects both community preference and nutritional needs, is to implement a store food and nutrition policy.

This makes the role of a store in the community vital to the ongoing health of the community. No adequate competition exists to provide alternatives in pricing and, perhaps even more importantly, nutritional and choice values.

It is my belief that, in many communities, Aboriginal residents are being badly let down by the managers and management committees of their community‐owned stores. The best interests of the community are not being served by proper responsibility or accountability. Unfortunately, in a significant number of cases, the mismanagement of community stores involves both financial and health policy concerns.

One recent review by me of a community store at Maningrida—which has an annual trading revenue of about $4 million in shop sales and about 1,000 people living in the community—shows that, for three consecutive years, there were qualified auditors' reports stating that the gross profit margins were not consistent with expected results, based on the set mark‐up percentages. In fact, growth profit margins were well below what was expected.

In plain English, this means that either cash was being taken out of the till or stock was walking out of the door unpaid for. I am concerned about the huge rip‐off of cash and stock, and the resultant honesty and competence of management, in stores of this size. Stores in Aboriginal communities cannot continue to face cash misappropriations—like the $150,000 at Maningrida—or hundreds of thousands of dollars in stock losses each year.

The profits of these community stores should be going back directly into the community by way of dividends for residents and improved community services. This is a legal and, more importantly, a moral obligation. Managers of stores, and their management committees, must ensure that there is no financial mismanagement or stock loss that deprives the community of what is rightfully theirs. Profits from these stores must be used to improve the wellbeing of the people and lift their standard of living, not line the pockets of rip‐off merchants, unscrupulous managers or selected members of the community. They should be providing money for education, cultural events, training and sporting events, and things that keep a community alive, healthy and active.

In many Aboriginal community stores the problems are compounded: stock disappears at an astonishing rate without being paid for; large sums of money are fleeced; and the nutritional value of foodstock is very low. Aboriginal communities must address this unfortunate financial situation if they are to gain true self‐determination. It is a situation I wish to continually highlight but, unfortunately, do not have sufficient time today to dwell on it in this particular speech.

Rather, I wish to concentrate on the poor nutrition in Aboriginal communities. The saddest and most shocking aspect of the problem is that, in many cases, a poor diet does not affect those consuming that poor diet. In many cases, such as those of expectant mothers, it can affect the unborn child in later life in many ways such as low birth weight, stunting of growth, subsequent learning problems at school, immune deficiencies and high rates of hospitalisation, morbidity and mortality.

A cycle of poor nutrition before birth leads to poor health in childhood and adult life. Repetition through generations must be broken. Nutrition is one piece of the health puzzle, and a very important one. Improving nutrition would go a long way to addressing the shocking health problems in Aboriginal communities. I must stress that stores in Aboriginal communities do have a vital role in the health of the community, and that there are success stories.

Let me cite the example of an extremely successful Aboriginal group operating stores in the Northern Territory. The Arnhem Land Progress Association, commonly known as ALPA, has been trading successfully for 25 years, and is an exceptional example of an Aboriginal cooperative retailer. Their financial accounts for the year ended 30 April 1997 show a trading turnover of $14 million and a gross profit of over $4 million in their own stores. Compare this with my earlier example of the poorly operated community store at Maningrida!

ALPA itself has stores in five Arnhem Land communities. These are: Minjilang, known as Croker Island; Galiwin'ku, or Elcho Island; Gapuwiyak, or Lake Evella; Ramingining; and Milingimbi. They also provide management assistance to the communities of Warruwi, Belyuen, Umbakumba and Lajamanu in the Northern Territory, and Turkey Creek and Noonkanbah in the Kimberley region of Western Australia.

ALPA is owned and controlled by Aborigines. Its board meets every three months and all policy decisions regarding ALPA are made at these meetings. The board consists of 18 Aboriginal directors from the five member communities and includes the board chairman, the Reverend Djiniyini Gondarra, along with five council chairmen representing their various communities.
It is this Aboriginal control and a strong, clear positive mission statement giving directions that accounts for ALPA's success. I will quote from their mission statement which says:

ALPA's mission is to conduct an efficient retail business emphasising customer service, nutrition and staff development, training and education. ALPA strives to enhance the social and economic development of its members. Giving primacy to their cultural heritage, dignity and desire for equality with their fellow Australians.

The emphasis on staff development, training and education has led to the vast majority of store workers being Aborigines who receive training in all aspects of store work. We are seeing people who live in the community, and the community itself, benefiting from the opportunity for employment, increased education and training.

The control over decision making processes with regard to their stores and the opportunities they present empowers the community and raises self‐esteem in the individual and pride in the community. Coupled with a good nutrition policy and sound management, this can only enhance a community—and it is important that people realise this importance. The promotion of the health of the community is something that the store should play a major role in and accept responsibility for, particularly with regard to nutrition.

ALPA has a strong nutrition policy that includes programs such as ensuring an ample supply of fresh fruit and vegetables, satisfying the dietary needs of diabetics and employing Good Food people in each store to help make this policy work. ALPA subsidises the full cost of the freight on fruit and vegetables, a significant amount of which has to be air‐freighted into the communities. This is made possible by charging a levy on cigarettes—perhaps a very good idea which many other stores in the Territory, not just those in Aboriginal communities, should consider adopting.

As you walk into an ALPA store you will see fresh fruit prominently displayed, not just the junk and fatty food and pink lemonade that stares you in the face in so many other community stores. The takeaway arms of ALPA shops are replacing foods high in fat with other healthier alternatives and are also making available stews and steamed and fried rice, and promoting fruit juices and diet drinks instead of sugared soft drinks. Simple decisions and leadership examples are quite easy to implement and will have a measurable impact on the health of the community.

I have recently written letters to all community store managers, school principals, health workers and ATSIC regional councillors in the Northern Territory seeking their views and advice. With the help and advice of the Northern Territory Department of Health, I am hoping that the nutritional value of the stock in some Aboriginal stores can be vastly improved, with a subsequent improvement in the health of the community.

The federal government is also taking important initiatives to improve Aboriginal health. The national plan to monitor indigenous health is another example of the federal coalition government taking strong action to address a problem. Instead of relying on rhetoric and little result, as Labor has done with regard to so many problems, particularly Aboriginal health, we are seeing the government require all health workers to report against a set of national performance indicators and targets to lift the health status of the indigenous population.

The setting of clear targets that are appropriate for different circumstances experienced across different regions of Australia, along with improved reporting and evaluation, is another important step by the federal government in improving Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health. The targets we have set include: a reduction by 50 per cent in the death rate for infants and by 20 per cent in the overall death rate over 10 years, and an increase in immunisation and vaccination for key conditions. An example is the target of achieving 95 per cent of Aboriginal people immunised against hepatitis B in two years.

The benchmarks are important as they set clear objectives for state and territory governments to achieve. They have been endorsed by the national Aboriginal community controlled health organisations and state and territory governments. With the concerted effort being taken at the state and federal level, I am hopeful that we will soon see an improvement in Aboriginal health. The Northern Territory Country Liberal Party government is working closely with organisations such as Batchelor College's Health Unit, the Menzies School of Health Research and with their own Territory health services.

There is a challenge for governments, supervising authorities and Aboriginal community leaders to achieve health improvements, policy improvements, by redressing the poor nutritional value of food sold in the community stores as a first instance, as well as lifting the standards of financial accountability and the performance of basic food providers, the community store.

There are, of course, other challengers, particularly those at universities and the need for university research and health work, such as the excellent work being conducted at Flinders University in South Australia and the issues that are associated with that. I hope, in the future, we will see more of that type of academic activity take place in northern Australia and particularly in the Northern Territory. We cannot allow the dramatic problems of the Maningridas, the Numbulwars and the Hodgson Downs to continue unabated. The costs to future Aboriginal generations are too high and must be fixed now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak on matters that flow from the Victorian Supreme Court of Appeal decision in relation to John Elliott and the NCA. I would like to draw together some information that I have previously put before the Senate with some further evidence that has never been put before a jury.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to start with Mr Ken Jarrett's original evidence that he gave to the NCA under oath on 19 December 1990. Page 565 of this transcript is a discussion between Mr Jarrett and the counsel on behalf of the NCA, Mr Rozenes, referring to the $39 million loss incurred by Elders:
Rozenes:
Were you involved or did you have any involvement in that transaction?
Jarrett:
Yes.
Rozenes:
How long prior to 11 January?
Jarrett:
Well, early September 1987 . . . I should explain—
He goes on to say:
that we purchased Courage Brewery in September the previous year, and we paid for it, I think, about January 1988 . . . the cost 1.4 billion pounds—
He goes on to explain that it was agreed to do this at a meeting of Elders management in August of that year. He is asked who else attended that meeting, and he says:
I think—actually it would have been John Elliott, myself, Ken Biggins, and I think Peter Scanlon was there.
He was then asked: what happened after the decision?
Well, I went—almost immediately I went overseas with John Elliott.
On page 567, he goes on to say that he was in Japan. He continues:

. . . which I think was early September, I got a call from Peter Scanlon who said he had been talking with Alan Hawkins of Equity Corp and Alan—and raised this question about hedging and Alan Hawkins had said that they would be interested in doing a—being the counterparty. I spoke to Peter Scanlon about a price of such a deal.
Another question:
After you spoke to Scanlon, what did you do then?
Jarrett:
John Elliott was there. I checked with John Elliott to make sure he was happy to do the transaction. It was less—it was 120 million pounds, not—was where—came to hedge up to 200—
He goes on to say:
He was happy with that and I relayed that to Peter Scanlon and told him we were happy for him to commit to Hawkins . . .
but Peter Scanlon came back and confirmed that he had confirmed the transaction with Hawkins and gave me the figures.
Rozenes:
And was the deal finally closed out?
Jarrett:
Well the short term one matured in January.
Rozenes:
And that resulted in a loss?
Jarrett:
The loss in that statement of $39 million.
He goes on to say:
Well the initial—the initial transition was done by Peter Scanlon and then
I had a few phone conversations, I suppose just confirming what he had confirmed really.
On page 570, Rozenes says:
If I can take you now to the second transaction, that is the transaction that resulted in Elders Finance incurring the loss of approximately $27 million on or about 7 September 1988.
Jarrett says:
Yes.
And he goes on to explain the background and says:

. . . the place and I think John Elliott had been talking to Roger Douglas about New Zealand. I think that he came back understanding that the New Zealand economy was ahead of Australia and turning around . . . but they believed because of the strength of the economy that the New Zealand dollar would appreciate over the following twelve months . . . So Ken Biggins and myself argued to John Elliott that we should close the contract out.
Once it was established that they were losing money on this transaction. He continues:
. . . but in any case the contracts were closed out and—result in that second payment of 27 million—
to Hawkins.
Later in the evidence—on page 580—the discussion returns to the first transaction where Jarrett again confirms that Scanlon, Elliott and Biggins were all involved in the discussions.
I would like to move on to Ken Biggins's evidence which he also gave on 19 December 1990 under oath to the NCA. He was asked:
Can you tell us what it is that you know about the first transaction?
And he replied (page 613):

Yes. Prior to 11 January, Ken Jarrett rang me and said that a fax would be coming from the BNZ addressed to me and to him, I think, at area 1, 1 Garden Street, seeking confirmation of the existence of foreign exchange contracts; that he had already spoken to Mr John Elliott about this matter and that John agreed that area 1 thing, that was an area 1 exposure; that area 1, namely me . . .
The transcript continued:

I took that on board and said I would speak to John Elliott during the course of the—when the fax turned up, in due course, when he was around, and if he gave me authority to acknowledge it, I would. I spoke to John Elliott. He said, yes, it was OK to acknowledge the BNZ and I did so.
Page 617:
Well, then, what were the circumstances of this particular—
Answer:
I do not know. You would have to ask Mr Jarrett. I mean, I did not—he told me he had spoken to Mr Elliott. I then sought Mr Elliott's approval to send off the reply.
He then goes on to say:
No, the purpose of it was explained to me to cover our long pound selling positions.
He was asked:

BREAK.PARA: Can you just tell me the conversation you had with Mr Elliott about this, what did you say to him and what did he say to you?
Answer:
I said that Ken Jarrett had spoken to me on the phone—or this is when the fax turned up from the BNZ from memory.
Question:
Yes?
Answer:

That Ken Jarrett had spoken to me and said he had already spoken to you about this particular hedging contract or contracts and that you had advised him that the corporate area would acknowledge to the BNZ the existence of the contract, and that I was seeking his approval to do so. He said fine.
That is John Elliott. John Elliott said, `Fine.' The answer continued:
Yes, he had been through it with Mr Jarrett and he was happy it could be acknowledged.
And it goes on and on. All of the principals that were charged were involved in setting up this deal.
I would briefly like to return to some evidence I gave previously to the Senate which was Mr Elliott's own testimony, where he implicates himself as having been involved in this transaction. He says:
And so, I agreed with him that he ought to take the 120 million pound cover but that it ought to be done through a bank.
On page 665 of Mr Elliott's transcript, Mr Rozenes said:
Well you gave an approval, I take it in principle.
Mr Elliott said:
I said, that it is fine, do it . . .
Well, the next time I really remember having any dealings about that transaction was in January when I—I suppose I hit the roof about it.
And he hit the roof because they had lost all that money. But again, Elliott admits he knew all about it. He was privy to the conversation to set the deal up. He gave authority to set the deal up.
Then we go to Mr Scanlon. Mr Scanlon is the man who actually set the deal up, and he admits it as shown in his transcript from 19 December:
I think, sir, my involvement in that may be in setting up a hedge contract that led to the transaction.
Mr Rozenes:
And can you recall when it was when you set up the hedge contract?
Mr Scanlon:
Approximately the third quarter of 1987.
He goes on to say:

In a conversation by phone with a Mr Hawkins from the Equiticorp Group, the conversation of which had other purposes if I recall, I asked if he had any interest in being on the other side of such a hedge contract. He, in fact, said yes, and I suspect that that led to that hedge contract . . .
After that phone call, I then talked to the Treasurer of Elders IXL, Mr Ken Jarrett, who in my recollection was not in the office here, he was overseas somewhere at that time.
Mr Rozenes:
So, having had this conversation with—how many conversations did you have with Hawkins?
Mr Scanlon:
Two.
Mr Rozenes:
I take it that we are dealing with the first one . . .
Mr Scanlon:
We are.
Mr Rozenes:
You then contact Mr Jarrett who is overseas?
What does Jarrett say to you?
Mr Scanlon:
Jarrett says that he would be very keen to do that, but he was unable to follow up directly with Hawkins himself, and would I go back to him and try to tie it down.
Mr Rozenes:
You would say, would you, that the time when you spoke to Hawkins last, there was no concluded agreement between Elders IXL and Equiticorp?
Mr Scanlon:
I would say there was.
Mr Rozenes:
There was a concluded agreement?
Mr Scanlon:
Yes, well, I would have thought Jarrett had gave me conditions that would enter into that contract for and asked me to—
Mr Rozenes:
So you would say a deal was done?
Mr Scanlon:
Yes, I would.
Scanlon did the deal.

I would now like to turn very briefly to Ken Jarrett's evidence of 1994. This is when Ken Jarrett had decided he was sick of telling lies about what had been going on at Elders IXL and Fosters. He wanted, finally, to tell the truth and he gave evidence to the NCA about the true nature of these transactions.
Paragraph 12 says:

In about June 1984 EXL, through a subsidiary Elders N.V., made an issue in Europe of convertible bonds having a face value of U.S.$160 million. The motivation for the issue was partly a need for EXL to raise capital and partly to enable executives of the company to take up financial interests in the company in a manner which could be self‐funded. I believe the scheme to finance executive participation was proposed initially by Bankers Trust. It was attractive to the intended beneficiaries in that it was expected that the bonds would increase in value as EXL prospered and it would enable them to maintain some control over the company.
Paragraph 13 says:

I became involved in discussions relating to the proposal initially with WIESENER and ELLIOTT. By the time that issue was made ELLIOTT, SCANLON, WIESENER, Cowper and Lord were, to my knowledge, aware of the executive participation.

This was the so‐called Swiss bonds issue for which John Elliott put his hand on his heart and said, `I know nothing about it.' Ken Jarrett was the man who organised it for him. He was his right‐hand man inside Fosters, and he has gone on oath and said, `I organised it. John Elliott was in it.'
Paragraph 16 says:

On 10 and 11 April 1986 EXL through a subsidiary, purchased approximately 18.56% of the issued share capital of BHP. On the same dates BHP purchased the U.S.$105 million parcel of Elders N.V. convertible bonds at a price which represented a profit to the beneficial owners of the bonds totalling tens of millions of dollars. By my own calculations the total profit amounted to about A$78 million.

This is $78 million profit on bonds that they owned, not, as they try to pretend now, that they knew nothing about. Ken Jarrett was a beneficiary of the bonds. He put up his hand and said, `I am in part ownership of these bonds with Elliott, Scanlon and others.'
Paragraph 21 says:

During that same period I was generally aware that between 21 and 26 May 1986 a company associated with . . . HAWKINS . . . and . . . PRATT . . . (which I now know to be Beid Pty. Ltd.) purchased approximately 4.4% of the issued share capital in BHP. As a result, the NCSC declared to be unacceptable the share acquisitions and the conduct of HAWKINS and PRATT in relation thereto.
Paragraph 27 says:

During the first half of 1987 SCANLON came to see me and said that EXL owed HAWKINS money as part of an arrangement with HAWKINS in relation to the BHP shares. I took this to be a reference to the BHP shares purchased by Beid Pty. Ltd. in May 1986. SCANLON told me that it was necessary to pay it in a way that was not disclosed. I think he mentioned a figure in the order of $30 million. Certainly, whatever amount was mentioned at that stage was a lot less than was ultimately paid. The purpose of this approach to me was to ask me how the payment could be made covertly.
Paragraph 29 says:

I had a number of further conversations during 1987 with SCANLON on the question of how the payment to HAWKINS could be disguised. At one stage he asked me whether company to company hedges might be used as the method of concealing the payment.
There are pages and pages more which time does not allow me to read into Hansard .

What happened on Friday in the Victorian Supreme Court of Appeal is very important to this case. The decision is conclusive that the basis for the acquittal of Elliott, Scanlon, Biggins and others was fundamentally flawed. Mr Justice Brooking said on page 12 of his judgment that in deciding whether the NCA had exceeded its reference, Mr Justice Vincent needed only to have looked at the wording of the reference itself, and no‐one disputes that the reference itself was sufficient to deal with the H fee transaction.

Mr Justice Brooking concluded on page 22 of his judgment that the course of action taken by Mr Justice Vincent in looking behind the wording of the reference to the events that preceded it and taking into account what was in the mind of the officers of the NCA when they approached the minister for a reference in the Elliott case was completely inappropriate on the part of Mr Justice Vincent. Mr Justice Brooking was supported in his view by Mr Justice Winneke and Mr Justice Tadgell.

The course of action taken by Mr Justice Vincent has no precedence to support it and has produced the wrong outcome. As a consequence of reaching the totally incorrect conclusion that the reference was inadequate, Mr Justice Vincent compounded his mistake by then ruling all the NCA evidence, which I have just been reading from, inadmissible. This was incorrect. Mr Justice Vincent then proceeded to declare that, because the evidence was inadmissible, there was no case to answer and therefore the accused should be acquitted. This was also incorrect.

Mr Justice Brooking has also made it clear that it is not appropriate in this case for the judge to determine the outcome of a trial before a matter has been put to the jury. The Brooking decision establishes that the basis of the Elliott acquittal was fundamentally flawed and that there was absolutely no basis for Mr Justice Vincent to acquit Elliott, Scanlon and Biggins.

After the acquittal in 1996, many derogatory statements have been made in the media by Elliott and Scanlon about the competence of the NCA to prepare a case, lay charges and present the case to court. John Elliott, Peter Scanlon, Ken Biggins and Ken Jarrett lied under oath in their evidence before the NCA. Elliott and Scanlon lied in their evidence before the NCSC. Elliott and Scanlon lied in their evidence before the joint committee overseeing the National Crime Authority. Elliott and Scanlon lied at their press conference after the 1996 Vincent decision.

Elliott and Scanlon have always lied in regard to their knowledge of the beneficial owners of the Elders convertible bonds. Elliott and Scanlon have always lied in relation to VicInvest. Elliott and Scanlon have yet to utter one word of truth on any of these transactions. If I worked at the NCA I would be begging John Elliott to bring on his claim: `For $200 million come and sue us.' I would beg him to do it. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators would be aware that yesterday the government introduced a package of proposed legislation to deal with unfair treatment of small business. What I wish to address today is a case study of how badly small business can be dealt with by big companies in this country—a case study which demands the urgent attention of every person in this Senate so that they can understand how the large oil companies have manipulated the system, abused the law and abused so‐called voluntary codes of practice to their own advantage.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sorry case which saw a small family company driven into the ground at the manipulation of one of our large oil companies, in this case Mobil. Mobil is a supplier of fuel products to Cairns international airport on behalf of all of the fuel companies in Australia. It has an arrangement whereby they all use one company to deliver products in their own name to the airport. Mobil in turn used a distributor at Cairns airport which was a company called Air Vision.

Air Vision was basically owned by the Boundy family, and they had had this business for many years. They were a long‐term distributor at that airport. They have always, in so far as I understand the situation, acted in a thorough and acceptable manner. In fact, so acceptable has been the service of Air Vision that a couple of years ago Mobil suggested to the principals of Air Vision that they increase their working capital by borrowing money from the banks, seeking advances from banks, for the purposes of Air Vision taking over the distribution of fuel products not just in Cairns, where they already were, but at Kingsford Smith Airport in Sydney.

It may be imagined how attractive a proposition this was for Air Vision. Accordingly, following the suggestion made to them by Mobil, they did go to the bank, they did increase their working capital, they purchased a property in Sydney from which their executives could work and they made other investments in terms of computer technologies and so on, in the belief that they were going to continue operations in Cairns and, further, that they were going to take over the distribution of fuel products at Sydney airport.

What happened, however, was that there was a change of heart in Mobil. Mobil decided that not only were they not going to allow Air Vision to become the distributor at Sydney international airport, but, moreover, that they were going to do this job themselves in Cairns. Therefore, Mobil decided to terminate its agreement with Air Vision for the distribution of fuel products at Cairns airport.

At this point, obviously, this company no longer had any business at all and, through APADA—the Australian Petroleum Agents and Distributors Association—they sought to have the matter dealt with under Oilcode. That is what they did. Unfortunately, Mobil did not want to play by the rules. Not only did Mobil not want to play by the rules; they also decided that they did not want to pay the outstanding invoices that were due to Air Vision—invoices in the amount of $300,000. The matter went to a conciliator, Mr David Newton. As a result, an offer was made by Mobil. But it was a `take it or leave it' offer in the amount of $450,000.

Air Vision and the Boundys claimed a substantially higher amount. The turnover at that airport would justify a substantially higher amount; their previous profit figures would justify a substantially higher amount; and fairness, given that this company has been there for decades, would require a substantially higher amount. Mobil said, `$450,000—take it or leave it.' At that point, Air Vision said, `Hold on. There is further information which has not been considered by the conciliator,' and they put further information, further evidence, before the conciliator. At that point, Mobil refused to cooperate with the conciliator and withdrew this case from Oilcode.

BREAK.PARA: So concerned was the conciliator that he has written a letter to Mobil Oil Australia Ltd. I shall read the letter to the Senate. It is addressed to Mr Symington and Mr Stevens, and it says:
Dear Garth and Craig,
Re Mobil and Air Vision—Cairns Airport—Conciliation under Oilcode Principles
I refer to Craig's letter of 10 September 1997 terminating the conciliation of the above matter.

I share the disappointment that a resolution of this matter has not occurred through conciliation. It is the first conciliation in 7 years out of approximately 35 cases under the Oilcode procedures that has not resulted in agreement between the parties.

It is especially disappointing that Mobil has terminated this conciliation and by doing so failed to comply with my directions to provide further information so that I can form a view as to a fair and reasonable outcome of this dispute in accord with Oilcode principles.

If that information had been provided then depending on the content of that information I might have formed the view that a higher payment than my suspended recommendation and Mobil's offer of $450,000 may have been a fair and reasonable settlement. Mobil's termination could reasonably be seen as an attempt to prevent such a possibility.

I am also very concerned about the fact that Mobil has not as far as I am aware adequately responded to Air Vision in respect of unpaid invoice claims of approximately $300,000 which in my view is an additional item to matters covered by the $450,000 as I stated in my suspended recommendation.
In my view Mobil has not complied with clauses 4 and 5 of the Conciliator Appointment Agreement.
I am very concerned to protect and advance the integrity of the Oilcode process and my comments are directed to that end.
Yours sincerely
David Newton
Conciliator
I seek leave to have that letter tabled in the parliament so that all can see it.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. In the final moments available to me, let me make the point that Mobil here has clearly breached the Oilcode principles, it has clearly attempted to frustrate the conciliator, and this is the way the oil companies conduct themselves in this country.

BREAK.PARA: It is important that the government's proposed reforms get passed. But it is also important, dreadfully important, that Mobil be brought to book for the way in which they have destroyed this small business—a family business. I intend to continue to pursue this matter. I would hope that if Mobil are sensible, if they do not want their dirty linen aired, as it ought to be, they will at least start to become reasonable and start to make a reasonable attempt to comply with the Oilcode principles before further action has to be taken in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before commencing question time, I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of Mr Kantibhai Patel, a member of parliament from Harare, Zimbabwe. I trust that your visit to this country will be enjoyable and informative.
—Hear, hear!

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mackay, Sen Sue

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Minister, has your attention been drawn to the comments made by the Prime Minister when announcing the government's backflip on TCF tariffs? He said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . this is a very good decision for the battlers of Australia. It is a decision which is designed to give people a greater sense of job security.
Why then did you tell a CEDA private dinner that, in order to reduce unemployment:
. . . you have to have
[as] it might be described . . .
lessened job security. It's not a message everyone wants to hear?
If that is not a message everyone wants to hear, why did you then endeavour to ensure that no‐one heard it, by insisting that this message was not to be passed on to the media?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for her question. Yes, I am aware of the Prime Minister's remarks, and I agree with them. The remarks made at the CEDA conference, as I think you well know, have been taken out of context, misunderstood and misreported. For confirmation of that, I think you can lead to this point—that it was not me that asked that the matters raised at the CEDA dinner be Chatham‐house rules. That, I understand, is CEDA's practice. They invite someone to dinner and they say, `We have Chatham‐house rules dinners.' In fact, they contacted my office and asked if we had an objection to a journalist being there. I said I had no objection whatsoever to a journalist being there. It is between CEDA and the journalist whether the journalist has broken the requirement that CEDA places on them.

ANSWER.PARA: Coming to the specific matters, I am very pleased that I have a complete tape of the relevant speech. If, Senator, you are interested in employment strategies, can I refer you to the OECD job strategy. Can I ask you to go through the 10 or so issues listed by the OECD as being appropriate for maximising employment opportunities and employment growth. They are things like getting appropriate macroeconomic settings right, having an efficient education and training system, maximising the generation of new technology and the dissemination of it and having a freer industrial relations system. One of them relates quite specifically to the question of unfair dismissals.

I am surprised you asked this question because it leads me to the opportunity of reminding you of one of the impediments to increasing employment in Australia that was there—your old unfair dismissal law. You do not seem to understand the consequences of your very unfair unfair dismissal law.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it's your unfair dismissal law.

—Senator, you asked me the question, so I am entitled to answer it—and I am answering it. You know, or you should know, that small business, when it believes that it is going to be very expensive to change a person who has proved unsatisfactory for one reason or another and to select another person, does not take a new person on if there is a high cost to that—and there was a significantly high cost under Labor's unfair unfair dismissal law. What you do in that situation is simply employ casuals because you will not take the chance that you might make a bad choice. If you cannot swap someone over and take a new person on who you hope more appropriately fits the requirements of your small business and if it is going to cost you too much money, you will not do it.

ANSWER.PARA: When there is a very unfair unfair dismissal law, such as the one you supported, people feel particularly secure in their jobs, whether they are performing properly or not. A job becomes almost a tenure. And the point that is being made with respect to this particular OECD aspect of the job strategy is that you cannot have a tight industrial relations system with a very tight unfair dismissal law which will inhibit business from changing people over. That is, if you are good at the job, you get to keep it and you are secure in your job; if you are not good at your job, then you should be insecure in it. That was the point that was made in the CEDA speech.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I have a supplementary question. Minister, if you claim that you were quoted out of context, misunderstood and misreported, can you confirm that you said at the CEDA dinner that you have to have, as might be described, `lessened job security. It is not a message that everyone wants to hear.' Did you say that.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, you tempt me to give you a tape of the whole speech.
—That would be all right.
—I know you would be grateful for that, but I am not going to give in to that temptation. No, today I do not feel like giving in to that temptation.

ANSWER.PARA: That remark, put in context, will give you the answer that I have just given you. If you are asking me whether those words were uttered, I have never denied that. Those words were uttered. If you are asking me whether they give a true and proper reflection of the whole answer to the question, in context of the speech given, the answer to that is that they most definitely do not.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the United Kingdom, led by the Deputy Speaker of the House of Commons, Mr Michael Lord, MP.

INTERJECT.PARA: On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate and trust that your visit to this country will be both informative and enjoyable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—My question is to Senator Alston, the minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. I note that in my home state of Queensland the government's comprehensive small business reforms—announced yesterday—were very warmly received by the retail traders and also the motor vehicle traders. Could you advise the Senate of the reaction of the broader Australian small business community to those long awaited reforms, which the Labor party and the Labor government could not deliver, even after overseeing 17 small business reviews and reports?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Boswell and I can assure him that the reaction in the other states has been equally as euphoric as that in Queensland. In fact, it might be a slight misrepresentation of the situation to say that this mob had 17 reviews in 13 years; the fact is that they had 18 and the 18th was no better than the ones that went before it because all they did was, once again, promise to have another good think about it. What they said, in a release from the current Leader of the Opposition, was:

ANSWER.PARA: We are beginning our program to reshape our election policy with an overhaul of our small business commitment.

In other words, they are basically saying, `We have got it wrong so far. We have delivered nothing so we are going to have another look at what else we might be able to offer them.' That is where they stand.
The endorsements that have come in from third parties have really been quite over whelming. The Pharmacy Guild says, `Government keeps faith with small business.' It goes on:
This can only lead to the growth of the small business sector and an increase in employment for young Australians.

The Service Station Association said it was the most comprehensive small business package in history and that thousands of service stations would be saved from closure and their employees saved from unemployment. The Australian Retailers Association said it provided a firm basis for fair tenancy laws. The Australian Business Chamber said it would address most of the areas of breakdown between big and small business. The Council of Small Business Organisations of Australia said the government has demonstrably committed itself to the small end of town. ASBA said the small business community could hardly have hoped for more and, `He has earned our confidence.' The Democrats have given it the thumbs up. The Motor Trades Association said Australia will be a better place to do business as a result of these measures.
But perhaps the most glowing endorsement of all came from Stephen Martin. We are particularly grateful to him because he happens to be the federal minister for small business and customs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shadow minister!

—Shadow minister; I agree, an absolute pipedream, my apologies. What Mr Martin had to say was that he gave a qualified welcome to the Howard government's fair trading inquiry report. Then he is quoted in the paper as congratulating Mr Reith on being able to achieve, through his cabinet, `far more than we anticipated'. In other words, he is basically saying, `We could not have done anything like that. We are amazed at how far you have gone and how successful you have been.'

ANSWER.PARA: That represents the low watermark of policy bankruptcy in this country; to find an opposition that has had 13 years in government and now 18 months in opposition still wallowing around talking about reviews, having a bit of a think, trying to play catch‐up politics and suggesting that somehow they forced us into these initiatives. The reality is that they are not interested in policy. We know what they are interested in: they are interested in every conceivable distraction. Some people, like Senator Sherry, might have other interests in mind but most of them over there are not interested in policy at all.

Time is running out, let me tell you. You are not going to get anywhere at the next election if you think that you can somehow drift in there with a leader who has no idea what he stands for, who clearly does not feel confident in the role, who has the young turks absolutely flouting his authority and big‐noting themselves on every possible occasion and who has Simon Crean simply ignoring him, pointing the finger at him whenever he gets a chance and blaming him in every respect for keeping the records of the Labor Party and not disclosing them. In other words, it is absolute chaos on the other side both in terms of management and in terms of policy.

Yesterday's announcement will be seen by the small business community for what it is. This is game, set and match. This is a very one‐sided contest because the other side simply has not turned up on the field and we have delivered the goods. We have recognised small business as a core constituency; it is a great shame that Labor does not appreciate the benefits that are there. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Can the minister confirm that the unemployment figure is stagnant at 8.7 per cent; the long‐term unemployment trend figure is 247,700 for August 1997, which is a 23‐month high, up by 32,000 since May 1996; 37,500 full‐time jobs have been lost in one month alone; and 60,000 full‐time jobs have been lost since the Howard government's August 1996 budget? Does the minister think this pathetic record—and I use the minister's words—constitutes a `big tick for effort'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for the question. I can confirm, as any Aus tralian would be able to confirm for you, that the labour market remains flat. I can confirm for you the various levels of unemployment; I do not have the long‐term unemployed figures with me. You ask: does that in itself merit a big tick? You are obviously in the habit of misunderstanding what has been said. I was asked a question quite specifically at the National Press Club last week or the week before and I clearly indicated that the government is not satisfied with the level of employment and unemployment, and the government is very concerned and determined to ensure that the level of unemployment comes down.

ANSWER.PARA: What I did say is that the electorate, which is completely understandably impatient and fed up with long‐term unemployment, is looking for change, is looking for improve ment and will be looking very seriously at what any government did and, in our case, has done to remedy the problem that we faced coming into government. They will give us, in my view, a big tick for the enormous effort we have put into repairing the mess that you left behind. Just in case you have forgotten the mess that you left behind—we had 13 years of your government, Senator; you were not here for all of them—you had an average unemployment rate of about 8.5 for 13 years. And after 18 months you think you have some credibility, a shred of it, left to come in here and ask this government what it is doing about unemployment when you created the problem. You had 11.2 per cent as an unemployment rate, which was the highest since the Depression. That is what you achieved. Do you think that gives you any credibility whatsoever to come in here and ask us about what we are doing?

Let me just explain to you a number of the things we have done. We have put the budget back into the black. If you do not understand the value of that, I do not think that in the few minutes available to me I can possibly give you enough lessons to clue you in. But you must understand the benefit that is to the economy and the opportunity it creates in terms of the lower interest rates that come for the business sector to in fact bloom and generate more real jobs. You must understand that.

BREAK.PARA: We have put an enormous effort into freeing up the industrial relations system. You probably do not agree with what we have done. I am sure you don't, because you liked a nice, tight system that kept you with 8.5 per cent unemployment for 13 years, and you were happy with that. We are not happy with that, and that is why we changed the industrial relations system. We have made a number of significant changes in relation to small business. Small business is where the jobs are in fact going to come from. We made a number of significant changes in that respect.

It is true that it is not always easy—in fact it is not possible—for a government to simply turn on a switch and generate more real jobs. Government does not generate real jobs; government creates the environment for business to prosper. It takes time for the confidence to come back. After the devastating effect that the recession we had to have, that your Prime Minister said we had to have, had on jobs, on long‐term unemployed, on young Australians and on business confidence, it is no surprise that people are still apprehensive about whether—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the minister concede that her own policies have contributed to the crisis by strangling community confidence and that she has mishandled the jobs crisis?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, what you do not understand is that, if we were not elected to government, do you know what you would have done when you came in? You would have covered your eyes, put your head in the sand and hoped, as you have for the last 13 years, that everything would get better. In fact, it would not have. Things would be much, much worse now if we were not elected to government, if we had not made the hard decisions we have made, which are important decisions and which Australia will reap the benefit of.

ANSWER.PARA: You can sit over there while we are waiting for the change to come through and you can cross your fingers and hope it does not come, but let me assure you of this: we have made the appropriate changes. The economic growth and the employment growth will come, and you will be smiling on the other side of your face when it does.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer and Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer to Senator Sherry's incredible attempt to explain himself in the Senate a short while ago in relation to claims in excess of $40,000 for capital city stays in Hobart. Is the senator entitled to claim city rates of travelling allowance when staying at his mother's country home 50 kilometres from Hobart, as claimed by Senator Sherry?
—Thank you to Senator Calvert for what can only be described as a fairly topical question that has arisen in the last day or so.
—Why did they give it to a dope like you to answer?
—Order, Senator!
—We all listened with great interest—
—Order, Senator!
—The Elmer Fudd of the Liberal Party.
—Order! Senator Kemp!
—Very sensitive, Senator Faulkner.
—Order, Senator Kemp! I have called you to order, Senator Kemp!
—Thank you, Madam President, but—
—Senator Kemp, resume your seat! I have called you four times to resume your seat while I ask Senator Faulkner to cease interjecting as he is doing at the present time.

—Thank you, Madam President. As I was saying, it has become a very topical issue, and I think a number of people would have listened with considerable interest to Senator Sherry's efforts at lunchtime to extricate himself from the mess that he has got himself into and indeed the Labor Party into.
—Is this the best you can do? What a miserable performance.
—Order on my left!
—Order!
—The issue goes wider than Senator Sherry.
—Is this the big fightback? Is this the big throw‐back?

—It goes to the standards of Mr Kim Beazley, the Labor Party leader. So it is an issue which involves not only Senator Sherry but Mr Kim Beazley and what sorts of standards he wishes to apply to the Labor Party. Because of this topical interest, I have sought advice from the acting Minister for Administrative Services on this matter.
—Either put up or shut up.

—I can inform you, Senator Calvert, that the Remuneration Tribunal has determined that senators and members are entitled to a capital city rate of travelling allowance when staying overnight in a capital city.
—A devastating attack from Elmer Fudd! Is this the fightback?
—Order! There are far too many interjections on my left. It is totally disorderly.
—Come on! Put up or shut up!
—Order, Senator Kemp!
—There are far too many interjections and they are totally disorderly!
—I can understand why the Labor Party does not wish to hear this, but they will be hearing a lot on this issue, let me tell you.

BREAK.PARA: In making his claims for travelling allowance, Senator Sherry has consistently specified Hobart in relation to Tasmania. The Remuneration Tribunal does not define a capital city. In processing claims for payment of travelling allowance, the Department of Administrative Services accepts the claimant's advice that it is a capital city. That is the advice from the acting Minister for Administrative Services. He concludes—and this is important for Labor Party standards; just tune in:
Senator Sherry in his travelling claims specified Hobart, not Opossum Bay—
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Kemp, resume your seat!
—A point of order!
—Order! Senator Kemp, when I ask you to resume your seat, you should do so.

—Madam President, on a point of order, it might be embarrassing to the Labor Party, but other senators are entitled to hear the answer. The Labor Party is deliberately shouting down Senator Kemp, out of embarrassment, presumably. If they were not embarrassed about it, they would be quiet and listen to the answer.

—On the point of order, I point out to you, Madam President,—even though you have called me, unfairly in my view, and a number of other opposition senators to order—the cacophony of noise coming from the government side during question time today. So, Madam President, I just ask you to be even‐handed as you apply the standing orders.
—The level of noise in the chamber is far too high and will not be tolerated. I call Senator Kemp.
—Elmer Fudd; here we go.
—Senator Carr, I have just commented on the noise in the chamber and would ask you to remain silent.
—You are defending frauds. They are defrauding the Commonwealth.
—Senator Conroy, you are defying the ruling that I have just made.

—I can understand the sensitivity on that side of the chamber. So the issue boils down to this, and it is a classic issue of standards: it is up to Senator Sherry to decide whether it is appropriate for him to stay over 40 kilometres out of Hobart at Opossum Bay with his mother in his mother's home while claiming he is in Hobart at $300 a night. And, of course, in addition to the $300 a night there is the cost of the Comcar to Opossum Bay and back again. So what we now have is a whole host of unanswered questions. The first question is: what are the standards of the Labor Party? Is it appropriate for Senator Sherry to claim for Hobart when he is staying at Opossum Bay? That is the first question.

BREAK.PARA: The second question is: how many nights did Senator Sherry, while claiming for Hobart, stay at Opossum Bay? That was one of the very big gaps in the quarter of an hour, I have to say, that we heard from Senator Sherry at lunchtime today. What we do know—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Murphy.
—Thank you, Madam President—
—I rise on a point of order.
—Too slow, Calvert!
—Order! I had called Senator Murphy before you stood, Senator.
—I ask that the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate withdraw that comment.
—I did not hear what he said.
—I did. It was unparliamentary, Madam President.
—I did not hear. If Senator Faulkner has made an unparliamentary remark, he should withdraw it.
—I would not make an unparliamentary comment, but if I did I would certainly withdraw it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Minister, I refer you to the latest unemployment figures, which were cited by my colleague Senator West in her earlier question to you. Is it a fact that you have now conceded that your budgetary policies have contributed to the perpetuation of this crisis and that it is, in part, due to your government's expenditure cuts? Is it also a fact that the Treasury conceded in the 1996 budget papers that your labour market deregulation would do little to alleviate unemployment?
—Order! Would those senators who are using their headphones turn the volume down on them so that the proceedings in this chamber may be heard?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I thank you for the question and I simply repeat in part what I have said to Senator West, who appears to have gone to sleep—never mind, she will come back to this world—on unemployment issues. She's back now; welcome back, Senator. Senator, what you need to understand is you have got no credibility whatsoever in talking to the Australian people about unemployment. Perhaps you do not understand why you were not re‐elected. Perhaps that penny has not dropped—13 years with unemployment at an average of 8.5 per cent or 8.7 per cent. It was stuck at 8.5 or 8.7. You were spectacularly unsuccessful.
—Order! There is too much noise in the chamber outside the area in which senators are sitting. Would those wishing to have conversations please leave.

—While you were so spectacularly unsuccessful at fixing the unemployment problem, you were spectacularly successful at running up debt and putting this government into debt. That is what you were successful at doing—making the problem worse, making future generations pay for your incapacity to be fiscally responsible. That was your attitude: `Oh, we're in government so we'll spend, spend, spend. When we get kicked out, someone else will have to fix the problem—we'll leave it to them. Let's do everything we can to maximise our opportunities to stay in. Let's walk away from the difficult decisions. In doing so, let's walk away from the semi‐skilled, from the low‐skilled and from the unemployed.' That is what you did when you walked away from making the tough decisions. We have got a clear and coherent strategy—
—Higher unemployment under you.
—for fixing up the mess we were elected to fix up—the mess that you left behind. What are you talking for? You were in the cabinet that created this problem.
—That is right and we had lower unemployment than you.
—You were into spend, spend, spend.
—Where are the jobs?

—Senators, let me help you through this. The policy goes this way: we need a balanced budget. We are looking to low interest rates. We have got low inflation. We have shifted to a flexible workplace relations system—much more flexible than you ever had or would dream of introducing. We have got assistance that will be tailored individually to assist unemployed people. We have reduced red tape for small business. We have reinvigorated the apprenticeships and traineeships. We are creating pathways from schools to employment and, importantly, we are focusing on literacy and numeracy in our schools.
—Where are the jobs?
—Has the drought broken yet? Is the rain coming?
—Why have you cut funding?

—If that is not enough for you, I will table and seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a summary of the OECD jobs strategy, which I referred to earlier. I will take the opportunity to point out strategy No. 5 and strategy No. 6. Senator Mackay, for your benefit, No. 5 says:

ANSWER.PARA: Make wage and labour costs more flexible to reflect local conditions and individual skills.
We have done that. We have worked along those lines. And No. 6 says:
Reform employment security provisions.

For those of you who do not understand what that means, I will spell it out for you again. That refers to unfair dismissal legislation, which we have also fixed and which, in the speech, I also said was fixed. So for the good senator's benefit, I seek leave to table and incorporate in Hansard a summary of the OECD jobs strategy, and on each measure this government gets a much bigger tick than the previous government ever did.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
The OECD Jobs Strategy
1. Sound macro economic policy:
sustainable, non‐inflationary growth.
2. Enhance the creation and diffusion of technological know how.
3. Increase flexibility of working time through voluntary agreement of workers and employers.
4. Facilitate creation and expansion of enterprises.
5. Make wage and labour costs more flexible to reflect local conditions and individual skills.
6. Reform employment security provisions.
7. Strengthen active labour market policies:
improve their effectiveness.
8. Raise skill levels by reforming education and training.
9. Reform unemployment and related benefit systems and their interactions with the tax system:
improve work incentives
achieve fundamental equity goals.
10. Enhance product market competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, talking about walking away from things, do you intend to stand by your comments made on the 7.30 Report last year that if the government could not substantially reduce unemployment by the time of the next election you would not deserve to be re‐elected?

—Senator, if I thought that you did not keep up with things I would have personally sent you an invitation to the National Press Club the week before last and you would have had the opportunity to have this matter cleared up as well. What I said there—
—We heard your answer before; it was pathetic.
—What I said there was that in the normal term of a government you would, of course, expect an improvement. I do not know when the next election is going to be. I went on to say—
—That is what you said at the press club.

—What if the election was in three months—a sudden double dissolution? Would you expect it to be fixed then? I went on to say that the electorate is understandably impatient because they got fed up with you lot telling them you were pulling the right levers—you were pulling something, but not the right levers—champagne bubbling over, everything was okay; and you never fixed the problem and they are fed up with it. Understandably! They will look to see what we have done and they will judge us very carefully. They will see that we have been a government that has made the hard decisions that you gutless people were never ever prepared to make.

—My question is to the minister representing the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training. Minister, everyone in Australia knows that Dr Kemp says that 30 per cent of students are not capable of reading or writing.
