Leaving aside for the moment the highly suspect modelling he used to make these wild claims, is the government aware that in the US and Canada it is estimated that more than 10 per cent of students are affected by specific learning disabilities such as dyslexia and dysnomia? Minister, what research has your government undertaken to determine the number of Australian students who have diagnosable learning disabilities and how many children in Australia are affected by attention deficit disorder and other disadvantages which cause learning difficulties?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, it will not be a surprise to you to know that I simply cannot give you that information off pat. I certainly do not ever intend to try to carry around in my head those sorts of figures. You come back to the same point every time, don't you, Senator? You never want any criticism of things as they are. You would like a plastic bubble put over schooling and education. All you ever want for it is more money. That is all you ever want. You never want to look at improvements in outcomes because that might mean something has to change. It might mean something you do not agree with. You are the sort of person who is afraid of change. I feel sorry for you in that respect because change is a part of life and you are going to have to live with it.

ANSWER.PARA: You come back to the literacy aspect, Senator. I repeat what I said to you the other day: irrespective of what benchmarks you might wish to choose—and we could argue about the benchmarks; there are different views about what are the appropriate benchmarks—I think I caught you nodding the other day when I said: nobody that I know, and I would hope no senator or member, would suggest that we should sit back and be happy with the literacy and numeracy levels that there are in Australia.

Do you think we should sit back and be happy with the levels as they are? Well, Senator, do you? You have got the chance tell the nation. What do you think? Do you think we should be happy with the literacy and numeracy levels as they are? You think they are a laughing matter, do you? You think it is a laughing matter that we have got kids who leave school not being able to read and write properly? Is that what you really think?

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Madam President. I draw your attention to the fact that Senator Vanstone appears to be having a personal conversation with Senator Allison.
—Unlike you.

—Well, I was not having a personal conversation with Senator Allison. I am certainly very particular whom I have personal conversations with, and I wouldn't have one with you. I point out to you, Madam President, clearly, as you know, Senator Vanstone is breaching the standing orders. You have referred to the standing orders on one or two occasions in this question time. I draw that to your attention and ask you to ask her to address her comments through the chair.
—Your remarks should be addressed to the chair, Senator.
—Thank you very much, Madam President. I do apologise for not directing my remarks through you.
—That is all right. Apology accepted, Mandy.

—I certainly do hope, Madam President, that you take every opportunity to insist that people, when they ask questions and want to interject, address their remarks through the chair—people such as Senator Faulkner.

ANSWER.PARA: The simple point is this. The senator raises the question of literacy. The senator clearly wants to get stuck into Dr Kemp. What she has to face up to is that the literacy and numeracy levels in Australia should be increased. If she does not agree with that, if she is happy with the levels as they are now, then she should come out and say so. She should come out and say to the parents of kids who do not make the appropriate grades, `You don't have to worry. This is an acceptable standard.'

If that is what the Democrats want to say, let them come out and say that. But this government unequivocally does not say that. What we say is that the literacy and numeracy levels must be improved. What Dr Kemp has said to the states is, `In order for you to be continually funded in relation to these matters you will have to come up with a plan to show us how you are going to improve the literacy and numeracy of Australian students.' I cannot believe that there is anybody in this place, or in the other house, who could possibly disagree with the government's intention in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Again, today, I did not ask a question about funding. I am certainly not afraid of change. Can I suggest that it is fairly clear that this government has no systematic way of identifying the size of the problem for children with specific learning disabilities or other learning difficulties. My supplementary question is this: If you could, would you care, and do you care, that, by blaming teachers and threatening to remove funds from government schools which do not comply with Dr Kemp's outmoded ideas, Dr Kemp is doing nothing to address the real problems that some children experience in our schools?

—I am almost lost for words that Senator Allison could possibly suggest that her position—which is: do not do anything that upsets anybody—of leaving literacy and numeracy levels as they are is a more caring position than this government's position. It is precisely because this government does care that we are determined to raise the levels of literacy and numeracy for Australian children. We will not be bullied out of that by any tactics the Democrats wish to use.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I believe I am being misrepresented by what the minister is saying. I did not make those remarks. I would ask you to direct the minister to answer my question rather than make comments about what I might have said.
—Keep the question in mind, Minister, as you are answering.

—Certainly, Madam President, I am very pleased to do so. In relation to the other part of Senator Allison's question, I did not say that the government had no information or did not care about getting the information. I simply said that I did not have that information at hand. I will happily get what information I can and give it to the senator.

—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, I refer to your publicly stated view on industrial relations reform and its impact on unemployment. At a CEDA dinner on 11 September you stated that Australia needed a `freer labour market'. Given that this call for a second wave of labour market reform was made in direct contradiction to the government's stated view that the Workplace Relations Act should be given time to work, do you believe that a second wave of reform is needed? If so, what do you believe it should be?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I refer you in part to the answer given to Senator Mackay. Let me take you through it quite slowly so that you understand. There are 10 key points in the OECD jobs strategy—two of which I just highlighted before for Senator Mackay. What I indicated to the assembled members of CEDA and guests was that the government puts a lot of store in the OECD jobs strategy. I clearly indicated to them that you cannot do just one of those aspects and not the others; you have to be working on all the fronts together. There is no simple magic solution.

ANSWER.PARA: Not you, Senator, because you were not here, but the previous government used to pretend that here was a statement—Creative Nation, Working Nation, Innovative Nation—and each of these things was going to solve the problem. They never did. That is why the electorate was completely fed up with being given promises, promises and no delivery.

With respect to labour market reform, I clearly indicated that that was a part of the OECD job strategy. What I was saying was that you need to act on all of these fronts; you need to have the basics right in relation to macro-economic settings; you need to generate more technological knowledge and disseminate it and so on down through not all of the points but including industrial relations. You do need to constantly work on a freer industrial relations system.

That does not mean that you say, `Therefore, we're going to do more today than we did yesterday.' Of course, you make some changes and you see what impact they have and then you work on them again. You do not change day by day by day by day. But one key aspect of the OECD job strategy is a freer industrial relations system. That is something you always have to keep your eye on. It is an integral part of a 10-point job strategy en dorsed by the OECD. That is one key aspect of it—a freer industrial relations system.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that you have already referred today to your well-known views on another aspect of your industrial relations agenda, unfair dismissals, I ask: are you aware that the implementation of the government's unfair dismissal provisions will deprive one-third of Australian workers of any protection whatsoever and will deliver to those one-third of Australian workers precisely what you want—that is, lessened job security? Is that what the government intends with its unfair dismissal laws?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —What the government wants is to have an industrial relations system that does not put disincentives there to take on new people. That is what you did. Not you yourself, Senator. You were not a part of the previous government that was such a disgrace and such a failure. No doubt, in about 13 or 20 years, when you lot get back, you will still be here and make a significant contribution. You will not be up the back there; you will be down the front replacing some of these has‐beens, undoubtedly.

ANSWER.PARA: At that point, you will understand that one way to discourage business to take people on is to make it very hard for them to swap someone over and get a new person. If someone is dismissed and another person is taken on, it does not affect the level of employment. But what you do by having these tight industrial relations systems is create disincentives for business to take people on. Your colleagues did that and we fixed it. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is on a loftier matter than some of those earlier on, and it goes to the Minister for the Environment and Minister representing the Prime Minister. Is the fact that cabinet is meeting in Launceston mean that next Tuesday is D-day for Tasmania's forests? Is the minister aware of the report entitled Tasmanian world heritage values data audit , which summarises the views of the national and international auth orities on the world heritage forests in Tasmania, and which was prepared in part by Commonwealth officers? If so, why is the Howard government moving to hand those same forests—such as, Beech Creek, the southern forests, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine—across to the woodchip industry in violation of the World Heritage Convention? Is it a fact that the government is proposing to hand tens of millions of dollars to the woodchip industry and Forestry Tasmania—
—Madam President, I raise a point of order.
—Senator Brown, it is not in order to display posters in the chamber.
—So much for lofty behaviour! (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —They are beautiful forests, and they are well presented in the poster, Senator Brown. Thank you for a copy. I also welcome the question because it is a long time since you have asked an environment question in this place. What we are seeking is an outcome that will provide for a comprehensive, adequate and representative reserve system in Tasmania together with resource security—in other words, a good jobs outcome together with a good conservation outcome. It is not easy to achieve, but we believe it can be achieved. That is why so much effort is being put in.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition—you referred to the audit, but there has been another study as well—the issues of world heritage have had further consideration, particularly relating to areas which might have world heritage values. That report has been taken into account as well in finalisation of the RFA. It is true that negotiations are well advanced. We hope we will be able to reach an agreement with Tasmania in the near future, which will achieve the objectives as I have just put them to you.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Will those areas identified as having world heritage value be protected? Secondly, is it true that tens of millions of dollars are already being earmarked for forests already protected, scraps such as roadside reserves and logging roads for the woodchip industry? I reiterate the first question: is this matter to be signed off at the cabinet meeting in Launceston on Tuesday, D-Day—`D' for destruction for Tasmania's forests?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —What I am anticipating—
—`D' is for deadhead, for you.
—I rise on a point of order, Madam President. I object to that nasty interjection from the Tasmanian senator opposite. He should know better. I ask him to withdraw it.
—I did not hear the interjection. If there was an unparliamentary expression used, it should be withdrawn.

—Madam President, I do confess that I said `"D" for deadhead, for you.' I addressed it to that side of the chamber. The only person to identify with the comment was Senator Brown. I think that speaks for itself, and I withdraw.

—Senator Brown will be aware that in relation to East Gippsland we were satisfied that world heritage values could be protected from within the reserved area. I am certainly approaching the Tasmanian challenge in the same light. In other words, these reports are seriously being taken into account and our obligations under the world heritage convention and legislation will be fully met.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to money, it is reasonable to assume that the Commonwealth is prepared to put in new money, despite the fact that money is scarce, towards preserving the conservation values of forests in Tasmania. We are doing so because we think a good conservation outcome in Tasmania is vitally important. We are also interested in a good jobs outcome. We believe that we can achieve a sustainable resource for industry consistent with good conservation outcomes. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Is it not true that the 1997 budget allocated $180 million over two years for the financing of a public employment placement enterprise, PEPE, and that you subsequently withdrew the legislation establishing the market into which the PEPE was to operate? In June this year departmental officers were unable to answer questions regarding the financing arrangement of the PEPE or the call on the Australian taxpayer from this venture. You, Minister, have made it very clear that the PEPE will not be guaranteed even a minimum share of the new employment services market. What guarantees does the parliament have that the $180 million will not go the same way as the $2.8 million ship of fools?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for his question. I just advise him and others that until we have a name for the corporatised CES, we are not referring to it as `pep'. It is actually referred to as the public employment placement enterprise and generally referred to by most people familiar with this subject as PEPE, pronounced `pepi'. I would have understood earlier what you were talking about had you used that pronunciation.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, you should have been at the estimates committee hearing this morning because you would have discovered just how sensitive the opposition is about its own performance under Working Nation in relation to labour market programs. Had you been there you would have started to get just a glimmer—just the tip of the iceberg—of the rotten wasted money in Working Nation which your government presided over. That would have given you a better idea of why we are shifting away.

I would think that, since you are interested in public administration, you would actually support our policies; I think you went away and paid to do a higher degree in that respect. From the party that does not believe in students being able to pay, you nonetheless did that. If you are interested in public administration, you would clearly look at the millions of dollars that were poured down the drain under Working Nation and you would say, `Why doesn't somebody develop a better system? Why doesn't somebody develop a system with more accountability than there is in Working Nation? Why doesn't somebody develop a system that delivers better outcomes to unemployed people? Why doesn't somebody develop a system that gives a choice of provider to unemployed people?' We would have been there saying, `We've done that, we've done that, we've done that.'
It was unwise of you to refer to the SPCL contract because, in fact, it is a Working Nation style contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, yes. Who are you kidding?
—Yes, it is. It is the sort of thing that people on your side of the chamber were in up to their necks. It would be very interesting—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The level of noise is far too high.

—I am very interested in the SPCL contract. I have indicated on every occasion it has been raised that I want to get to the bottom of what went wrong and the process issues. That is why I referred the matter to the Auditor-General, and we will get to the bottom of that matter.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator, if you understood Working Nation, you would understand that SPCL was a Working Nation style contract. That is what happened in Working Nation all the time. Someone put a submission in. Was the minister's office involved? We would like to know. Sometimes members with marginal seats might have been interested in having a working nation program flopped into their electorate. We would like to know a bit more about that as well.

You can be assured that the SPCL contract is a transition contract between Working Nation and the new and improved employment services market, which will have much stronger accountability, much closer financial checks and much better outcomes to unemployed Australians than you could ever dream of delivering.

I advise you, Senator, that it is not true to say that all the money under the SPCL contract was wasted. Even if the entire value of that contract was wasted, it pails into insignificance in relation to the sizes of some contracts, which we would like to discuss this afternoon, in comparison with SPCL. So we help you put it into perspective: it pails into insignificance when compared with the millions of dollars that your minister simply threw down the drain. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you have spent four minutes avoiding answering the central question that was asked, so I will ask it again in a different way. What guarantees does the parliament have to ensure value to taxpayers from this $180 million? Will the PEPE be accountable to the estimates committees, or, as indicated by the department, will information about the practices of the PEPE be treated as commercial-in-confidence?

—Senator, I am sorry; it is just very difficult to answer questions to someone who clearly does not understand the issue that they are asking about. You clearly do not understand. What I can tell you, Senator, is that the new employment services market will deliver a much, much better service to unemployed Australians than you ever did. The new PEPE—
—What about answering the questions.
—I know what you are on about—protecting the jobs of your union mates.
—Order! There are persistent breaches of the standing orders by a number of people, and it should cease.

—The PEPE will have to compete for work against private sector operators and community operators. This government, as I have said before, will always be more accountable to parliament than you ever, ever were.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and is a logical follow-on to the matters we have just been discussing. Will the minister explain how, in contrast to Labor's Working Nation, the new employment services arrangements provide transparency in government expenditure? Will the minister also explain how paying employment services providers on the basis of job outcomes rather than training or work experience will, one, get a better result for Australia's unemployed, who are the victims of Labor's economic mismanagement and, two, provide better value for money for Australia's taxpayers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Troeth for the question. She took a strong interest a long time ago in Working Nation and was one of the first to spot the flaws that were there, the process issues that were there and the capacity for slush funding by Labor in marginal seats. So it is quite appropriate that she asks this question.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I have already pointed out that there have been persistent and wilful breaches of the standing orders during question time today and it should cease.
—The answer to the senator's question is yes, yes and yes.
—Well, sit down.
—Order!
—She has answered it, Madam President.
—Order!

—The opposition members have shown an interest in the SPCL contract. As I have indicated to you, Madam President, I am determined to get to the bottom of the matter. That is why I referred the matter to the Auditor-General.

ANSWER.PARA: It was very interesting at the estimates committee this morning when government members sought to put this matter in perspective, to really look at the SPCL contract and see how it compared with projects under the previous government. After all, if they were so good, this is an appropriate comparison to make. It is an appropriate standard to judge the SPCL contract by. What happened then was that Labor simply went into panic mode. I do not think they understand that the SPCL contract was a Working Nation style contract. It had tighter guidelines than Working Nation, but clearly that was not enough.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to what appears to be a concerted campaign to drown Senator Vanstone's voice from being heard, at the same time—
—Order! Just a moment, Senator Newman. We will have silence while the point of order is enunciated.
—as clearly, fragrantly disregarding the number of times—
—Ha, ha! Fragrantly!
—There they go again.
—Order! I have already pointed out that there have been persistent breaches of the standing orders throughout question time.
—Even for you, Josie, that was a shocker.
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—Madam President, I think we have just seen another example of the Leader of the Opposition, together with his chorus line, using loud male, arrogant voices to drown women's voices in this chamber. I think it is intolerable that Senator Vanstone has been subjected to this noise throughout question time by an opposition that asks questions and has no interest whatsoever in the answers and, at the same time, disregards your rulings so flagrantly.
—I regard my rulings as having been ignored throughout question time today by senators on my left.
—Does she live in Tasmania?
—Order! Senator Collins!
—I didn't say anything.
—Senator Jacinta Collins.

—The contract had tighter guidelines than Working Nation, but that clearly was not enough. It was really a contract that is in the transition period be tween Working Nation and the new and much improved employment services market.

BREAK.PARA: What happened was that Senator Faulkner was absolutely determined this morning to ensure that the truth about his government's performance in Working Nation stayed covered up. That is what this morning was all about. It was a very ugly sight. None of you would have liked to have been there, for those of you who were not there. He went into a very ugly bullyboy mode—absolutely bullyboy mode. Very few people think it is admirable at an estimates committee—

TALK.START.PARA: —We are both ugly, Amanda.

—Senator Faulkner, I have spoken to you a number of times today about shouting while sitting at the table. It has been copied by a number of your senators behind, and I regard your behaviour as totally disorderly and in breach of my rulings.

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Let me say this to you: I find it quite offensive when one senator happens to be singled out when there is rowdiness on both sides of the chamber, including government senators, Madam President, which you consistently ignore in this chamber.

—Madam President, I point out to you that this unctuous, deceitful and disgraceful behaviour is what sets the pattern for the rest of the opposition. If he is elected leader, he is elected to set an example, and the example he is setting is of sitting back in his chair, showing complete and utter contempt for your position and encouraging and inciting his colleagues to drown out those who have been asked questions on this side. Madam President, you should not tolerate it, and I invite you to carefully consider whether standing order 203 ought not to be invoked in the very near future.

—Further to the point of order, Madam President: I think any member of the opposition would take great offence at any suggestion coming from someone like Senator Alston that we treat any ruling that you give with contempt. We do not. We respect the Chair, and we respect you as President. We certainly do not respect Senator Alston or his ilk, and never will.
—There is very little time left for Senator Vanstone to conclude the answer, if she has not already done so.

—Thank you, Madam President, I certainly have not. It was appalling to watch Senator Faulkner in bullyboy mode threatening a public servant. Before a public servant had even answered a question, Senator Faulkner was there saying, `And I remind you, you're at a parliamentary estimates committee.' He was trying to put the fear of God into their hearts. And then, even worse, Senator Carr came in with some of his union bullyboy tactics; he literally pushed Senator Tierney out of the chair and purported to take over. The sad thing is that Senator Faulkner and Senator Carr displayed today their complete lack of understanding of standing orders; they were not entitled to ask Senator Tierney to move out of the chair.

BREAK.PARA: Why did they do so? The answer is pretty simple. It is because Labor is desperate to cover up what went wrong under Working Nation. These are the things, if you are interested in SPCL—and there is quite a long list of them, Senator Troeth, if you get my drift—that Labor does not want to come out about Working Nation. We would like to know the answers. Were Working Nation projects in certain marginal seats? Wouldn't it be interesting to look at that issue? Were they tendered for, as they will be in the new system? Were they largely tendered for? No, is the answer.

What were the outcomes? Were they good outcomes? How would they compare with SPCL? They do not want to know the answer to that. Here is another very interesting one: what was the previous minister's involvement in Working Nation programs, this big slush fund to put money around? Did the previous minister's office have any involvement in Working Nation projects? Wouldn't we like to know the answer to that? With this list of questions, you can imagine why Senator Faulkner started to thump the table and say, `We don't want to let you talk about this.' (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I would have to acknowledge that, on a couple of occasions, you have drawn attention to interjections or whatever during question time. I understood that the purpose of question time was for government ministers to provide answers to questions, and particularly to provide information. It seems that every time government ministers rise to their feet to answer any question, whether it be from the opposition or the government, it consists simply of a tirade of abuse about members of the opposition or the former government. If government ministers are going to continue with that practice, one can only assume that people on this side of the chamber are really not going to take much notice. I ask you, Madam President, to ask ministers to answer the questions rather than simply, like Senator Vanstone has done all day today, stand up and attack and abuse members of the opposition.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: HILL

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I wish to speak on the point of order. What cheek from a frontbencher of a party that came in here today with the deliberate intention of shouting Senator Vanstone down. It must have been a very creative tactics committee meeting this morning—`What will we do? We'll ask every question of Senator Vanstone, and we'll shout down her answer.' Very smart! Imaginative! There is a touch of Senator Carr in it, I would suspect.

INTERJECT.PARA: All I can say is that it is disappointing that Senator Ray missed the tactics committee this morning, because he would have added a touch of leadership to that meeting, and you would have come in with something better than you opted for today. It is a disgraceful performance in this Senate when you deliberately determine that no answer will be heard. You have the cheek to ask the question but you deliberately determined that the answer will not be listened to. Then you get up at the end of question time and complain about it.

Madam President, you have been treated poorly today in this place. Again, Senator Faulkner has shown no leadership on this issue. He should respect the fact that you are entitled to have order in this place. You should not be taken to the line on every occasion. There is no point of order in what has just been put to you. Madam President, this question time should be brought to an end. I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, by a letter dated 30 September 1997, has raised with me a matter of privilege relating to the allegation that the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) sought to influence the Australian Law Reform Commission to dissuade the commission from presenting a submission to the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the usual practice, privilege matters relating to joint committees are raised in the house which administers the joint committee. The joint committee on native title is administered by the Senate.
Standing order 81 requires that I determine whether a notice of motion to refer a matter of privilege to the Privileges Committee should have precedence, having regard to the following criteria:

(a) the principle that the Senate's power to adjudge and deal with contempts should be used only where it is necessary to provide reasonable protection for the Senate and its committees and for senators against improper acts tending substantially to obstruct them in the performance of their functions, and should not be used in respect of matters which appear to be of a trivial nature or unworthy of the attention of the Senate; and
(b) the existence of any remedy other than that power for any act which may be held to be a contempt.
It is not my role at this stage to make any judgment as to the facts of the matter.

Since these provisions were adopted, Presidents have followed the principle that a matter should be given precedence if it is capable of being held by the Senate to satisfy criterion (a) and if there is no other readily available remedy.

Several cases alleging improper interference with witnesses have been given precedence by Presidents and referred to the Privileges Committee and reported on by that committee. In some cases, as a result of recommendations by the committee, persons have been found guilty of contempts of the Senate because of interference with witnesses. No penalties have been imposed because the persons have usually withdrawn offending actions against witnesses.

The past rulings of Presidents and reports of the Privileges Committee have made it clear that allegations that witnesses have been interfered with have always been regarded as meeting the criteria the President is required to consider and have always been taken extremely seriously by the Privileges Committee. In the present case, there are several elements which should be noted.

First, this is a case of a person who has been invited to give evidence before a committee but has not yet given evidence. The Privilege Resolutions of the Senate and the reports of the Privileges Committee make it clear that improper interference with a witness can occur before the witness has given evidence.

Secondly, the point has been made in public controversy about this matter that the Attorney‐General has a statutory power to direct the Australian Law Reform Commission as to the work it is to undertake. Improper interference with a witness, however, can be constituted by an act which a person is otherwise lawfully entitled to take. This has been made clear by the courts in relation to contempt of court and also by the Privileges Committee in relation to interference with Senate witnesses.

Thirdly, the point has also been made in public controversy that the Australian Law Reform Commission does not have a statutory function to give evidence to parliamentary committees. The question of whether a witness has been interfered with, however, does not depend on the nature of any evidence to be given or on the power or ability of a witness to give it. This principle also applies equally to legal proceedings and parliamentary proceedings.

BREAK.PARA: As the public controversy indicates, there is some dispute about the facts of this matter. Standing order 81 does not require any assessment of the facts. It is for the Senate to determine whether the matter should be referred to the Privileges Committee. If it is referred, it is then the task of the Privileges Committee to inquire into and to find the facts of the case. The President determines the question of precedence on the matter as submitted by the senator raising the matter.
I therefore determine that this matter may have precedence under standing order 81.
I table the letter from Senator Bolkus. Senator Bolkus may now give a notice of motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee of Privileges:

(1) Whether the Attorney‐General (Mr Daryl Williams), or any other person, sought, by force or threat, or by other improper means, to influence the Australian Law Reform Commission, and/or its President, Mr Alan Rose, in respect of evidence to be given, namely the making of a submission and/or the giving of evidence in person, to the Parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, and whether the Attorney‐General, or any other person, induced the commission, or its President, to refrain from giving that evidence.
(2) Whether any contempt was committed in respect of this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), to a question without notice asked by Senator Calvert today, relating to the travelling allowance claims of senators and members.

This goes to Senator Sherry's behaviour in relation to travel allowance. Let the facts be understood from the outset. Senator Sherry, for the last 20 months of the Keating government, was exceeded only by Kim Beazley and Senator Bolkus in claiming travel allowance. Between March 1993 and February 1997, he claimed travel allowance for 143 nights in Hobart, at a cost to taxpayers of $40,700. More than half of the nights for which travel allowance has been claimed in Hobart have been for Friday, Saturday or Sunday nights.

The facts are these: Senator Kemp was asked today whether or not there are rules that determine what constitutes capital cities. The answer was that the Remuneration Tribunal determines capital cities. It does not define capital cities and the Department of Administrative Services simply takes the advice of the claimant as to where that person was on the night in question.
What Senator Sherry has done here is very clearly understood by the taxpayers at large. He has pretended that he has been in Hobart when in fact he has been at Opossum Bay. He has not yet told us—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you been to Opossum Bay?

—I know that it happens to be 50 kilometres from Hobart and, if you were honest, you would not write down Melbourne if you had been staying in Geelong. You would write down Opossum Bay and you would then argue that it comes within the capital city definition and you would allow the department to make a judgment. You would not simply make a misleading statement which is clearly de signed to create the impression that you were staying in Hobart when you were not.

SPEECH.PARA: What is even more important is this—

TALK.START.PARA: —What about where I live in Melbourne?

—I could not care less where you live. The principle that is important here is why the taxpayer pays $300 a night. The taxpayer pays it because they take the view you are entitled to compensation because you would normally incur expenses for staying in a capital city.

SPEECH.PARA: If Senator Sherry is staying with his mother and incurring no expenses at all, what he is doing, colloquially speaking, is working the system. He is basically arranging to be in Hobart whenever he can, saying that he is there for business—not hard to manufacture one or two points—

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. It concerns the words that Senator Alston has just used—the accusation that Senator Sherry is working the system. The challenge was made yesterday in a question to the Assistant Treasurer, I think—I cannot remember the precise words—as to whether Senator Sherry had done anything unlawful. The question was directly asked of the government yesterday as to the lawfulness—
—What is the point of order?

—of Senator Sherry's claims, and it was not replied to. The point of order is that a senator, even if that senator is a minister in the government, is not allowed to malign another senator in this place.
—I do not interpret the words as having maligned somebody, Senator, but I will certainly be listening to make sure that does not occur.

—I am endeavouring to make it crystal clear that this is working the system. This is a sharp practice. It is possible to bring yourself within the guidelines by finding an excuse to be in Hobart on every conceivable occasion, making every effort to be there.

SPEECH.PARA: I say to you that the principle that Senator Ray espoused the other day was in fact to look at a pattern—and here you have a very significant and consistent pattern of staying in Hobart on a regular basis—and then ask, `What is going on here?' The principle underlying this is that the taxpayers ought to provide compensation for those who would normally incur expenses in staying in capital cities, which can be very expensive.

So what you would do is declare that you stayed in Hobart if you stayed in Hobart. If you stayed in Opossum Bay, 50 kilometres away, in a sleepy rural hollow up a dusty track, you would say: `I stayed at Opossum Bay but I argue that somehow I am entitled to a capital city claim.' It undermines the whole principle of the travel allowance arrangements if you are entitled on a very regular basis to not pay any money out of your own pocket but pick up $300 a night.

I invite Senator Sherry to indicate on how many occasions he actually did stay with his mother or at his mother's place in that 143 nights and whether he paid out any money on those occasions. I ask him to justify why he happened to be in Hobart on so many occasions. We know that he is right at the top of the tree. We know that as shadow minister for finance there are not too many interest groups that he needs to be seeing on a regular basis. But if he managed to find enough in Hobart on 37 occasions, let us hear about it. Let us not simply say that DAS guidelines have a broad definition. That is not what Senator Kemp said.

More importantly, the proper course of action to take if you want to act openly is to specify Opossum Bay and then argue your case. Say that it comes within a broad definition, point to a guideline if you can and then justify your claim. To simply put down Hobart when you stayed 50 kilometres away, I submit, is very misleading indeed. The taxpayers will be the judge of this. All I can do is invite Senator Sherry to come up with a lot more information than he has provided to date. It is clear that Senator Sherry has managed to find excuses to be in Hobart on as many occasions as possible and at the same time has managed to find opportunities to earn $300 a night. We have no idea on how many occasions he actually had to expend any money out of his own pocket. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —For the first time ever a minister has moved to take note of an answer in a predetermined attack. We have set a precedent in that regard. But the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), if he wants to answer some questions, can answer these questions, which still remain. Does Senator Newman, sitting over there, stay basically in Canberra? Does Mr Anderson basically stay in Canberra? The amazing thing was that, even though he was briefed, the Acting Minister for Administrative Services went into the other place today and said: `There is no definition of "capital city".' How could he be advised of that? I know Administrative Services currently is in a total shambles, but how could he have said that when, firstly, 3½ years ago Senator Sherry's office checked with Administrative Services for guidance and was given it on this very subject? Secondly, the DAS guidelines say the following:

SPEECH.PARA: Capital city is as defined (in relation to its boundaries) by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
There is a guideline. It does apply. It is there in the DAS guidelines. How could Mr Ruddock and, presumably, Senator Kemp be ignorant of that fact? The ABS definition of Hobart is that it:
. . . comprises the local government areas of Hobart, Glenorchy, Clarence and Brighton and the predominantly urban parts of Kingsborough, New Norfolk and Sorrell.

It defines it. So we have a definition in the DAS guidelines of a capital city and the ABS definition of the capital city includes Opossum Bay and many other areas. So, in effect, are we to go back through the records and find that certain members have stayed in Dandenong in Melbourne and therefore have misclaimed because it is not regarded as part of a capital city? Ask anyone in Dandenong, anyone in Parramatta, anyone in Port Melbourne, `What capital city do you live in?' and they will say, `Melbourne', `Sydney', `Hobart'.

So this pre-prepared attack, which has been launched both here and in the House of Representatives, is based on a lack of substantial work, bordering on the misleading of both chambers today. I do not believe they deliberately misled. I just think it was out of total ignorance. Senator Alston comes in and says, `I think Senator Sherry's travel allowance is a bit high.' What does Senator Alston say when the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) in the first nine months of government claims 80 per cent of the avail able days in travel allowance? What does he say to Mr Peter McGauran, claiming 108 days in Melbourne, including Boxing Day when he was at the test cricket the next day? What does he say about the claims of a variety of ministers? Look at the charter allowance of Mr Anderson. He doesn't live in Canberra, but 75 per cent of his 55 charters either start in Canberra or finish in Canberra. Who is fooling who in this debate?

We put this challenge to the government, to Senator Kemp and the bully boys over here: you come up with a substantial allegation. You have today, and you are absolutely wrong, wrong because you did not do your research and because DAS is in a shambles and cannot feed you the information you need. That is the situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the information we need?

—Senator Abetz interjects. He is on the Hansard record at 10 minutes to one today acknowledging that each one of Senator Sherry's travel allowance claims in Hobart is legal. That is what you said. That is in the Hansard . I thought you had done your research. I thought you were smarter than the rest of the Bozos down here. I thought you had gone away and researched it. But you have not. Senator Sherry's Hobart claims meet the DAS definition as defined. It exists. If you are so stupid you only go to the Remuneration Tribunal, you should know that the Remuneration Tribunal's various determinations are interpreted by DAS on a whole range of things. Here is one example where it is. You are absolutely wrong.

—Madam President, you know that the Labor Party is in trouble when Robert Ray, who was not in this chamber during all of question time, Robert Ray, the hammer of people who he alleges are rorting the travel allowance system—and we remember that Robert Ray in relation to Senator Colston and his hammering of that—suddenly is rolled in to defend Senator Sherry. You suddenly are rolled in to defend Senator Sherry.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. The motion was that we take note of Senator Kemp's answer. Surely it is inappropriate for Senator Kemp to take note of his own answer.
—There is no difficulty with a minister who has spoken and given an answer taking part in the debate on that answer.

—Thank you, Madam President. In relation to the debate, Senator Ray missed the central question that Senator Sherry and the Labor Party now have to answer—and this is the question: do Senator Sherry and, of course, Mr Beazley think it is appropriate for Senator Sherry to stay over 40 kilometres out of Hobart at Opossum Bay with his mother while claiming up to $300 a night? That is the issue which Senator Sherry might like to tell us about. Senator Sherry has stayed, we know, some 143 nights in `Hobart' at a cost to the taxpayer of over $40,000. That is what we know.
—Peter McGauran did that for 11 months.
—Yes, a very good interjection, Robert Ray.
—Order! There are far too many interjections. It is almost impossible to hear.

—Thank you, Madam President. We know that in that 143 days, there were 29 Fridays, 28 Saturdays and 15 Sundays. The question that Senator Sherry can now turn his mind to answering for us is: on how many of those 143 nights did he stay at Opossum Bay? That would be of considerable interest. Then it is a matter of whether, according to the standards of the Labor Party and those of Senator Sherry, they feel this is appropriate behaviour. That is the issue: whether that is an appropriate standard of behaviour for the Labor Party.

BREAK.PARA: Opossum Bay, I understand, is some 40 to 50 kilometres out of Hobart. Senator Sherry hops off the plane; he then takes the Comcar out to Opossum Bay for $50, $70 extra. He takes it back into Hobart for another $50, $70, or maybe even more. So Senator Sherry, meant to be staying in Hobart, has already cost the taxpayer substantial amounts of additional money. But we assume—and Senator Sherry can enlighten us on this—that, presumably, he stays at Opossum Bay free of charge.

Senator Ray and others have raised the issue of travel allowances in this parliament. They have pursued many people in this Parliament in relation to this issue. They should not be remotely surprised that it is coming back to bite them, firstly with Senator Sherry.

This is an issue of standards, and Senator Sherry is in the chamber. Senator Sherry, you can stand up and tell us on how many nights of the 143 nights costing $40,000 you stayed at Opossum Bay. You can tell us that, Senator Sherry—and remember that there are Comcar records that presumably can be checked. Then this debate, Senator Sherry, will be one of: what are the standards of the Australian Labor Party and, in particular, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Kim Beazley?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to join this debate—an extraordinary one, the first time ever we have had a government minister move that the Senate take note of another government minister's answer. We must admit that the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, made an absolute fool of himself in question time. This is an orchestrated attack from the Liberal Party, and Senator Kemp could not even organise a supplementary question. Senator Kemp, really, it is not surprising that your deputy leader, the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), trying to get a little bit of a confidence builder after his bad day on Tuesday of last week, was trying to show you how it is done.

SPEECH.PARA: The motivation for this incredibly weak parliamentary performance from Senator Alston and Senator Kemp is this: Mr Sharp and Mr McGauran have resigned as ministers of the Howard government—for rorting. They resigned because they put in false travel claims. Their travel allowance claims were false, and they were found out. They were found out, even though the former Minister for Administrative Services, Mr Jull, who also has had to resign—that is three ministers last week—tried to cover it up. That is the truth of the matter. They were found out. They were found out rorting, and the responsible minister for administration of parliamentary entitlements was found out covering it up. What does that say about the Howard government?

Since that time, of course, we have had the grand strategy hatched by the Treasurer, Mr Costello, in the House of Representatives, and these pathetic underlings over here, Senators Kemp and Alston, to try to square it up. So what have we had? We have had a member of staff of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) attacked, and now we have had Senator Sherry attacked.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about your attacks?

—There is a substantial difference, because Senator Sherry's claims, as Senator Abetz at least had the decency to admit in his contribution earlier on, were legal. That is the difference between the claims of Mr Sharp and Mr McGauran and those of Senator Sherry—and, no doubt, a lot of others. Mr Sharp and Mr McGauran are rorters, and no‐one on that side has suggested—not even these weak, lily‐livered, wimpy Howard government ministers in the Senate—that there is anything wrong with Senator Sherry's claims.

SPEECH.PARA: They are legal, and they know they are legal. They know they are in accordance with entitlements. Frankly, I am amazed that this mob want to open up the business of actually saying, `If you put in a capital city claim, you have to stay in the central business district.' Really?

That is what they are saying: that you can only have a valid capital city claim if you stay in the central business district. What an own goal that is from you, because we all know senators and members on both sides who stay in capital cities and—properly—put in claims even though they happen to stay overnight in areas outside the CBD.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not driving for half an hour down a bush track 50 kilometres from the suburbs of Hobart.
—The point is, in relation to Hobart, as defined by the Australian Bureau of Statistics—
—Not when you are in the bush.

—Wouldn't you have had a winner? Had you had a real winner, you would not have had Senator Abetz and Mr Miles trying to tip the bucket. You would not have had amateurs like Senator Kemp and Senator Alston. You would have got a real professional to come in and try to tip the bucket, had you had a real story. But you know the definition shows that Senator Sherry's claims were legal. He was within greater Hobart, so it was a capital city claim and he has done nothing wrong.

BREAK.PARA: That stands in absolutely stark contrast to the rorters on the government side. That is the difference between McGauran, Sharp and any other claim you care to mention. They rorted and tried to cover up, with the connivance of Mr Jull. You know this is different. You have not proved one claim of wrongdoing against Senator Sherry, and he is absolutely right to call you sanctimonious, lying hypocrites.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Faulkner, two matters: I wish you to withdraw the word `lying'—
—I withdraw it.
—I would draw to your attention that, referring to members of the other place, you should refer to them as Mr Sharp or Mr McGauran.
—Oh yes.
—I do not regard that as an adequate response to my comment, Senator.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —You know when the Labor Party is going badly: they call in Senator Robert Ray. I have to say to you, Senator Robert Ray is usually a polished performer. Today his performance has been abysmal. One of his thrusts today was—disorderly conduct though it was—to say that I had somehow dealt Senator Sherry a terrible blow by announcing publicly what Senator Sherry's home address was during the public debate today.

SPEECH.PARA: Do you know what? On 29 September—two days ago—Senator Sherry, your deputy leader in this place, issued a public media release saying, in part:
The fact is that I have a home in Burnie. I live at 3 Hale Street, Burnie.
That is what Senator Sherry did, and you accuse me of committing a heinous crime by repeating Senator Sherry's press release. The trouble is, the Labor Party do not believe each other any more.

Do you know what brought all this up? Mr Simon Crean, the member for Hotham, when he was challenged about why Senator Sherry's travel allowance was so high, said, `Senator Sherry does not have a home.' That was the only defence proffered on behalf of Senator Sherry: `He doesn't have a home.' That sole defence was destroyed by Senator Sherry himself, when he acknowledged that it was wrong.

But why didn't Senator Sherry seek to correct the record as soon as Mr Crean stated that mistruth? Because he thought it would go to the keeper and nobody would realise. But Mr Costello picked up the line and absolutely pilloried Senator Sherry. As a result Senator Sherry puts out a media release not condemning Mr Crean—his friend and colleague—but condemning Mr Costello.

The public of Australia have the right to ask this simple question: why is it that Simon Crean, a senior man in the Australian Labor Party, was under the impression that Senator Sherry did not have a home when in fact he owns two homes? Why did Mr Crean labour under that misapprehension? I will give you a bit of a guess why: because Senator Sherry's travel allowance was well‐known around this place. It was a matter of constant debate, constant discussion and some awe‐inspiring concern at the magnitude of it. And the only defence that Simon Crean could put up on your behalf, Senator Sherry, was that you do not own a home. Wrong on two counts. You own two. You have admitted to as much.

BREAK.PARA: So what is your excuse? What is the Labor Party's excuse for your high travelling allowance costs, Senator Sherry? That is the matter that the people of Australia want to have answered.
Yesterday, when Senator Sherry was in this chamber, he said that he spent a majority of his time in Burnie. Allow me to quote exactly:
I spend the majority of my time in Burnie and I travel as required.

Coming from the shadow minister for finance, the shadow spokesman on superannuation, when we go through the figures, what do we find? We find that for 60 per cent of his time he is claiming travelling allowance. So, at the best possible analysis, he spends only 40 per cent of his time in Burnie. A minority of the time.

No wonder the Labor Party left this country with a $10.3 billion deficit. You think that 40 per cent of the time is somehow a majority. It clearly is not. You ought to apologise to the Senate and acknowledge that you misled the Senate.

Time is short, but Simon Crean ought to come clean. Why was he under the misapprehension that Senator Sherry did not have a house? Because Senator Sherry never goes to live in the house; he is busily claiming his travel allowance, going around the country or staying at mum's at Opossum Bay, which is 50 kilometres, in rough terms, away from Hobart—a quarter of the way to Launceston. Are you going to tell people a quarter of the way to Launceston that they are really in Hobart? Senator Sherry, you have a lot of explaining to do. Senator Ray said that Mr McGauran resigned; so should you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is unfortunate that the senators who are sitting opposite were not in the chamber at lunchtime.
—We watched it.

—I am glad you did. I did provide an explanation of this matter. The central issue related to Mr Miles, who put out a press release yesterday in respect to a capital city claim vis‐a‐vis a country claim. As I made very clear at lunchtime, when I became a parliamentary secretary I did ask my staff to check the DAS guideline in respect to Opossum Bay. I asked them to collect that and I asked them to check it thoroughly. We checked the DAS guidelines and the guidelines state that `capital city' is as defined in relation to its boundaries by the Australian Bureau of Statistics.
—Why didn't you declare Opossum Bay?

—Because it is part of the Hobart division for TA claims. Senator Alston, when you go to Sydney or Melbourne do you put down Parramatta or Carlton on your claim? You put down the name of the principal city and that is what I did. We checked with the Australian Bureau of Statistics definition, which states that the greater Hobart division comprises the local government area of Hobart, Glenorchy, Clarence—and Opossum Bay is in Clarence—and Brighton, and the predominantly urban parts of Kingborough, New Norfolk and Sorell. If the Department of Administrative Services had said to me, `Senator Sherry, Opossum Bay is not classified as part of Hobart,' then I would have claimed what was the correct country particular allowance. That is what I would have done. As I said, we queried this with the Department of Administrative Services.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Abetz has made some references to my home in Burnie. I issued the challenge earlier; I am very happy for those in the government, and for Mr Costello, to fly down to Burnie on Friday with me. Come down to the Burnie show; come and stay at my house. What is the definition of a house? I own it, I pay rates and all of my personal worldly goods are in Burnie in my house. I spent a month decorating the place. All of my books and my clothes are there. The first thing I do when I walk in the door of my house in Burnie is to throw the washing in the washing machine. Burnie is my residence. Senator Abetz should know all about this because he knocked off a senator on the north‐west coast. He cleaned out the Liberal Party's north‐west senators. Mr Miles knows full well the considerable amount of work I do, the consider able amount of time I spend there and the fact that I am living on the north‐west coast.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're not going to answer these questions, are you? You've got two minutes left to answer the questions.
—Order! There are far too many interjections in the chamber. It is almost impossible to hear and I would ask senators to desist from being so disorderly.

—I raised the issue of Senator Brownhill and I did draw attention to Senator Brownhill's travel allowance claims. I did make the point that Senator Brownhill is in a very similar position to me. It is interesting that Senator Brownhill is not here at all this week. I did raise the issue of Senator Brownhill, although I have not made any remarks about Senator Brownhill. I have highlighted the effective work that he has carried out in respect of primary industries and resources—similar duties to me. Senator Brownhill, in the first year, was in Sydney for 48 nights.

SPEECH.PARA: Could all of the members and senators in this parliament put up their hands if they have not stayed privately? How many of you can say you have not stayed privately? Put up your hands, come on. How many of you have not stayed privately? I would be very interested to know. Do you want to open up that issue? Do you want to open up the issue of where everyone stays and have all of the Comcar records checked? You can check my Comcar records. If you want to open up that issue for everyone's scrutiny, go ahead. You have opened up my affairs. Fine. Go ahead. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

BREAK.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled:
The humble petition of the undersigned Citizens of Australia respectfully sheweth:

(1) That members of the Royal Australian Navy who served in Malaya between 1955 and 1960 have been deliberately and wrongly excluded from eligibility for repatriation benefits under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (the Act) for honourable overseas `active service' under `Operational Service' at Section 6.(1)(c)(ii) of the Act. They are the only Australian Citizens to be treated in that way.

(2) A defined group of citizens, who served in the Malaya area, being members of the Royal Australian Navy Defence Forces so affected, have been wrongly excluded, whereas members of the Army and Air Force were not so excluded, and this is supported by documents in the Australian Archives and elsewhere on public record.

(3) Allied veterans of 50 nations involved in conflicts with Australian forces until the end of the Korean War can have had qualifying eligibility for benefits under the Act. Veterans of South Vietnam, the Philippines, South Korea, Thailand and the United States can have eligibility resulting from the Vietnam War. Their service was recognised after RAN service in Malaya was excluded.
(4) It is claimed that:

(a) Members of the RAN were designated as `on active service' when they served in a designated zone that is within a 12 NM limit offshore from the coastline of Malaya from 9th May 1952 to 1st December 1960. These dates are verified in Declarations by the Governor‐General, Commander‐in‐Chief of the Naval and Military Forces of the Commonwealth, contained in Commonwealth Government Gazettes No. 40, 5th June, 1952 and No. 82, 8th December, 1960.
(b) Members of the RAN were engaged on operational duties that applied to all service personnel everywhere.

(c) Naval personnel were subject to similar dangers as all other Australian service personnel serving in Malaya and there were RAN casualties, including the death by `friendly fire' of a sailor during support operations. This can be attested to be a Naval Flag Officer who witnessed the death on board his ship.

(d) The Royal Australian Navy was `allotted' for operational service from 1st July 1955 and this authorisation was contained in Minute No. 011448 of 11 November 1955, signed by the Secretary to the Department of the Navy.

(e) They were not bound by the `Special Overseas Service' requirements which were introduced in the Repatriation (Special Overseas Service) Act 1962, which act became law some two years after the war in Malaya ended.
(f) the Australian citizens serving in the Royal Australian Navy complied with all the requirements for `active service'. The fourth, for `military occupation of a foreign country' did not apply;

(g) The Department of Veterans' Affairs has indicated it can find no written reason(s) for the RAN exclusion in the Act. In two independent Federal Court cases (Davis WA G130 of 1989 and Doessel Qld G62 of 1990) the courts found the two ex‐members of the RAN had been `allotted'. Davis had served in Malaya in 1956 and 57. As a result of these cases ex‐members of the RAN who served in Malaya and who had, at that time, claims before the Department of Veterans' Affairs for benefits, had their claims accepted. Eight weeks after the Doessel decision the Act was amended to require allotment to have been by written instrument. In Parliament, it was claimed the amendment was necessary to restore the intended purpose of the exclusion, reasons for which can not be found. This action would not have been taken had the Parliament been properly informed. Parliament has unfortunately approved the introduction of qualified retrospectivity through accepting these amendments to the Act resulting in an injustice being perpetrated against ex‐service personnel.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray

Your Honourable House take appropriate action to remove the previous Government's discriminatory exclusion of Naval personnel in the Act thereby restoring justice and recognition of Australian citizens' honourable service with the Royal Australian Navy for their country, whilst on `active service' in the Malaya campaign.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: Bourne, Sen Vicki; Brown, Sen Bob
PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
For permanent protection of old‐growth forests and all other areas of high conservation value, and for the implementation of tree plantation strategies.

This petition from the undersigned respectfully points out that: there is an increasing and urgent demand from the people, to protect all remaining high conservation value forests which support flora and fauna unique to Australia, thus complying with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory. We have a responsibility to future and present generations, and the necessary reasons, knowledge and technology to act now on the following achievable solutions.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate legislate to:

PARA.TAB: immediately stop all logging and woodchipping activities in high conservation value native forests;

ensure intergenerational equity by planning for the rights of future generations, and protecting in perpetuity all biologically diverse old‐growth forests, wilderness, rainforests and critical habitats of endangered species;

facilitate rapid transition of the timber industry from harvesting high conservation value native forests, to establishing mixed‐species farm forestry on existing cleared and degraded lands, using non‐toxic methods to protect ecological sustainability;

maximise use of readily‐available plantation timber for industry needs, using appropriate forestry techniques and progressive minimal‐waste processing methods, such as radial sawing, and wherever possible, reuse and recycle wood and paper products;

support incentives for nationwide employment in composting, soil remineralisation programs, and the planting programs of trees and annual fibre crops, inter‐grown with appropriate fruit and nut trees and medicinal plants;

encourage sensitively‐managed, environmental education tourism in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for natural ecosystems, Aboriginal cultural heritage, sacred sites and other sites of significance;

progressively utilise technological expertise and resources transferred from the military sector, to help implement these tree planting solutions; and to motivate the international community to follow this example.

PETITION.PARA: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Bourne(from 200 citizens)and Senator Brown(from 216 citizens)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Senate notes the Federal Government's $820 million cuts to child care over two budgets.
(2) That the following matters be referred to the Community Affairs References Committee for inquiry and report by 30 June 1998:

PARA.TAB: (a) the impact on families and child care service operators of:

TAB.TAB: (i) the abolition of capital grants,
(ii) the abolition of operational subsidies for community‐based long day and out of school hours care,
(iii) cuts to Commonwealth Block Grants for Vacation Care,
(iv) limiting work‐related care to 50 hours and non‐work‐related care to 20 hours per week,
(v) the changes to rebateable fees for school‐age children using family day care from $3.05 to $1.95,
(vi) limiting child care places to 7 000 in 1998 and 1999,
(vii) freezing the child care assistance and the child care rebate ceilings for 2 years;
(viii) the reduction in the income limit for families with two or more children in care, and
(ix) the abolition of deductions from taxable income of $30 for each dependent child;

PARA.TAB: (b) the extent and impact in the past 2 years and into the future of:

TAB.TAB: (i) fee increases related to budget cuts,
(ii) child care service closures,
(iii) reductions in child care places,
(iv) the use of unregulated backyard care,
(v) reductions in hours and services provided to children,
(vi) redundancies and reductions in staff places and hours within the industry;

PARA.TAB: (c) the effect on the child care sector of the implementation of the Child Care Payments Bill 1997 on 1 January 1998;
(d) the impact of the new planning system on the child care industry;
(e) the criteria the Government will use to regionally allocate child care hours and the impact it will have on the child care industry;
(f) the effect of placing a limit on emergency child care assistance;
(g) the extent of oversupply of child care places;
(h) the extent of unmet demand for child care places;

TAB.TAB: (i) the effect on the whole child care industry, its quality, affordability and the availability of places, of any reduction in quality, significant reduction in or demise of the community care sector in the child care industry;

PARA.TAB: (j) the extent and impact on children of any reduction in the quality of child care services provided and the availability of early childhood education, and the increased use of unlicensed or unregulated care;

(k) the effect of fee increases, changes to the child care payments system and a reduction in the availability or quality of care on women and their ability and choice to participate in the work force;
(l) the impact on the quality of child care and on children and families of any reduction of the current accreditation system;

(m) the advantages to be gained from extending the National Child Care Accreditation Council and its Quality Improvement and Accreditation System to family day care, outside school hours care, and to pre‐school services;
(n) the effect on work‐based child care and on workers of:

TAB.TAB: (i) not having fringe benefits tax exemption for employer sponsored care, and
(ii) any restriction on child care places contained in the Child Care Payments Bill;

PARA.TAB: (o) the impact on child care services of direct payments to parents;
(p) whether current changes and a move to direct payments of child care assistance will result in increased choice and flexibility for parents;
(q) the impact of the proposed smart card voucher system on the child care sector, on the viability of child care services and on families using the new technology;
(r) the impact on family day care services of any decision to abolish operation subsidies for these services; and
(s) the impact of the Government's changes on workers in the child care industry.
