TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I give notice that, at the giving of notices on the next day of sitting, Senator O'Chee will withdraw four disallowance motions, the full terms of which have been circulated in the chamber and which I now hand to the Clerk. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the committee's correspondence concerning these instruments.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows—
Airports Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1997 No 104
27 August 1997
The Hon John Sharp MP
Minister for Transport and Regional Development
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to the Airports Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 104, which provide a formula for the Minister to give an airport operator notice to adjust its foreign ownership to comply with the 49% maximum foreign ownership requirements.

The Committee notes that r.3.01 provides that, where the Minister is of the opinion that an unacceptable foreign‐ownership situation may exist, the Minister must give a company notice before applying to the Court. In effect such notice gives the Company an opportunity to answer the Minister's concerns. Regulation 3.02 sets out the matters to be included in the notice. However, r.3.02 provides only that the Minister may include certain specified matters. The Committee would appreciate your advice on why it is not a mandatory requirement to include these matters.

Paragraph 3.01(2)(b) requires the company to provide evidence to the Minister's reasonable satisfaction that an unacceptable foreign‐ownership situation does not exist. As this discretion may have significant commercial implications, the Committee would appreciate your advice on whether merits review of the exercise of this discretion is available.

Subregulation 3.02(1) provides, quite reasonably, that nothing in r.3.01 affects an airport‐operator company's obligation under s.42(1) of the Act which requires an operator to take all reasonable steps to ensure that an unacceptable foreign‐ownership situation does not exist. The Committee notes, however, that r.3.02(2) provides for prosecution of an operator company whether or not the Minister has given notice under r.3.01 and even if the time allowed in the notice has not expired. The Explanatory Statement advises that the reason for the introduction of the giving of notice provision recognises the difficulties faced by listed companies in complying with strict limits. However, having provided for safeguards under r.3.01, it appears that r.3.02(2) takes away much of the protection of those safeguards. The Committee would appreciate your advice on why r.3.02(2) was considered necessary.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Senator W O'Chee
Chairman Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

I refer to your letter of 27 August 1997 in which you sought my advice in relation to a number of concerns the Committee had with the Airports Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No.104 (the Regulations).
Before addressing the Committee's specific concerns I thought it might be useful to set out briefly the context of the Regulations and what they are intended to achieve.

The Airports Act 1996 (the Act) imposes limitations on, amongst other things, the ownership of leased airports by foreign persons. The ownership provisions of the Act are set out in Part 3 of the Act and the Schedule to the Act. Part 3 limits foreign ownership of an airport-operator company to 49%. There are two offences associated with this rule. Firstly, section 41 prohibits the acquisition of shares which would result in a breach of the 49% rule. Secondly, section 42 obliges an airport-operator company to take all reasonable steps to ensure that the 49% limit is not exceeded. Any breach of these rules can be enforced by a prosecution and/or an application to the Federal Court for remedial orders.

In recognition of the difficulties faced by listed companies in complying with strict limits the Regulations sought to provide a mechanism under which the Minister may give an airport-operator company a period of grace of up to 180 days to adjust its foreign ownership level where necessary to ensure compliance with the 49% limit. While there is nothing in the Act that would prevent the Minister from staying his or her hand for any period administratively, potential bidders asked, and Cabinet agreed, for this to be reflected explicitly in Regulations.

The Regulations were drafted in a form which was consistent with the scheme of the Act. A regulation which would have required (rather than merely empowered) the Minister to delay taking any enforcement action (either by way of prosecution or remedial order) for 180 days would fetter the discretion conferred on the Minister by the Act and thus be invalid. On the other hand, there is no legal objection to requiring the Minister to give notice of his or her intention to apply for a remedial order provided that he or she is not then required to wait 180 days to do so.

While regulation 3.01(1) is intended to require the Minister to give the notice, regulation 3.01(2) makes it clear that the notice may (but need not) include a statement that the Minister Will allow 180 days for the airport operator company to provide evidence that an unacceptable foreign ownership situation does not exist before making the application. Similarly, regulation 3.02(2) is intended to make it clear that the regulation does not fetter the Minister's discretion to bring prosecutions in appropriate cases.

The Committee also expressed concern that the Regulations do not provide a right of review on the merits of a decision of the Minister as to whether he or she is satisfied as to the evidence provided by an airport operator company as to compliance with the foreign ownership limits. I assume that the Committee's concern is that the Minister may then proceed to seek remedial orders without the opportunity for the company to apply for a review on the merits of the evidence which was the basis for the decision to apply to the Court.

Subsection 242 provides that a decision of the Minister to apply, or to refuse to apply, to the Federal Court for an order or injunction is not reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Provision for merits review of the Minister's decision under the regulations would be inconsistent with the unavailability of merits review of a decision to apply for Federal Court orders under the Act. Ultimately, the Act establishes the Federal Court as the authority on whether there has been a breach of the foreign ownership limit. In this context, a right of review of the Minister's decision under the Regulations would have no practical effect and would create the possibility of conflict with the Act.

In summary, the regulations merely provide a formal basis for the Minister to provide reassurance to companies which may exceed the foreign ownership limit despite having made all reasonable efforts to comply. This is in recognition of the practical difficulties for listed companies of ensuring compliance at all times. They do not, indeed cannot, purport to limit the discretion of the Minister to either bring a prosecution or seek remedial orders under the Act.
I hope that the Committee finds this response to its concerns helpful.
Yours sincerely
John Sharp
Minister for Transport and Regional Development

PARA.EMPHASIS: Civil Aviation Regulations (Amendment) Statutory Rules 1997 No 111

SPEECH.PARA: 27 August 1997
The Hon John Sharp MP
Minister for Transport and Regional Development
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Civil Aviation Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No 111, which provide for the appointment of maintenance controllers and for maintenance manuals.

Subregulation 42ZZ(2) provides that CASA may direct an operator to amend the maintenance control manual. As failure to comply with this provision carries a penalty of $5,000, the Committee suggests that it may be appropriate that the direction must be in writing.
Also, rr. 42ZZ(3) and 42ZZA are strict liability offences. Given that the penalty in both cases is $5,000, the Committee asks whether strict liability is appropriate or necessary.
The Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Senator William O'Chee
Chairman Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

Thank you for your letter of 27 August 1997 to the former Minister for Transport and Regional Devel opment concerning the amendments of the Civil Aviation Regulations (Regulations) made by Statutory Rules 1997 No 111.

The first matter of concern to the Committee relates to the fact that the new regulation 42ZZ of the Regulations allows the Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) to give a direction in relation to maintenance control manuals but does not specify that the direction must be in writing. The requirement for a direction to be in writing is dealt with in subregulation 5(1 ) of the Regulations which provides, among other things, that where CASA can give direction under the Regulations, CASA can give the direction in Civil Aviation Orders or otherwise in writing. I have been advised that any directions issued by CASA in relation to maintenance control manuals would be in writing in accordance with subregulation 5(1). Any such directions would also need to be in writing for evidentiary purposes. To confirm these arrangements I will arrange for an amendment to the Regulation to require such directions to be in writing.
The second matter relates to the inclusion in the amendments of strict liability offences in relation to the amendment of maintenance control manuals and the inspection of those manuals.

The maintenance control manual is a fundamental link in the control of the maintenance of class A aircraft (which, in the main, comprise the larger aircraft used in regular public transport operations involving the carriage of fare paying passengers). The need for CASA to exercise greater control, both, over the appointment of maintenance controllers, and over maintenance control manuals, has been highlighted by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation on several occasions and was also referred to in the report of the Coronial Inquiry into the Monarch crash at Young. In these circumstances, I believe that it is necessary and appropriate that strict liability offences attached to these provisions given the drastic consequences that can result from inadequate or improper maintenance of such aircraft.
If the Committee requires any further information, please do not hesitate to contact me.
Yours sincerely
JOHN ANDERSON
Minister for Transport and Regional Development

PARA.EMPHASIS: Instrument of Approval No 1 of 1997 made under ss.4A and 77H of the Customs Act 1901.

SPEECH.PARA: 27 August 1997
Senator the Hon Christopher Ellison
Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister
I refer to the Instrument of Approval No 1 of 1997 made under ss.4A and 77H of the Customs Act 1901 , which approves the Application for a Customs Depot Licence form as an approved form.

Clause 1.2 of the instrument requires the name, address (residential and business) and date of birth of an applicant, all partners, all directors, officeholders and shareholders who will participate in management or control of the depot. The Explanatory Statement does not explain why all these personal details are necessary. The collection of unnecessary personal details by a government agency may be a breach of privacy and the Committee would be grateful for your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
The Senate
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

I refer to your letter of 27 August 1997 in relation to Instrument of Approval No. 1 of 1997 made under sections 4A and 77H of the Customs Act 1901 (the Act), which approved the Application for a Customs Depot Licence form as an approved form. You noted that question 1.2 of the form requires the provision of the name, address and date of birth of the applicant, all partners, all directors, office holders and shareholders who will participate in the management of the depot. You sought my advice as to why the collection of these personal details is necessary as the collection of unnecessary personal information by a government agency may be a breach of privacy.

The Customs Depot Licensing scheme set out in Part IVA of the Act was inserted on 1 April 1997 as part of the new cost recovery scheme for import related services. The new licensing regime applies to premises previously appointed under paragraph 17(b) of the Act as places for the examination of goods on landing. Goods which were being allowed onto these premises were subject to Customs control, however the appointment of these places had no formal application or licensing process.
New section 77G of the Act provides for the granting of a Depot Licence, upon application in accordance with section 77H, to use the place described in the licence for the following purposes:
. the holding and unpacking of imported goods that are subject to Customs control;
. the holding and packing of goods for export that are subject to Customs control; and
. the examination of goods that subject to the control of Customs by officers of Customs.

Section 77H of the Act requires an application for a depot licence to be in an approved form and to contain such information as the form requires. The questions on the form have been designed to enable to Chief Executive Officer of Customs (the CEO) to have sufficient information available to determine whether the application meets the requirements for the grant of a depot licence under section 77K of the Act. In particular, paragraphs 77K(l)(a), (b), (c) and (d) require the CEO to be satisfied that all persons who would participate in the management or control of the depot (including the applicant, all partners (if the applicant is a partnership), all directors, office holders and shareholders (if the applicant is a company), are fit and proper persons to so participate.

In deciding whether a person is a fit and proper person for the purposes of paragraphs 77K(1)(a), (b), (c) and (d), under subsection 77K(2) the CEO must have regard to, amongst other things, any convictions of the person for offences committed against the Customs Act and any convictions for offences against other Commonwealth, State or Territory laws punishable by imprisonment for more than 1 year. To determine whether any such convictions have occurred in the preceding 10 years in accordance with these provisions, Customs uses the information provided in response to question 1.2 on the application form for the purpose of obtaining a police records check. The information and the results of the check are used for the purposes of determining whether the nominated persons are fit and proper persons for the purposes of section 77K of the Act, and does not amount to a breach of privacy.

In closing, I would note that before receiving your letter a review of the form by the Australian Customs Service had already identified this question as one which, without further clarification, might raise concerns as to the use of the information provided. Action is being taken to revoke the approval of the current form and to replace it with a new approved form The new form will include a note at the end of question 1.2 putting applicants on notice that nominated persons will be the subject of a police records check and that the information will be used in part to satisfy the requirement that the nominees are fit and proper persons for the purposes of section 77K of the Act.

The Australian Customs Service has also put in place strict procedural guidelines to ensure that the privacy of partners, directors, employees etc. is not breached should such a police records check result in the CEO not being satisfied that the person is a fit and proper person for the purposes of section 77K of the Act, and that opinion results in a refusal to grant a licence. Information about an individual, or identifying an individual, will not be made available to the applicant for the licence without the consent of the individual concerned.
I trust this meets the concerns of the Committee.
Yours sincerely
CHRIS ELLISON
Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs
27 August 1997
The Hon Philip Ruddock MP
Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Minister

I refer to the Migration Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules 1997 No.109, which amend provisions relating to evidence of ownership of assets, to the internal review of decisions, introduce or increase certain fees and introduce a new form of visa.

Regulation 58 inserts new Part 846. Subregulation 846.222(1) provides for a Gazette notice to specify points for the business skills points test. Similarly, r.59.2 provides that an applicant is affected by a risk factor if the applicant has all of the characteristics of a class of persons specified by the Minister by Gazette notice. Both these provisions appear to be subdelegations of legislative power and therefore invalid unless expressly authorised by the enabling Act. The Committee would appreciate your advice.
Yours sincerely
Bill O'Chee
Senator Bill O'Chee
Chairman
Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator O'Chee

Thank you for your letter dated 27 August 1997, requesting advice as to whether regulation 58 and subregulation 59.2 of the Migration Regulations (Amendment), Statutory Rules No. 109 involved subdelegation of legislative power.

I have received advice from the Attorney-General's Department ("the advice) to the effect that neither regulation 58 nor subregulation 59.2 infringe the rule against subdelegation of legislative power for two reasons, as follows.
Firstly, the regulation and subregulation at issue are expressly authorised by subsection 504(2) of the Migration Act 1958 ("the Act"). Subsection 504(2) of the Act provides that:

"Section 49A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 does not prevent, and has not prevented, regulations whose operation depends on a country or other matter being specified or certified by fee Minister in a notice published in the Gazette after the taking effect of the regulations."

The explanatory memorandum to subsection 504(2) (originally inserted into the Act as subsection 181(1A) by Act No. 196 of 1991), explains that the provision was intended to permit "the Regulations [to] prescribe matters to be specified by the Minister by notice published in the Gazette".

The advice provides that the overall structure of subsection 504(2) contemplates the inclusion of provisions, such the ones at issue, in the Migration Regulations. That is, the structure of the subsection is consistent with the explanation provided in the explanatory memorandum. Similar provisions have been repeatedly included in the Migration Regulations since 1991 on the basis of subsection 504(2).

Secondly, as mentioned in the advice, the making of a Gazette notice under the new provisions should properly be viewed as an exercise of administrative power, rather than an exercise of legislative power. This is because there is an established distinction, enunciated by the Courts, between a legislative instrument and an administrative instrument. Legislation determines the substantive content of the law, such as defining general rules of conduct or entitlements, while administrative action applies the law, whether in a particular case or more generally.

Thus, instruments that take the form of notices prescribing categories of persons (regulation 59.2) or a qualifying points score (regulation 58) in a way contemplated by the law itself are examples of administrative action.
Thank you for drawing this matter to my attention.
Yours sincerely
Philip Ruddock
Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs

Motion (by Senator Tambling) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the Broadcasting Services Act 1992, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Tambling) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

The Broadcasting Services Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 seeks to amend the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to give effect to decisions in respect of X and R‐rated programs on narrowcasting services, which were included in a range of measures announced by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts and the Attorney‐General on 8 April 1997.

Currently, X and R‐rated programming is banned on subscription broadcasting services and on free‐to‐air broadcasting services. However, narrowcasting services, that is, services limited in availability or appeal, are not prevented from providing X and R‐rated programming.

Increasingly, pay television companies are offering extra channels of specialised programming through narrowcasting services. Such services provide pay television companies with an avenue to broadcast explicitly sexual material which mainstream television services are prohibited from showing. In response to considerable community concern, the Government has decided to amend the Broadcasting Services Act to prohibit programs that have been refused classification or have been classified as X on subscription television narrowcasting services and also on open (free‐to‐air) narrowcasting services. This will serve to prohibit the depiction of actual sexual acts (as provided for under the current X classification) across all television services, whether broadcast or narrowcast.

The Government has also decided to apply to open narrowcasting services the same restrictions regarding R‐rated programs as currently apply to commercial television broadcasting services. These include the requirement that codes of practice must provide for modification of R‐rated films to comply with the previous AO classification, and restrict the hours within which M and MA material may be broadcast.

Typically, open narrowcasters are community television services provided free‐to‐air, and without any limitation on access by children. It is considered, therefore, that they should be subject to the same restrictions as apply to other free‐to‐air services in respect of the televising of R-rated material.

It is not proposed to prohibit R‐rated material on subscription television narrowcasting services. The Australian Subscription Television and Radio Association's code of practice for subscription television narrowcasters, which has been registered with the Australian Broadcasting Authority, requires that the broadcast of R classified material on subscription narrowcasting television services will be restricted to access by those with appropriate disabling devices, and services devoted predominantly to adult erotica will be restricted to late night access only.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned until the first day of sitting in the Autumn sittings 1998, in accordance with standing order 111.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —At the request of Senator Cooney, I present the 13th report of 1997 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. I also lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Alert Digest No. 13 1997 , dated 1 October 1997.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Sen Mark

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Community Affairs References Committee on the CJD settlement offer, together with submissions and the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.

This inquiry was established following public expressions of concern by recipients of human pituitary hormone at the fairness and adequacy of the legal settlement being offered by the Commonwealth to the hormone recipients treated under the Australian human pituitary program. This program ran from 1965 to 1985 for the treatment of infertility and short stature. It was suspended in 1985 following deaths overseas from Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease which had been linked to pituitary hormone treatment.

In Australia, the deaths of five hormone recipients from CJD had occurred by 1992. Legal action for compensation for `nervous shock' on learning of the possibility of contracting CJD as a result of treatment was commenced in 1993 by a number of recipients in both Melbourne and Sydney. The settlement offer was made by the Commonwealth prior to any case going to court.

The committee received a large volume of evidence—nearly 140 submissions, both public and confidential, mostly from people who were hormone recipients. The views and concerns expressed to the committee were quite varied.

BREAK.PARA: The committee sat for over 25 hours to hear evidence from in excess of over 60 witnesses. Much of the evidence was conflicting and contradictory. Much of it was of a scientific or technical nature and hence open to different forms of analysis, differing conclusions and, indeed, varying interpretations. Some witnesses saw the committee as a forum to seek expiation of feelings of guilt. Other saw it as a vehicle to demand legal redress in either civil or criminal courts. A few sought compensation; many sought an acknowledgment of pain and suffering from the Commonwealth. A number of witnesses broke down in front of the committee. All committee members were greatly affected by the great suffering endured by recipients and family members. What commenced as a passage of hope for many infertile persons ended as a disaster for some.

It should be noted that this was an all‐party committee. It comprised three government senators, three opposition senators, an Australian Democrats senator and Senator Harradine from Tasmania. There were no party divisions or differences pursued by individual members of the committee. Accordingly, the unanimous nature of the report and the unanimous set of recommendations are proof of the desire of the committee that the government give effect to all recommendations.

Some recommendations go to matters of process, keeping of records and dispersal of information in both a timely and sensitive manner. Other recommendations require significant government departments to review their methods of operation and not be purely reactive. Other recommendations have modest budgetary implications for government. One of the two key recommendations is that all of the new evidence brought before the committee be rigorously reviewed by Professor Allars.

The committee was asked to consider a number of specific issues in its terms of reference. Firstly, it was asked to consider the adequacy of the response to the report by Professor Allars. Following increasing public awareness and media interest arising from CJD deaths of hormone recipients, an inquiry was established in 1993, headed by Professor Margaret Allars. Professor Allars reported in June 1994, making a number of recommendations relating to issues including: the allocation of funds for CJD research; the activities of the CJD task force; the establishment of an advisory committee; fostering support groups; enhanced counselling services; review of NHMRC guidelines on human experimentation; transplantation of organs and tissues from cadavers; guidelines for the provision of information to patients by medical practitioners; and amendment of the National Health Act to ensure information can be released directly to members of the public and that special arrangements applying to the distribution of pharmaceutical benefits are appropriate. The committee concluded that, generally, the recommendations have been adequately implemented, although there were some areas where the committee has recommended that additional action be taken.

Secondly, the committee was asked to consider claims that the government refused to make certain documents related to the inquiry available to recipients. The committee was advised that discovery processes relating to the Allars and other documents were agreed between the Commonwealth and the legal firms representing the litigating recipients. The committee received considerable evidence on allegedly missing or destroyed documents. The committee was satisfied that none of the Allars documents had been lost or destroyed. However, a range of possibly relevant departmental and CSL files have been destroyed, apparently in accordance with standard Australian Archives procedures.

Thirdly, the committee was asked to consider the Commonwealth's offer of settlement. The Commonwealth offered to litigants and then to all recipients on 4 April 1997 to pay compensation in the event that a recipient actually contracted CJD. The Commonwealth also undertook to pay legal costs of the litigants and that benefits under the pituitary hormone trust account would not be affected. The Commonwealth did not agree to pay damages in relation to nervous shock.

Major concerns expressed to the committee related to the failure of the settlement offer to recognise psychiatric injury and the deadlines within which the offer had to be accepted. A related issue was an alleged threat by the Commonwealth to enforce costs against the plaintiffs. The committee was informed that the initial deadline was 24 April 1997. This was subsequently extended to 30 June and then, in accordance with a request by the Senate, until the government's response to the committee's inquiry was known. While most recipients regarded the time frame as insufficient, the committee was advised that the usual acceptance period in Supreme Court matters was seven to 14 days.

The committee was concerned that some recipients felt pressured to settle by reason of the deadline. Of greater concern was the financial situation of many plaintiffs—that without legal aid they could not pursue their case. The committee accepted that people who suffered psychiatric injury should be compensated. This is a key recommendation that may be found as recommendation 6. The committee has recommended that without conceding the likelihood or otherwise of a legal action on psychiatric stress succeeding, the Commonwealth should also offer payment, through the allocation of additional funds to the trust account, to recipients who have evidence that they have suffered psychiatric injury as a result of treatment under the AHPHP. The Commonwealth should consider extending this offer of payment to include recipients who have suffered psychological stress or significant life disturbance. The committee has also recommended that unapproved recipients who are formally identified and accepted as such should be eligible for the settlement arrangements.

The committee further recommends that a formal acknowledgment should be made by the Commonwealth of: the deficiencies in the operation and oversight of the hormone program; the experimental nature of aspects of the treatment under the program; and the anxiety and stress that has been caused to hormone recipients.

Fourthly, the committee looked into whether legal aid was unfairly denied. Eligibility for legal aid is a complex question. Applications need to be made in accordance with guidelines operating for particular schemes. The application for legal aid was originally made in May 1995 and was considered for eligibility under three non-statutory schemes. The application was eventually rejected for funding in August 1996. The committee received detailed evidence on the consideration under each scheme and the review of decisions which applied to this particular application.

The committee was advised that in early 1996 the Attorney-General's Department was of the view that it was an appropriate case to receive legal aid funding under the cases of national importance scheme. However, the proposed costs of the case would have used about half the total money available under that scheme. The department intended to seek ministerial and cabinet approval for additional funding when the election intervened.

Following the election, guidelines for eligibility to receive legal aid changed and the application was no longer eligible for the particular scheme. The committee has noted that, as governments change, legal aid guidelines change and eligibility criteria change. There is a limitation to the funds available for legal aid, and apparently meritorious cases are not always able to be funded. The committee has no doubt that the denial of legal aid placed pressure on many plaintiffs and their legal advisers and influenced their decision to accept the settlement offer.

Fifthly, the committee also considered whether public safety in relation to the pituitary hormone program had been adequately protected. In this regard, the committee relied heavily on the report of Professor Allars. This report contains adverse findings and many instances of deficiencies and illegalities associated with the establishment of the scheme, the collection of glands and preparation of hormones, the role of government agencies, and the decisions and actions of the department following the suspension of the hormone program.

The evidence received by the committee tended to confirm the various findings made by Professor Allars. Not only were these findings not disputed by the committee, but the evidence also provided information which may not have been available to the Allars inquiry and could lead to an expansion of some of the Allars findings.

Much of this evidence involved scientific argument and focused on quite specific aspects of the hormone program. Particular issues raised in this evidence and referred to in the committee's report included the collection of pituitary glands, deficiencies in the development of and compliance with exclusion criteria, the processing of pituitaries—concerns with screening of glands—quality assurance and contamination, potency testing and compliance with good manufacturing practice, developing knowledge and awareness of the transmissibility of CJD, and supervision of the product and the program.

The committee was unable to make an authoritative judgement on the merits of the scientific and technical information provided in evidence to the committee. It considered that some of this information raised serious concerns and warranted a further review. (Extension of time granted) The committee therefore recommended that, in view of the availability of further information—much of which is conflicting in its nature—which may not have been considered by the Allars inquiry, Professor Allars be invited to review, with the necessary independent scientific advice, this further information on scientific matters concerning the AHPHP, which has become available since the Allars inquiry reported and, if Professor Allars is unavailable, that another suitably qualified independent person be invited to undertake the review.

The committee also considered action taken by government agencies following the cessation of the program in 1985. Evidence was received which raised concerns over the approach adopted in relation to a number of actions, including the tracing of both approved and unapproved hormone recipients, the provision of information about CJD and other issues to recipients, and the release of identifiable information to blood banks and organ and tissue agencies. The committee made a number of recommendations to address these concerns.

The committee received the sad and disturbing evidence late in the inquiry of a probable sixth case of CJD. The department's actions in relation to this probable new case appeared slow and reactive and lacking in compassion and sympathy at a time of considerable stress for the recipient and her family. The committee has recommended that the department put in place protocols to ensure sympathetic early intervention so that information and assistance is provided as soon as a recipient is suspected to have contracted CJD.

Finally, I should acknowledge the excellent work carried out in a very short time frame by the staff of the Community Affairs References Committee. They had to collate a large number of bulky and often highly technical submissions, arrange for a large number of witnesses to be heard in a relatively short space of time and carry out a large degree of liaison work with a range of departments. The quality of the committee's report is in no small measure due to the high degree of professionalism they brought to its preparation. In the final analysis, however, it is a report of this Senate and I wish to thank them for their hard work. I commend the report and its recommendations to the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —My comments on this CJD report of the Community Affairs References Committee will be brief in view of its comprehensive nature. In speaking on behalf of government senators, I think it is significant to note the extent of the concern by the government members of the committee for those affected by the sadness of the CJD issues. Those who have suffered and died from this terrible disease have our deepest sympathy, as do their families.

SPEECH.PARA: We commend the recommendations of the committee to the Senate. I am sure that everyone associated with the inquiry would agree that the committee has inquired into the terms of reference thoroughly, as has been demonstrated by Senator Bishop's comments just concluded.

I would like to thank Senator Bishop, as chairman of the committee, for his particularly constructive approach and ensuring that we achieved a unanimous report. It was a difficult issue. The work that Senator Bishop put into ensuring the unanimous report is something of which he should be very proud.

BREAK.PARA: I would also like to thank the secretary of the committee, Mr Elton Humphrey, and his staff for the excellent work they did in providing the support that is so crucial to a committee such as this. The issues were particularly emotive and complex. The work that the committee secretariat put into ensuring that the facts were presented to the senators cannot be underestimated.

I would also like to recognise the work of Senator Lightfoot. He is not speaking on this report at this stage, because he is waiting in the wings, so to speak, to make his first speech in this chamber. Ironically enough, that speech is going to follow the discussion on this report today. He may choose to speak on this issue at a later date. He contributed, in my unavoidable absence during the recess when I was on electorate duties, to ensuring that the government was represented well on the committee.

Government senators are particularly supportive of the recommendation to ask Professor Allars to do further work. We believe that it is essential that hormone recipients and their families, who have been subject to considerable uncertainty in the past, do not face any more uncertainty. Therefore, I am sure the government will move as quickly as possible to request Professor Allars to undertake the work recommended by the committee. In the event that Professor Allars is not available to do so, I am sure that the government will appoint a similarly appropriately qualified and objective person to undertake this work.

From discussions that I have had with the Minister for Health and Family Services, Dr Wooldridge, in the consideration prior to this committee really getting under way, the government is particularly keen to respond to any committee recommendations at an early date. The government members of the committee very much empathise with the concerns and extreme sadness of recipients and their families. I am sure the government in its response will reflect its real understanding that issues connected to CJD are about people and their families at a very profound level. I certainly commend the report to the Senate as a very constructive document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees, Sen Meg

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to thank the committee staff for their dedication, for the enormous volume of work they got through in a very short period of time, and for the excellence of this final report. I also commend the chair for the work that was done in making sure this was a majority report with no dissent and, indeed, for getting a set of recommendations that everyone could agree to. In particular, I thank Senator Harradine for his meticulous research and questioning, and Senator Lightfoot, the government senator who worked with us most of the time but who, unfortunately, cannot come into the chamber to comment on this report today as he has not yet made his first speech.

SPEECH.PARA: I think I am right in saying that this was a difficult and, at times, emotive issue for members of the committee. But we have to acknowledge that it is a devastating problem for the people caught up in this situation. Hopefully, this committee's unanimous report will be another step along the road to justice for them and that it will ensure those people are supported, and not just financially. I will draw attention to a recommendation that relates to this area. It goes beyond just financial support; it goes to recognition of the experimental nature of these programs, recognition of the difficulties they and their families now face, particularly in light of the sixth case. We must now think of all those people who can go back through the batch numbers and, perhaps, link their own treatment to the same batch as the sixth victim.

One of the key recommendations does involve money, and I hope that the government does not step back from it. Indeed, I would not just recommend to the Senate that this report be accepted. I would also recommend to the government that the recommendations be followed. Recommendation No. 6 says that an additional allocation of funds to the trust account has to be made, and that the purpose should be widened to include those people who are able to show that they do have psychiatric injury, psychological stress or significant life disturbance as a result of being part of this program. We are talking about men and women, most of whom have families who are also very much affected by this.

I want to refer to some of the issues that are very much in the minds of some of those who are still involved with litigation. In particular, I call on the government to make it far easier for these people to access the documents they need. This has been covered in the recommendations quite clearly, but we should not have these barriers put in place for people who are trying to get justice.

We are not just talking about official recipients. One of the points made, as we listened to the witnesses, was that there are a number of unofficial recipients; that some doctors kept spare material on one side and treated a number of other patients experimentally. Tracing them, as well as tracing the rest of the recipients, is something that, hopefully, the department will facilitate very speedily.

The deficiencies of the program must be acknowledged. I think that many of those who came before us found it very difficult to appear before the committee and, in front of others, go through the trauma they and their families have been through. We have to now look at an acknowledgment of the various deficiencies within the programs, going back to issues such as the collection of the glands and the fact that some, it seems, were collected illegally. The report, at page 125, says:
Although exclusion criteria were established, the Allars Inquiry found that there was a failure to communicate the criteria to the pathologists and mortuary attendants who removed the glands.

Stage by stage, as we worked through the processes followed to get this program up and running, we found that there were breaks in communications and that information which was available was not flowing through to many of the people making the decisions.

We did use the Allars documents quite a bit. We noted that that inquiry looked at the warnings that were not heeded from people like Dr Whitten of the National Biological Standards Laboratory. He noted in 1966 that, because large particles, including viruses, would precede the hormone through the column—this is the extraction process for the hormonal material that they were after—the line would become contaminated.

Despite a lot of technical evidence before the committee, I still had great difficulty accepting that all of these warnings were out there but that somehow the message did not get through. Certainly, patients were never informed of the likelihood of any problems of any sort of contamination of the material that they were receiving.

We looked at some of the history of the knowledge of CJD. It was a disease that was first identified and described in 1920. In 1968, the transmissibility of the disease in monkeys was understood. In 1974, the first transmission in people, through a corneal transplant, was acknowledged. And, again in 1974, there were warnings beginning to appear in international medical literature. But, somehow, those involved in the programs here at all the various stages—whether it was those actually running the program, those overseeing the program or those in the departments—did not heed the messages. We never really established whether people were not reading these international reports and, therefore, were not reading about the difficulties, but the message certainly was not getting through.

In 1977 a Nobel Prize winning paper contained warnings about CJD. That is where the British have drawn the line as far as compensation is concerned. They have basically said that, as it was understood in 1977, people certainly should have made themselves aware of the most up‐to‐date research regarding this issue, and compensation is payable after that.

I will not go into many of the details in terms of the rest of the recommendations. I will just say, in closing, that I hope this report goes some way to offering some comfort and additional support to all those people who were so active in requesting that this be looked at by the Senate. I hope that it will also be of some comfort to those who have been so upset by the way in which the settlement was made and who were feeling that they were forced to sign on the dotted line—it seems that even the threat of losing their homes was understood to be hanging over the heads of many—and accept the government's offer.

The government's offer really added up to nothing more than waiting until people were confirmed to have CJD—mostly that is post‐mortem—and then compensation would be payable. I think we had an admission that it was really not much more than was available already.

I hope that the government accepts these unanimous recommendations and that they do not sit on a shelf somewhere for month after month waiting for something to be done. Despite the fact that there are recommendations here that do involve money, and despite the fact that some members of the committee felt that there could have been some stronger recommendations, I stress that they are unanimous and I hope that this government will act upon them as soon as is possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity of expressing appreciation to Senator Lees, the last speaker, and to the members of the Senate Community Affairs References Committee—particularly to the chair and to the secretariat. A mighty job has been done. I also express my gratitude to the committee and to the Senate in enabling me to become a participating member of the committee for the duration of this inquiry.

SPEECH.PARA: I, of course, welcomed the establishment of the inquiry into aspects of CJD, the government's response to the Allars report, the treatment of recipients of human pituitary hormones and whether certain government bodies failed to protect public safety.

The recommendations that are contained in this document—and I seriously recommend that honourable senators get the document and study it—resulting from the inquiry are modest, moderate and manageable. I do hope that those to whom the recommendations are directed understand that. I believe that the recommendations could have been far more stringent but it must be indicated to the chamber that these are unanimous recommendations.

The history of the human pituitary hormone program is a history of broken rules. It is another example of the deadly results of the technological imperative driving so much medical research and the application of medical research. The driving force in many of these areas is the technological imperative that what can be done should be done and it is done, very often, with insufficient attention to proper procedure, health risks and informed consent.
As Dr David Howes, the former chief virologist and head of the biologicals branch of the National Biological Standards Laboratory, the NBSL, told the committee:
It is the consumers who will pay the heaviest price . . . when the duty of care plays second fiddle to other imperatives . . .

These are very important matters indeed. Our examination of the whole CJD episode provided a window into lax processes and cover‐ups by those responsible for regulating human experimentation and by those whose grave duty it is to ensure the highest standards in the regulation and manufacture of biological products derived from blood, tissue and organs.

Women seeking help for infertility, and men and women of short stature were essentially guineapigs in an unlawful experiment which has so far killed four women and one man. Another woman is believed to be dying from the disease.

Every day, recipients must live with the possibility that they could be living incubators of the human equivalent of mad cow disease. I urge my Senate colleagues to read their distressing testimonies to try to comprehend the depth of their suffering.

Of course, very little can be done other than what is recommended in the committee report and people need to go through the traumatic but, nevertheless, healing experience of acceptance. They need to be encouraged to do this and they need to be given all the support that they require. Some of our recommendations go to that very point.

This report actually documents the mistreatment of these people—the recipients—at the hands of those whose responsibility it was to ensure the highest standards were applied to experimentation on human subjects in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: CSL did not meet the requirements of the Australian regulatory authorities in the manufacture and distribution of the hormones. It failed to follow world's best practice in pooling and homogenising of glands. It failed to comply with the codes of good manufacturing practice. It told pathologists to ignore the exclusion criteria about possible hepatitis‐infected glands.
In evidence to the committee, Dr Wes Whitten, reproductive physiologist and former assistant director of the National Biological Standards Laboratory, said:
It was a shocking product. I cannot believe that this could have been marketed.
Dr Frank Peters, formerly assistant and acting director of the NBSL, told the committee that it was his opinion that:
not one batch of fertility hormone met all the regulatory standards and many did not even meet CSL's own rudimentary standards.

The lack of informed consent recurs time and again in the thousands of pages of submissions and transcripts. Recipients believed that the hormones were safe. They did not know that the HPG had not been evaluated for clinical use before the program started. They did not know they were receiving processed material from dead bodies, some of which was 99 per cent impure.

Possibly the most damning indictment of the procedures for collecting the glands was the statement by Dr P. Schiff, CSL's representative on the Human Pituitary Hormone Advisory Committee, HPHAC. He was responsible to the then minster for health in overseeing the program. He advised the gland collectors that, `Unless the body is badly decomposed it is never too late to take the gland.' In other words, decomposing body parts could be removed and processed for use in living humans.

Conflicts of interest were rife. Those with a vested interest in the program were also those supposed to be regulating the hormones. There was enough information in 1966 to indicate that the program should not have been allowed to proceed. But it did, and was only shut down in May 1995. All overseas cases involving hormone recipients have been settled in favour of the recipients. France, in fact, has gaoled two doctors for manslaughter and a pathologist in charge of the program for poisoning. But in Australia no-one has been prosecuted. No-one has admitted fault. In the words of one hormone recipient: `It is not the money that matters; it is the fact that people should be accountable for what they did to us.'

It could be argued that all of this is with hindsight. But there are certain universal ethical principles which should be maintained and should have been maintained then. One of them is: first do no harm. The second is: do not allow the science technologists to be the ones who influence the setting of ethical standards. You will note that we on the committee have recommended to the NHMRC that the revision of the statement on human experimentation should be expedited. That will be done by the Australian Health Ethics Committee. One of our worries is that the current IECs are in-house committees and, therefore, are not totally separate from influence by science technologists and those with a vested interest.

I commend the secretariat and the committee members for their extremely hard work. I hope the recommendations will go some way to providing justice and hope to the victims of the CJD legacy and contribute to higher, tighter standards in human experimentation and the protection of public safety. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on Public Works, I present the following reports: No. 9 of 1997, Development of operational facilities at RAAF base Learmonth, Western Australia; and No. 10 of 1997, Redevelopment of facilities for the 51st Battalion Far North Queensland Regiment throughout Far North Queensland and the Torres Strait. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the reports.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statements in Hansard .
Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: The first report which I have tabled concerns the proposed development of operational facilities at RAAF Base Learmonth. The base is located on North West Cape, Western Australia, 1,235 kilometres north of Perth and the base covers an area of approximately 2550 hectares, situated on the coastal plain between Cape Range and Exmouth Gulf. The nearest township, Exmouth, is 35 kilometres north of the base.

RAAF Base Learmonth is a bare base which forms part of a chain of defensive airfields across northern Australia and is vital to the air defence of north‐western Australia. The primary function of the base is to serve as a deployment base for combat aircraft in a contingency. The base was developed during the early 1970s and 1980s and no further development or major maintenance work has occurred since.

The proposal examined by the committee involved the construction of: explosive ordnance loading aprons for fighter, strike and maritime patrol aircraft—one apron will double as an explosive ordnance apron for transport aircraft;

alert facilities for fighter aircraft; operational and technical support facilities; ordnance preparation facilities; a central emergency power station; rehabilitation of existing airfield pavements; airfield lighting equipment; and
airfield lighting, engineering services and civil works.
The estimated out‐turn cost of the proposed work was $69 million.

The committee has recommended that the work should proceed. After inspecting the base and conducting a public hearing at Exmouth, at which senior RAAF officers gave evidence, the committee concluded that there is a need for operational facilities at RAAF Base Learmonth to be upgraded to bring them into line with requirements designed to enhance its capabilities for the deployment of fighter, strike and maritime aircraft in a safe and flexible manner.

The proposal attracted interest from local government authorities, who raised a number of issues relating to the use of the main runway for regular public transport aircraft as well as the siting of a number of facilities within the civil aviation area. The downgrading of the runway's pavement classification number by Defence was a matter of concern and the committee has recommended that Defence should enter into further discussions with the Shire of Exmouth about the practicalities of upgrading the pavement classification number of the runway. The project was the subject of environmental impact assessment and the report mentions a number of safeguards and precautions to be adopted during and after construction of the project.

The second report which I have tabled covers the proposed redevelopment of facilities for the 51st Battalion Far North Queensland Regiment throughout Far North Queensland and the Torres Strait. By way of background, I should mention that this Army unit, with its headquarters in Cairns, is a General Reserve Regional Force Surveillance Unit. The role of the unit is to conduct reconnaissance and surveillance operations in Cape York Peninsula, the Gulf country and Torres Strait. Elements of the unit are widely dispersed over more than 20 locations throughout its area of operations, which covers 640,000 square kilometres.

During any move towards conflict, FNQR would be a vital element of the first three layers of land defence. The unit's observation posts or reconnaissance patrols would be a vital source of initial strategic information which would provide early warning of any changing situation. Once other military forces are in place, the unit would operate in a zone well forward of any protected vital asset in Far North Queensland to provide a surveillance screen.

Before addressing the specifics of the proposed work, the committee sought to establish if the unit has an assured future, following the restructuring of the Army. The committee was advised that this unit, the Pilbarra Regiment and NORFORCE—all regional force surveillance units—have an assured future. The committee also sought to establish if the recruitment of reservists can be sustained. Again, Defence advised that a fundamental principle of recruitment is to recruit people from local communities who have specific knowledge and understanding of their areas and use this to support the surveillance capability.

The history of the unit has been characterised by strong representation of members of local communities. At present, 40 per cent (200 members) of the unit are indigenous. It was also pointed out that the unit is currently manned to its full establishment. This is a good indication of the effectiveness of recruitment campaigns and a strong indicator of the support for the unit in Far North Queensland.

The proposal involves the provision of facilities which will enhance the unit's ability to meet its operational commitments and will involve the redevelopment of some existing facilities and the provision of new facilities. This work will address current deficiencies such as non‐functionality, size, non‐compliance with building and occupational health and safety standards and location. The proposal involves work at 22 locations.

The committee concluded that, based on the evidence the general lack of modern storage facilities and poor working conditions at headquarters, company headquarters and patrol locations are having an adverse impact on the ability of the unit to undertake assigned tasks.

The proposed work encompasses: construction of a new facility on the Queerah Meatworks site in Cairns for the Regimental Headquarters, Administration Company, Alpha Company and 134 Regional Cadet Unit; new company facilities at Weipa;

new platoon facilities at Atherton and Normanton; upgrading of existing platoon facilities at Innisfail and Bamaga; upgrading of the camp on Horn Island; upgrading of existing facilities at Normanby Street and the construction of new facilities at the naval fuel installation site on Thursday Island; and provision of secure storage for vehicles, boats and associated equipment at 14 patrol locations at Cooktown, Coen, Kowanyama, Aurukun, Pormpuraaw, Lockhart River, Cloncurry, Burketown, Mornington Island, Badu Island, Boigu Island, Yam Island, Darnley Island and York Island. The estimated out‐turn cost of the proposed work is $22.5 million.

The committee has recommended that the work should proceed. The committee sought to establish if there will be opportunities for the local construction industry to be involved in the project. The committee was advised that elements of the project will be packaged to maximise opportunities for involvement by locally based companies. Normal tendering processes will be followed. I commend the reports to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Before I call Senator Lightfoot, I remind honourable senators that this is his first speech and I would therefore ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lightfoot, Sen Phillip

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin my speech this afternoon I would like to again acknowledge the contribution of the late Senator John Panizza, whose position I was fortunate enough, under unfortunate circumstances, to take. I offer again to his wife Coral, his children and his family my condolences. I knew John very well. John was a man of the bush, something with which I associate myself. His life's interests, apart from his family and his church, were farming and mining, two pursuits I am vitally concerned with. I have given an undertaking that not only will I look after the people of Western Australia, but I will particularly concentrate on those people in the bush whom John served so well. I trust that I will be able to fill, in some way at least, the boots that he so untimely left behind.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to declare that I am a republican—if a republic can place more bread on the national table for those in need, if a republic can reduce national debt, if a republic can resolve the problems between black and white Australians, if a republic can bring with it honesty and integrity through all levels of government, if a republic will bind the commonwealth of states together in a mutual bond of trust and fairness, if a republic will deliver lower unemployment, particularly to our youth, and if a republic will cause Western Australia to obtain a more equitable retention of the wealth it creates.

If the mooted republic, however, is to split us along sectarian or ethnic lines or rend the fabric bandage that has bound us together for nearly 100 years—one of the very few nations on earth to have maintained a democracy for so long—then that will only reinforce my conviction that the system of government we have is by its history enviable. Then I will remain under these circumstances a staunch advocate of the monarchical system.

I am not always a supporter of the royal family, but of the system of government I am, lest it be perceived as ambiguous, an unabashed admirer of Her Majesty the Queen Elizabeth II, one of the greatest women, I believe, of the 20th century.

Political change has too often in history ended in tragedies—such as those which are being enacted in several discrete parts of the globe currently—and brought with it bloodshed, hatred and division. I have no doubt that the republican‐monarchical debate will, by its very nomenclature, degenerate into sectarian lines at least in part. Whether the issue attracts spontaneous advocates to its ranks who believe that one or the other of the systems will be better for Australia remains to be seen. Perhaps as never before in our history, except in times of war, will our youth, with their pristine minds and honest, uncluttered motives, play such a determining role in our future.

BREAK.PARA: There can be no minimalist change. It is not a matter of crossing out `Queen' and inserting `President'. It is not as simplistic as erasing `King', as when George VI died in 1952, and inserting in its place `Queen'. It is a fundamental alteration of our very constitutional foundation. It will cause, before we are through with it, much heartache and vitriolic dissent.

What part, we have to ask, will parliament play? What say will the people of Australia have? What role will the High Court adopt? Will the High Court, for instance, find that having a monarchical state is inconsistent with a republican federation? What will be the excuse if the longitudinal and latitudinal lines that separate the states are erased?

However much admired the promoters of change are, I would ask my fellow Australians to look for the motive behind their advocacy. Words can often blanket meaning and true reasons for the support of change. Change without benefit is nebulous. I wish Australians clear and honest thinking in this, the most important constitutional issue to face us since federation.

Madam President, I now turn to the High Court. The perceived aptitude that the High Court has of recent times to transgress upon the hallowed green and red carpets of the legislature deserves some comment. Since its inception in 1903, two years after federation, the court, until the early 80s in the case of the Commonwealth, and the mid 80s in respect of the states, had always had the collective and paternal eye of the London Privy Council to temper any constitutional excesses. The Privy Council, in effect, was the last appellate court for the nation.

With the statutory cessation of appeals to the Privy Council, the High Court became the last court of appeal for the Australian nation. The High Court did, however, acknowledge that, whilst a residual path for the states to take constitutional issues to the Privy Council still existed—and still, in fact, exists—the High Court was not going to give its imprimatur to allow any such appeals. That begs the question as to why no reform of the High Court was undertaken when inordinate power—some would say, excessive power—was transferred to the High Court by itself, in effect, in the 1980s.

How do we reform the highest court in the land? There are no practical limits to the legislature; it is ultimately all powerful, and should be so. Where constitutional limits as checks and balances do not evolve with the nation's aspirations, then referenda can be resorted to. Governments must not lose their nerve to the judiciary.

I accept unequivocally the concept of prior settlement of Australia by Aborigines—first, by the Oceanic negretos or the Tasmanoids, remnants of whom are still in Victoria, some of the Bass Strait islands and Tasmania; second, by the wave of Murrayians, who crossed the Plains of Carpentaria many ice ages ago; and the last and most significant Aboriginal invasion by the Carpentarians, probably no longer than 14,000 years ago or even less. But one would have to ask: would the High Court decisions on Mabo and Wik have been upheld by the Privy Council in its entirety, if appeals were allowed?

My visit and subsequent correspondence to that august body in London strongly suggests no! That is not to say that I do not accept the prior settlements or even a form of ownership. What I do not accept is that the High Court is omnipotent, infallible, or has the unique god‐given ability to speak `ex‐cathedra' on all issues; or that its charter, significant of which was its role, as outlined by the founding fathers, to protect the states. It has, in too many recent cases, failed to do so. It has become centralist, somewhat arrogant and insulated from the real Australian world.

The High Court is the most manifest of the nation's tripartite machinery of powers. But it is only a cog in that machine; it is not the engine. The people of Australia are the engine, Madam President, and parliament should mirror the people.

At the time that the High Court evolved to become our last court of appeal, reform was needed. Constitutional restructuring of the High Court, in my view, is overdue. While the old adage, `power corrupts, absolute power corrupts absolutely', does not in its literal form apply to the High Court—and I hasten to say that—there is a danger that integrally this essential institution may not march separate from but in step with the legislature and the executive.

High Court reform that reflects representation from the states and territories is needed to prevent the outlying states being overwhelmed by the Sydney‐Melbourne‐Canberra axis. Furthermore, the High Court should be reminded of its initial role as a constitutional court that dealt specifically with constitutional problems—rather than branching into the realms of the legislature, as it is wont to do—and further reminded of its role to protect the states from the creeping erosion of their rights and the negative effect of centralism.

With respect to states rights, since the formation of this indissoluble federation of states—long on gestation—in 1901, there have been arguments between the federal government and the states. Most have been well‐justified. Western Australia, which produces nearly 30 per cent of national export income and yet pays $1.5 billion more in taxes annually than it receives, has every reason to resent at times its treatment by the increasingly centralist governments of Canberra. If one were to take Mr Keating's last budget as an example, although Western Australia has 25 per cent of the national road network, is one‐third of the nation, contributes, as I have said, 30 per cent of national export income and has about 10 per cent of the population, it was, nonetheless, only allocated 8½ per cent of national road funding by Mr Keating in 1995.

Again, over the last four years, in spite of the massive contribution the state makes to the nation's coffers—we have the biggest diamond mine in the world, the biggest alumina powder provider in the world and the biggest delineated reserves of iron ore, we boast the biggest port in terms of tonnage in the world, rank with the biggest in production of gold, nickel and rutile, we will probably be the biggest producer of wheat in the nation this year and we are the biggest producer of petroleum gas condensate in the nation—our Commonwealth grants, including tied grants, which are part of a system which could be described as fiscal slavery, have been slashed by approximately $700 million in real terms, with more to come.

There would be no problems with our state's hospitals, roads or schools if our forward planning—predicated on our share of the federal cake being equitably distributed—was not reduced. It should never be forgotten that it was the states which created the federation. Yet the federal child is dictating to the parental states in an increasingly worrying manner, by controlling the purse strings which were in the possession of the six self‐governing states 96 years ago.

It should also be remembered that the states in aggregate are infinitely stronger than the federal government, which produced as little as $30 per capita last fiscal year in the Australian Capital Territory. The fiscal erosion of the states—particularly Western Australia—must stop if the federal government is to survive as a contented institution into the third millennium.

On this point, the Constitutional Convention, in my opinion, should include discussions on federal‐state reformations; not whether the Northern Territory should necessarily become a fully‐fledged state—I do not think we can afford that—but a sincere effort to reform and to stop the erosion of the outlying states, which causes resentment and antipathy towards Canberra.

When I think of Western Australia, I am reminded of Aeneas Gunn's We of the Never Never and her immortal words, `the tyranny of distance'. Western Australia is the only mainland state not to have a direct flight to Canberra. Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane, Adelaide and even Newcastle and Coolangatta do but neither Western Australia nor the cherub state of Tasmania do. Recently—today, in fact—the federal aviation authority announced that Malaysia and New Zealand would be granted direct flights to the national capital. While I welcome those initiatives, the insult to Western Australia must be abundantly clear.

We are yet to have a representative in the federal cabinet. I trust that that anomaly will be rectified during what must be, at a guess, a cabinet reshuffle. While the Commonwealth has increased its spending by 21 per cent over the same decade, we suffer both the iniquitous tied grants that have increased from 46 per cent to 55 per cent in a decade and are the chains of a centralist slaver around our necks and a decrease of 8 per cent in funding to Western Australia.

From Perth to Darwin an undefended coastline which includes in its perimeter Port Hedland—the biggest tonnage port in the world, as I have mentioned—and the North West Shelf, the nation's biggest producer of petroleum hydrocarbons, adjacent and contiguous to that coastline.

Unlike South Australia, which has never had a High Court judge, at least Western Australia does boast one and, at times, two. With the implementation of Mabo and Wik, we have massive problems—unique to Western Australia—which require special attention. We hope these will be addressed by the Wik 10‐point plan. We believe that plan goes a long way to resolving those problems, so inherent and manifest in Western Australia.

Western Australia does have, as I pointed out, unique problems; not ones associated with its own making but more with the increasing cost to it of federalism. During my time in the Senate, a position in which I am honoured to serve my state, I intend to do just that: serve my state to the best of my ability and, through it, the rest of the nation. I trust, at the end of my tenure, my home state of Western Australia is better served and stronger for me being here. I thank you Madam President for your indulgence and I thank you fellow senators.

TITLE.XREF: FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

BREAK.XREF: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1997

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick

BREAK.PARA: FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND TRADE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997
The Foreign Affairs and Trade Legislation Amendment Bill 1997 is an omnibus bill which amends five acts administered by this portfolio:
. The International Organizations (Privileges and Immunities) Act 1963 (International Organisations Act)
. The Chemical Weapons (Prohibition) Act 1994 (Chemical Weapons Act) and the Nuclear Non‐Proliferation (Safeguards) Act 1987 (Nuclear Safeguards Act); and
. The Consular Fees Act 1955 and the Passports Act 1938.

The bill addresses a diverse range of issues, mainly of a technical nature, including meeting formal legal obligations in respect of international organisations, strengthening international nuclear safeguards standards and false passport applications.
International Organisations Act

The bulk of the amendments included in this omnibus bill relate to the International Organisations Act. These amendments update a nearly 35 year old act. They are necessary to keep pace with the increasing number and diversity of international organisations now being established.

An important amendment will allow for the simultaneous entry into force of both the treaty establishing an international organisation and the regulations relating to that organisation. Otherwise Australia could find itself in technical breach of treaty obligations if there were to be a delay in implementing associated regulations. This amendment will be particularly useful when the treaty is unlikely to enter into force until some years after agreement has been reached to establish the organisation.
Another of the more important moves in this bill is to tighten the definition of an international organisation which can be eligible for privileges and immunities.

Australia only grants privileges and immunities which are required under our international obligations and commitments. When negotiating privileges and immunities as part of international agreements, this Government takes the line that specific items should be included only where there is a demonstrated functional need. We have to be satisfied that the specific privilege or immunity is necessary for the effective operation of the organisation.
Disarmament Issues—Chemical Weapons and Nuclear Safeguards Acts
This bill also amends an oversight in the drafting of the original Chemical Weapons Act.

It is highly unlikely that an inspection team will ever have to come to Australia to investigate another country's allegation that Australia was in breach of the Convention. Nevertheless, should this occur, representatives of the country making such an allegation will now be extended standard diplomatic privileges and immunities, along with other members of the inspection team.

Australia is committed to the international disarmament process and enjoys a well‐deserved reputation as a leading player internationally on arms control issues. That reputation has been enhanced by this Government's successful efforts last year to help bring to conclusion the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty—a goal sought after by the international community for over 20 years—as well as our work over the last year in leading the international drive to gather sufficient ratifications to bring the Chemical Weapons Convention into force.

The appointment in May of Dr John Gee, an officer of the Department, as Deputy Director‐General of the newly established Organisation for the Prohibition of Chemical Weapons reflects wide recognition among parties to the Convention of Dr Gee's professional background and experience. Moreover, this appointment reinforces Australia's prominent position in this sphere of disarmament activity.

Similarly, Australia's reputation is further bolstered by the appointment of Richard Butler to the Chair of the United Nations Special Commission (UNSCOM), the body charged with ensuring the discovery and destruction of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction.

This Government's commitment to the cause of disarmament is evident in Australia's substantial contribution to the international effort to address the problems caused by the misuse of anti‐personnel landmines.
In April last year the Minister for Defence and the Minister for Foreign Affairs announced Australia's support for a global ban on the production, stockpiling, use and transfer of these weapons.
