I do not wish to labour this point for too long, but the Labor Party lost the right to speak about full employment after 13 years and `the recession we had to have'. Because of your failures in that area you have lost the right to get up and lecture the people about this. We always remember the recession which we, apparently, `had to have', and which threw hundreds of thousands of workers out of a job. There was never a complaint from you, Senator Cook. In fact, you were always the person up here justifying it. So we do not need to be lectured by you with your pious comments, Senator Cook. You had your chance and you failed.

This government is committed to restoring prosperity and employment in this nation. One of the ways you do it is by having sound fiscal policies. If big government spending could create jobs we would have a surfeit of jobs in this country. A surfeit of debt has been left to us thanks to Senator Cook and his colleagues. The government has a commitment in this area, a commitment to increasing the prosperity of people, to making sure that wages can be related to productivity and to the growth which this will entail, to making sure that we work towards achieving full employment. This government has a huge commitment in this area. That is why we are doing these things. Part of the reason for the charter of budget honesty is to stop wreckers like the previous government, who come in and cause so much chaos and pretend that everything all right. Then, when we open the books, we find that is not the case.

Senator Cook, you are entitled to your views, but spare us your piety on this matter. You have huge amounts of baggage on this issue. Senator Cook, I believe that you, among other former ministers in your party, given your dreadful record, have lost the right to talk about jobs in this country. You were not job creators; you were job destroyers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one should underestimate the importance of the amendment that Senator Cook has moved. I am certainly not underestimating or taking lightly the government's resistance to it. The issue of full employment has a very precise and serious meaning in economics and in the general view of the population and those who comment on these matters. Classical economics—I must say, Senator Cook, I have never thought of you as classical; perhaps more as a sports model with a few years on the clock—says that full employment is about two to three per cent unemployment. Senator Cook well understands the importance of what he is putting down here and the guidance he is attempting to give government. The government does not want to be pushed in that direction because it will put a very onerous burden on it to deliver something which both sides of the house recognise is notoriously difficult to deliver on these days.

SPEECH.PARA: The overall economic prosperity and welfare of the Australian population are important additions, Senator Cook, to the principles of sound fiscal management in this bill. We say again and again that society does not serve economics; economics must serve society.

Amongst all the things you list, Minister, it is the job of your government to deliver to your fullest capabilities full employment, job security and the welfare and advancement of Australians. You would find it very difficult not to agree with those sentiments, but we all disagree as to the method of getting there. This is an attempt to commit you, if you like, to that direction—to a direction. Accordingly, I advise Senator Cook that the Democrats will be supporting his amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to rise earlier in the debate but, on mature reflection, and after listening to the support of the Democrats, I will not be baited by the government on this. I will pocket all the criticisms and personal innuendo made against me, Minister. Thank you very much for that. But your job is to explain to this chamber why it is good en ough to have these provisions in the Reserve Bank Act but it is not good enough to have them in the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —If you had listened you would have noted my comments on the preamble and how the government would define that preamble. The preamble talks of `maintaining the ongoing economic prosperity and welfare of the people of Australia'. As far as the government is concerned, this includes the goal of sustainable economic growth and full employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Murray, I thought your peroration was fairly good. I was about to wish issue a `hear, hear!' But unfortunately you had a concluding sentence which did not appeal to me too much. This government is entirely focused on delivering growing employment in this country, setting the basis for that, and setting the prosperity for the security and welfare of this country. That is the goal. Sound fiscal policy is one of the means by which such a goal can be achieved. There are differences of opinion on the means to an end, and that is quite appropriately the subject of debate in this chamber. We think the policies you put forward are policies which are liable to increase unemployment, not reduce it. They would be liable to add to the insecurity of the Australian people, not increase it.

Let me make this government's commitment to sustainable growth absolutely clear. It is not the sort of growth we had under Labor: whoops, down it comes again; there is the recession we had to have. For months, as unemployment mounted and the queues of unemployed lengthened, we could not even get the former government to concede that there was a recession.

Senator, let me make it clear. There is no doubt about this government's commitment. That is why we have had to make some tough decisions—and, I might say, very rarely do we get support from the non-government parties for those tough decisions. A generous harvest will be reaped as a result of our policies for this country, and it will be because we had the guts to take a few of these tough decisions.

BREAK.PARA: Senator, have no doubt about our commitment to those goals. But this is not the part of the bill in which they should be included. This is to do with fiscal matters, and the preamble makes it very clear where we stand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just say that we know the preamble has no meaning here; that is as a consequence of the Native Title Act. We know that that is not the relevant part to be construed as a direction of government. So what you are saying, Senator, is not to the point. Also, you still have not answered the question: why is it that you will not put in this bill what is already in the Reserve Bank Act in terms of full employment and the welfare of the national economy?

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Margetts's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (Senator Cook's), as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3) Schedule 1, clause 5, page 7 (lines 28 and 29), omit "financial effects on future generations", substitute "financial and social effects on future generations and the implementation of the principles of ecologically sustainable development".
(6) Schedule 1, clause 21, page 16 (lines 23 and 24), omit "the financial implications of demographic change", substitute:

TAB.TAB: :(a) the financial implications of demographic change; and
(b) the social implications of policy decisions which may affect future spending and taxing policies; and
(c) the environmental implications of policy decisions which may affect future Government spending and taxing policies.

SPEECH.PARA: In trying to flesh out the intention of government with regard to this bill, these two amendments further the process we have been engaged in.

There is certainly nothing wrong with the government's existing intention to ensure that its policy decisions have regard to their financial effects on future generations. No‐one is going to object to that, but what we say, once again, is that that leaves out and leaves open the potential for important considerations not to be brought into play by the government of the day. Those important considerations, as spelt out in amendments 3 and 6, relate to the social implications of policy decisions and the environmental implications of policy decisions.

Our communities are increasingly understanding that the path we have come down has not delivered them all the benefits they should have realised and that we need policies which flavour economics with solid doses of ecologically sustainable development policies, environmental concern and, perhaps most of all, concern for our society and the communities that make it up. The purpose of environmental policies, of ecologically sustainable development policies and of economic and fiscal policies is to produce a society in which people are in harmony with each other and which has a good long‐term prospect of survival and maintenance, health and welfare.

That is a big speech for a small amendment, but this is the thinking and the purpose which lies behind those intentions. As with our previous amendments, amendment No. 6 is intended to add to the requirements and details of the intergenerational report—which is a marvellous term, Minister, that you have introduced in your bill; it is a first‐rate idea—by putting in place considerations of social and environmental implications of policy decisions. Not only do we think that our amendment will force the government to consider these aspects of any financial decisions; it will also include the cost‐benefit analysis—and you are aware that I am keen on those—of social and environmental considerations in government fiscal policy.

All too often people on our side of politics believe that economic decisions which apparently deliver short‐term gain in fact deliver long‐term cost. That is something we have always been concerned about. Quite frankly, it is something that governments in the modern era are beginning to understand more and more. To add a compliment back to your bill once again, the longer term perspective you are trying to introduce in this bill encourages that kind of analysis and thought in the matter.
We think our amendments, as moved together, add to the health and prospects that this bill should, in its best sense, offer us. I commend these amendments to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a little disagreement with Senator Murray; I think these are the most important amendments that he is bringing forward. The government is acting as if we are in a world in which only dollars count and in which policies can only be assessed according to the price tag that is put on them. But life is much wider than that; the values that people have for themselves, for their societies and for their children coming after them are much wider than that. As Senator Murray has indicated, a dollar led decision can be a catastrophe for the environment or for social order. We only have to look at the current smog blanket covering four or five nations to the north of us to see how fiscal policy—for example, the Suharto government's policy of allowing loggers wherever they liked into the Indonesian forests and encouraging the transmigration of millions of people—can lead to an environmental catastrophe, despite all the warnings.

SPEECH.PARA: That is not to say that this would not be a big job, but the departments are there and they ought to be brought into this assessment no less than the Treasury—departments of the environment and departments to do with the delivery of social justice. We ought not to have economics being master of our destiny; it ought to be very much the servant. Ecological considerations and social considerations ought to be at the forefront. We ought to be putting future generations at the top of our consideration because if we do not we become a failed generation; we become a generation that gets looked at by those people of the future as one which was self‐invested and short‐sighted and which forgot about them. We cannot afford to do that.

What Senator Murray's amendment does is move some way towards having parties contesting elections and being responsible for the environmental and social components of their policies. It is a sensible amendment and one has to worry about this nation when it has not been at the forefront of the government's consideration. Why has the government not moved this? How can you be honest about policies if you are not assessing the environmental and social outcomes of those policies? How can you be honest if your eyes are not wide open to the impact on future generations of policies we are making now as far as their environment and as far as their right to social order are concerned, let alone those people who are going to be immediately affected by government policy? Of course you cannot.

The problem here is that it is simple to talk dollars and it is complicated to talk environment and social wellbeing. But it is a default of the worst order to ignore the complexities and exemplify the simplicities. That is a very mistaken political outlook and it is one we should not countenance. If we were a more sane, level‐headed and caring society, and if we did have a long‐term view, we would have a charter in here which would make it incumbent upon us to look at the social and environmental ramifications of what we are doing in our policies, and we would have the government or the Democrats amending it to say, `We had better look at the dollars as well.' But that is not the way it is; the world is the other way round and we are going to pay increasing penalties because of it.

I am sure the government is going to get up and say, `Oh dear, this is just too difficult. This is too complex. We want to put our heads in the sand. If we can't do that, we at least want to wash our hands of our environmental and social responsibilities.' That is not good enough. This is an extremely important amendment. I commend Senator Murray and the Democrats for putting it before the Senate and I hope it will be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook, Sen Peter

TALK.START.PARA: —The Labor Party will not support this amendment. In saying that, it is not because we do not have sympathy for it. If I go to the text of this amendment, on page 7, what this amendment does is remove the words `financial effects on future generations' and replace those words with `financial and social effects on future generations and the implementation of the principles of ecologically sustainable development'. Let me just pause there before I go to the second part of amendment No. 6 that has been moved conjointly.

SPEECH.PARA: This appears under the heading `Principles of sound fiscal management' and would be an amendment to (e) under that list of various items. The problem I have with this is: how is Treasury going to assess objectively the social effects of particular policy principles that are laid down either by the government or by the opposition—now that the minor parties cannot be involved because of a decision that I voted against—and only those two parties? I cannot see how Treasury would be able to do that. Nor do I see automatically that Treasury is the appropriate agency to do it.

The second part of it is on ecologically sustainable development. I think there is a definitional problem with what ecologically sustainable development is. Even if there was an agreed definition, to make an assessment against particular policy principles is an exercise which I think Treasury is ill‐equipped to do. Even if the agency were not Treasury but the environmental agency, there may be a considerable difference as to whether or not what everyone thought was the definition of ecological sustainability was in fact being fairly applied. I know this sounds like a trite objection, but this has to work in practice after the writs have been issued in an election, when there is a relatively short amount of time.

In assessing the social impact of various economic measures, there is a huge amount of subjectivity involved, and the subjectivity brought to this issue will be brought by the assessing agency, Treasury. It will be the case, I suspect, that we will want to argue that the subjective principles on which they base their assessment are wrong, or that they do not fully comprehend the extent of the social implications that we would see as a political party. One of the reasons why I would oppose this is that it is in the cut and thrust of the last days of an election campaign when these reports are coming down. I must say that I think the government would have the same problem, but far less of a problem, because it is conservative and we are progressive. But in the cut and thrust of an election campaign, having a political party trying to debate whether Treasury is right or wrong with Treasury bureaucrats, does create a major political difficulty. It is for those reasons, not because I am out of sympathy with the objec tive but for the reasons of the practical application, that we oppose this. The same remarks can be made about clause 6.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an odd sort of statement that Senator Cook has made, inasmuch as when they were in government his party actually accepted the general principle of the kinds of accounts that we have been talking about, environmental and social accounts, that is, the full picture of what is happening within the wider economy. That is a principle that the previous government agreed to in relation to national accounts. They actually made statements that they would work towards including these things in national accounts. I understand that the Treasury already has an environmental economics unit associated with it. That is my understanding. If Senator Cook is suggesting that national accounts ought to be taken from Treasury and given to someone else, or that elements of national accounts ought to be given to someone else, that is a different matter altogether.

SPEECH.PARA: It is my understanding that Treasury are already looking at elements of how you include satellite accounting and how you include other elements that actually give you the whole picture of how the economy is going. So I am afraid that what Senator Cook has indicated does not hold water. As I say, Senator Faulkner, when the Labor Party were in government, indicated that they were prepared to move towards that kind of national accounting and that that might be a goal in the future. That was part of the various nice statements that have been made to the environment movement. The environment movement, I guess, had no choice but to believe that the Labor Party were serious when they made those statements.

So I just wonder whether Senator Cook has actually been talking to anyone else or has taken advice that in fact even Treasury, to my understanding, unless they have had those areas removed, has an environmental economic unit. I would like to think that they had some units which looked at equity considerations and social impacts, that is, in conjunction with national accounts, and whether or not there was an index on employment, on equity and on greenhouse. There are methods that have been looked at not only in Australia but actually all around the world.

There is a strong debate occurring within the OECD countries and there is a strong debate that is occurring within the European Union. There are copious tomes being written on how this can happen. There are countries which are doing this already. It is not impossible. What Senator Cook seems to suggest is that it is something that we have magically pulled out of thin air and has nothing at all to do with how national accounts can perhaps be run. I would strongly argue that this is my whole concern about how this bill has been put together: we are pretending that these things either don't exist or can't exist, or are somehow out of the purview of the way you present budgets and the way you present national accounts.

I would agree with Senator Brown that these two amendments, amendments Nos 3 and 6, are not just an addition to what is going on; they are in fact probably the most important element in what is being presented. Without them, it is in fact a charter of budget dishonesty, not a Charter of Budget Honesty, because it does not give the full picture. It pretends that it is giving the full picture but it is in fact giving a very narrow view of what national accounts are, a very narrow view of what even the economy consists of and the implications for the economy in the future.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald, Sen Sandy

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

I want to make some comments on the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation 1996‐97 annual report. As most senators would know, this organisation is funded by a compulsory four per cent levy on all wool growers of their gross returns. As the report outlines, the financial year 1996‐97 was a successful year for the organisation both in terms of the activities undertaken and the solid financial performance achieved. Its work was concentrated in the following areas: identifying strategic access and investment opportunities for Australian wool; researching and developing productivity improvements for land, labour and capital; encouraging investment and the take‐up of high quality Australian wool products; building on a competitive Australian export sector; protecting our natural resource base; and innovating with and marketing Australian wool.

Under the chairmanship of Mr Alec Morrison, the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation has continued to focus on the crucial task of building demand for wool by developing new wool and wool‐blend products, sourcing new markets, strengthening existing ones and improving processing techniques. In a very difficult climate, the organisation has remained committed to its task. It was originally set up in 1993 under the legislation of the previous minister, Senator Bob Collins, who is in the chamber, and since that time it has been funded, as I said before, by the compulsory four per cent levy on all wool growers.

This coming year is of vital importance to the future funding of the organisation because it will be reviewed by a voluntary vote taken by all wool taxpayers—they have to take up the option. That process is taking place now and they can then vote on the rate of future funding for the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation. Presently, as it is divided up, 3½ per cent of the four per cent goes to the promotion side of its activities and the other half a per cent goes to research in Australia and overseas. The total amount raised is about $100 million and the organisation, in conjunction with its sister organisation, the International Wool Secretariat, has a budget of around $150 billion and it has that extra finance through a number of strategic alliances with a number of users of the Woolmark and other related business programs.

The organisation has a big job to do because, of course, you can improve the price of a product in two ways—one is by promoting it properly and the other is by the producers taking a lower price than is sustainable for them. For most of the 1990s, producers of wool have certainly taken a lower price than was economically viable, but there is some hope and some prospects that the wool price is improving.

The other aspect is the promotion one and in that area the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation is exceptionally important. As I said, the future funding level of the organisation is being debated within industry circles at this time, and wool growers will have the chance to make some impact on the future funding arrangements for their organisation. The Wool Council of Australia has recommended, on behalf of the primary industry producer organisations in each state, that the funding remain the same—at four per cent—and I imagine that will be the decision taken by wool growers. But, whatever it is, all wool growers demand a very high degree of expertise, a very high degree of accountability and a very high degree of performance, and I am pleased to see that the management and directors of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation are providing a higher level of accountability and disclosure of their activities than ever before and I encourage them in that regard.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon, Sen David

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
The corporate plan 1996‐97 to 1998‐99 of the Civil Aviation Safety Authority of Australia has, in the beginning of the document, the authority's vision statement, which says:
With the aviation community, create an air safety environment which engenders public trust and confidence.

The sad truth is that at the moment the Civil Aviation Safety Authority is in a state of absolute crisis and the public are entitled to have absolutely no trust or confidence in the way in which air safety regulation is currently being administered in this country. It saddens me to make that statement.

It is a matter of fact that, indeed, had it not been for other matters relating to travel, the crisis that has enveloped the safety authority in the last few weeks would have been given far more public prominence in the press than it has had to this point in time, because it is, indeed, a crisis arising as a result of some extraordinary events that occurred at the last CASA board meeting in September this year, just a few weeks ago. Among those present at that board meeting were the four new appointments—that is, the appointments by the now departed Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp—led by the deputy chair and now acting chair of CASA, Mr Dick Smith.

A number of extraordinary events happened at that meeting. Justice Fisher, the then chair who has since resigned, asked those four board members whether it was true that they had given written notice to the minister—an unprecedented act in all of my time in politics—that, as a condition of their appointment, they would resign, if so requested, from those positions. Immediately after that confirmation and with no prior notice, those four board members moved peremptorily a vote of no confidence in the chief executive of CASA, Mr Leroy Keith, leading to his immediate resignation, which was immediately followed by the resignation of the chair of CASA and the other remaining members of the board. That motion of no confidence was passed four to three.

Who was Mr Leroy Keith? Who were these four recent appointments to head Australia's premier safety regulation authority getting rid of? Leroy Keith was an American citizen who was recruited from the United States to that position after gaining over 30 years of the most high‐level experience in senior positions in the Federal Aviation Authority in the United States in safety regulation, culminating in his position as a deputy president of McDonnell Douglas, one of the largest aviation companies in the world. When he came to us from the United States, he was the general manager of quality with McDonnell Douglas as well as being the vice‐president of the company.

He was an officer who enjoyed, unusually, the full confidence of not just the government and the minister, Mr Sharp, who expressed that confidence publicly only in April this year, but of the opposition as well. All senators who have attended the Senate estimates committees would know of Mr Leroy Keith's attendance at those committees. His competence was obvious to everyone. He enjoyed the confidence of industry in Australia. The minister, as I say, expressed that confidence earlier this year when he said in a press release headed, `Breakthrough in safety regulation':
The Director of Aviation Safety, Leroy Keith, is to be congratulated on the way he has provided direction for CASA in its work with the PAP—

That is the Program Advisory Panel. Mr Sharp had expressed very publicly on a number of occasions his confidence in Mr Keith, and so did we and so did the industry. The industry at the moment is in a state of total apprehension about Leroy Keith's sacking because no credible explanation for it has been provided whatever. The General Aviation Association of Australia have already written directly to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) expressing their concern, and I seek leave to table their letter.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time I have left I want to conclude with a most extraordinary statement issued by the now acting chair, Dick Smith, to the staff of CASA. I want to quote briefly from it. Explaining Leroy Keith's sacking, he says:

SPEECH.PARA: To give you an idea of what we expect, I asked fellow Board Member, Dr Paul Scully‐Power, to sum up the feelings of the Board.
He advised the Senior Management that the Board wants staff to know that the events of yesterday that led to the resignation of Mr Keith, and the events of today—
and I am quoting from Dick Smith's own statement—
would leave each and every one of them with a feeling of shock, apprehension and even fear relative to their personal future and that of the Authority.

That is in fact the case, and it is also the case within industry. I understand that the government is in a difficulty at the moment in that it does not have a new permanent Minister for Transport and Regional Development, but CASA is in crisis and the government is obliged to give some public explanation. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —That completes consideration of government documents. I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

There has been an agreed speakers' time for some speakers and when they rise to speak, if they do rise to speak, I will ask the clerks to set the clocks accordingly. But, Senator Schacht, you have your full 10 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a matter that has arisen in the South Australian election campaign. Earlier this week I made a speech on the adjournment about the so‐called `Dale Baker affair', in which Mr Baker had given evidence to the Anderson inquiry into his conflict of interest over a purchase of property while he was a minister for primary industry and forests in South Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I said in that statement that, according to advice I had received, the reason the Premier had refused to table the report—although he had promised to do so when it was first commissioned—was that Dale Baker had alleged that the President of the Liberal Party of South Australia, Mr Martin Cameron, was involved in undermining him, Dale Baker, and bringing to light the issue which led to his demise as a minister. At the time I made those remarks the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, interjected saying that it was a pretty weak allegation, et cetera.

I want to point out that on the following Tuesday morning, that is, yesterday, Mr Tim Anderson clearly confirmed in an interview on ABC radio in Adelaide that Dale Baker had named Mr Martin Cameron, the President of the Liberal Party, as being involved in a campaign to undermine him on this issue. That is on the record—on ABC radio. So what I raised on Monday night in this place was correct, despite the best efforts of Senator Hill to disparage my remarks.

I want to go on to another matter which the ubiquitous Mr Martin Cameron, the President of the Liberal Party of South Australia, has been involved in. All I have to do is read a press release issued yesterday, 30 September, publicly in South Australia by the Combined Shooters and Firearms Council of South Australia. I will read the press release. It says:

The Liberal Party has indicated it would be prepared to do a backflip on guns and allow people to keep pump action and semi automatic shotguns in return for the Combined Shooters & Firearms Council of SA urging its members to back off in their opposition to the Liberal Government.

The president of the council, Mr Michael Hudson, said that late last week a senior representative of the Council was invited to Liberal Party Headquarters by the Party's president, Mr. Martin Cameron, to discuss ways of placating the State's firearms owners and users.
"One of our senior members, Immediate Past President Mr. Rob Low, attended the meeting and, over a cup of coffee, Mr. Cameron sought ways of appeasing sporting shooters," Mr Hudson said.
He indicated that the Government might consider legislation to allow people to keep pump action and semi automatic shotguns.
However, Mr. Cameron was told that his offer was pointless, considering that most people have had their firearms `confiscated' and melted down.
The press release continues:

Mr. Cameron obviously realises that the liberal Government has made a serious error of judgement and will pay a dear price at the October 11 election when tens of thousands of firearms owners and users are expected to vote for the United Australia Party in protest.
My Council will not be bought off by Mr. Cameron's offer. It is too little too late.

On October 11, the Liberal Government will discover—to its dismay—that by meekly bowing to Prime Minister Howard, many of its back benchers will join thousands of other South Australians on the dole queue.

This offer—be it an official offer or an unofficial plea for help from Mr. Cameron—will not be accepted, and nor will it be followed up. The Liberals as, the old saying goes, will reap what they have sown.

At the bottom of the press release it tells you that for further information you can get interviews with Michael Hudson and it gives his telephone number. Again, that was issued by the Combined Shooters and Firearms Council of South Australia.

Isn't it extraordinary that we have on the day on which the 12‐month firearm amnesty ends, which was yesterday, the President of the Liberal Party of South Australia trying to undermine his own Prime Minister, his own Attorney-General and the unanimous decision—with the exception of one or two members in the lower house—of the federal parliament to ban firearms such as the pump action and semi‐automatic shotguns in Australia, which is what everybody in Australia, except that firearm lobby, wanted to happen after that awful tragedy at Port Arthur last year.

The Liberal Party in South Australia is now so desperate to get votes that it is willing to undermine its own policy and offer a possible legislative change in South Australia after the election to allow people to again have pump action and semi‐automatic shotguns. I find it astonishing that the President of the Liberal Party—who, I understand, holds a position on the National Council of the Liberal Party with four South Australian federal cabinet ministers—would be willing to call in this group and offer them a change in legislation that would fundamentally wreck the agreement which all state, federal and territory parliaments reached in the middle of last year.

Mr Howard claimed enormous credit for this agreement, and he was fully and unanimously supported by the Labor Party. We make no bones about our position. As a result, there was almost full unanimous support in the Australian parliament. The President of the Liberal Party, Mr Martin Cameron, is not an unknown public figure in South Australia. He is a former senator in this place and a former member of the Legislative Council for very many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are scraping the bottom of the barrel, Schachtie.
—I know that Senator Ferguson is interjecting over there because Mr Cameron is in the other faction.
—We are all one big happy family.
—Order! Address your remarks through the chair, Senator Schacht, and ignore the interjections. And Senator Ferguson will cease interjecting.

—We know that Senator Ferguson would make some remarks because Martin Cameron is in the other faction in South Australia. But I would ask Senator Ferguson, through you, Madam Deputy President: does he support overturning the federal and state legislation, which is what Mr Cameron is doing by putting this offer on the table to the shooters of South Australia?
—There is no truth in that whatsoever.

—This is a public press release which does not have parliamentary privilege and which was issued yesterday. Has Mr Cameron denied it? Has he issued a writ against Michael Hudson and against Mr Rob Low? That will be the test—whether a fair dinkum writ has been issued to take him to court. I suspect not.

SPEECH.PARA: I suspect Mr Cameron is scurrying away to avoid this because what he has done is despicable. He is undermining a policy that 90 per cent of Australians agree with. We certainly have on record the shooters of Australia, the gun owners, not agreeing with it. But, as they have said, to be offered this deal, after they have handed all their guns in and had them destroyed, that after the election they will be given legislation means that this Liberal Party in South Australia is beyond scraping the barrel to find a vote which undermines the Prime Minister and Attorney-General of this country. I look forward to them—that is, the Prime Minister and Attorney-General—telling Martin Cameron where to get off on making this sort of grubby offer, this behind‐the‐scenes deal to get a few votes to help save the Liberal Party in South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Ferguson, I believe you have a time arrangement with one of your colleagues for five minutes. We will set the clock accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Sen Alan

TALK.START.PARA: —I only want to speak briefly for five minutes, because I understand that later Senator Calvert will be tabling an important document—a report on the visit of a parliamentary friendship group to Ireland. At the outset, I want to thank Senator Calvert, who was chairman of the Australia‐Irish Parliamentary Friendship Group, and Senator McKiernan and his wife Jackie particularly for their involvement in the preparation of this trip.

SPEECH.PARA: This trip took a long time to prepare, and we had the cooperation of the Irish Embassy; the Irish Ambassador, Richard O'Brien; together with the Irish parliament, which hosted us for one week while we were there. That made this an enjoyable trip not only because of the make‐up of the people of this bi‐partisan delegation but also because of the important information that was gained by us in Ireland, which has been regarded by many people in Europe today as Europe's modern miracle, particularly in an economic sense. So I want to particularly thank those people involved in the preparation of this trip. It was done over a long period and done with excellence. I would particularly like to thank Senator Calvert and Senator McKiernan for their roles in preparing for this trip.

I am not going to speak a lot about the trip because there are a lot of other speakers who will be commenting on the aspects of the trip. The important aspect was us getting the opportunity to have a first‐hand look at their economy, how they have managed to turn their economy around in such a short time and how they are now one of the leading lights of Europe. There were many things that were gained on this trip in what was a hectic program which will be beneficial for a long time to all of those that went. I say it was beneficial because, as a group of backbenchers, I think there can sometimes be more importance placed on backbenchers going away and seeing the sorts of things that happen, because backbenchers from both parties, after all, do have input at committee level on the sorts of policies that we want to have in the future.

I want to particularly make comments on some comments that were made on the return of this delegation from Ireland, particularly on the John Laws Show on 15 September. I have never listened to John Laws, and after reading a transcript of his program that morning, I doubt if I will ever listen to John Laws. I thought some of the remarks he made about members of our delegation were quite outrageous.

As a member of the Liberal Party, I take exception to some remarks that were made about some colleagues and friends who went on that trip, particularly those from the Labor Party. I will read into Hansard the end of the interview conducted by John Laws where he was trying to chase around every member of parliament who had travelled overseas during the winter break. This is how he concludes his interview:
Here's another one. One of the handmaidens tried the same line and I said I'd let you know how we went.
This is him trying to track down members of parliament. He continued:

This is what one said. This is amusing. Ted Grace, you know the famous Ted Grace? Oh, Prime Ministerial material, Ted! Ted Grace, one of the MPs who went to Ireland, he said: There's always benefit to Australia when politicians go overseas'.
Then John Laws laughs and says:
Yeah, you're right, Ted. Quite right. Trouble is you come back.

I think that is the most outrageous attack on a member of parliament going away on a parliamentary delegation. He was a well‐respected member of parliament who served in the other place for a considerable length of time. For somebody as ignorant of the affairs of this delegation as John Laws obviously was to make that sort of statement about a parlia mentary colleague, where the person has absolutely no right of reply, even though that colleague is not from my party, having travelled with him for a week and working with him on other committees, is outrageous. He also said of former Senator Bruce Childs:

. . . you've never heard of these people, of course you haven't because they do bugger all except take your money and travel overseas. Senator Bruce Childs. Did you know we had a Senator called Bruce Childs? He retired from Parliament on September 10th, which makes you wonder why he went on a trip to North and South America when he was leaving the job a few weeks later.

Here is a former senator who was held in the highest regard in this place. You do not have to be a member of parliament who is read in the papers every day of the week or sensationalised by people like John Laws to make a significant contribution to this parliament and to this place.

Some of the best contributions I have seen have been from those people who quietly work away doing their job, as Senator Childs did here for some 16 or 17 years. To see him spoken about by someone like John Laws on a radio program makes me quite sure that I will never listen to John Laws because I think those sorts of ill-informed and totally ignorant comments have no place on the airwaves of Australia. If he wants to make those sorts of remarks, let him do some proper research and find out what contribution these people have made to the parliament.
I know my time is up. The trip to Ireland was most worthwhile and I will remember it for a long time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to endorse the comments made by my colleague Senator Ferguson. I would like to thank, in particular, Senator McKiernan, Senator Calvert and Senator McKiernan's wife, Jackie, for organising the trip. I particularly endorse what Senator Ferguson said about comments on the John Laws Show . It was a very worthwhile trip. It was a great group and we got on well together. The Irish parliament turned on a great week for us.

BREAK.PARA: Tonight I wanted to use the short time available to comment on the economic growth of Ireland and its industry policy. I think there has been some misinterpretation here in Australia about what we should be doing with regard to attracting investment and trying to copy Ireland.

I will start with some background. Ireland has had fantastic economic growth for the last three years—seven and eight per cent real growth per year. Going back to 1996, they were a cot case. IMF was about to come in, government debt was 123 per cent of GDP, GDP incomes per capita were 20 per cent below OECD average and in 10 years they have lifted themselves up to be equal to the OECD average. It is just a fantastic effort.

There has been enormous investment in Ireland. People have interpreted that this investment has basically been driven by tax concessions. Sure, Ireland started off in 1986 offering tax concessions to businesses to invest there, with a 10 per cent corporate tax rate. But that applied to the manufacturing industry. They had no manufacturing industry, so it was easy for them to do that. Some years later they widened the advantage and it also applied to services, but only for services that were exported out of Ireland. For instance, if a bank invested in Ireland, they had to ring‐fence their export activity from their internal activity—a 36 per cent tax rate on internal activity and 10 per cent on external activity.

Some of the government people we spoke to emphasised that a lot of investment was not really tax driven. I visited the National Irish Bank because I knew they had spoken to a lot of businesses. I also visited Hewlett-Packard personally. The managers of the bank and the managers of Hewlett-Packard stressed that the main reason they invested in Ireland was, first of all, because it was an easy entry into Europe; the second reason was good people and a good education system. They said that good people were available in Ireland. With regard to education, the emphasis in Ireland is on the three Rs. The common comment from the investors who invested there was, `Well, Senator, would you believe they still teach grammar here', which the business people found very attractive. The third priority was a tax incentive, but it was in that order and not the other way around.

I think the implication for us here in Australia is that it is impossible for us to go chasing Singapore and Ireland with 10 per cent corporate tax rates versus the 36 per cent corporate tax rates. I do not think that will work. What is more important is for us to sell our advantages as part of the Asia-Pacific region, because we have good people here. We have to emphasise education and training of our people and put more emphasis on training people in the IT industries, for instance, which have been very successful in Ireland. There is a huge increase in demand for people with IT skills across the economic commerce area worldwide. We can do that in Australia. We are really competitive in that area and we should do more about that.

Whilst we were in Ireland, the Prime Minister announced an additional 5,000 tertiary places that very week. He said, `After conferring with industry, I'm announcing 5,000 additional places that the government is going to support—2,000 in the electronics area, 2,000 in computer programming and 1,000 for language skills for core centres.' They identified those needs between government and industry. That is what they were investing in—education and the skills base.

It was a very worthwhile trip to Ireland. I think there were great messages from that visit which have great relevance to industry policy here for Australia. I am delighted that I was part of the group. It was very worthwhile.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak about the Senate estimates committee hearing that is being held today, sitting concurrently with the sitting of the Senate, in relation to the South Pacific Cruise Lines fiasco that has been presided over by Senator Vanstone, the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs.

SPEECH.PARA: What we have seen today is the most extraordinary situation of the government deliberately hindering a Senate estimates committee hearing. Of course, it has had good reason to do so: it wants to deliberately cover up Senator Vanstone's handling of the $2.7 million South Pacific Cruise Lines fiasco.

Just a few moments ago we heard that, although Senator Vanstone first knew about these problems on 11 and 12 June, she did not raise the issue with her departmental secretary, Mr Sedgwick, until late August. It is absolutely extraordinary. No wonder officers at the Senate estimates committee today have been so embarrassed.

We have had a situation where an order of the Senate allowed the DEET estimates committee to sit today to deal with the specific matter of the South Pacific Cruise Lines issue. It was a clear order of the Senate. So apparently this is something that the government could not cope with and they had to come up with a political strategy to deal with it. But what they came up with was extraordinary.

It was this: the government members of the committee flouted the standing orders of the Senate and flouted the terms of reference of the committee, which was to examine Minister Vanstone's cruise ship fiasco, in order to attempt to protect their minister, Senator Vanstone. I suppose it is an honourable enough motive. After all, Senator Vanstone needs all the help she can get. They resorted to the most extraordinary diversionary and filibustering tactics to prevent facts emerging.

Senator Vanstone was away all last week and is going to go off again for another couple of weeks, so it is very difficult for us then to get parliamentary scrutiny of this scandal, this fiasco, that Senator Vanstone is both responsible for and has presided over. The excuse that government members of the committee used to try to soak up at least half the time of the Senate estimates committee was most extraordinary. They tried to find a benchmark for Labor's Working Nation program against which the South Pacific Cruise Lines fiasco could be judged. That was the excuse they were using. They could not do that, of course, but that was a very blatant, very transparent attempt to obstruct parlia mentary scrutiny of a financial disaster that was all Minister Vanstone's own work.

So we had the embarrassing spectacle of government senators asking dorothy dix questions to Minister Vanstone, but even more importantly to DEETYA officers who brought along their prepared briefs to deal with a whole range of labour market programs and Working Nation programs, matters that they tried to trawl through which went back six or seven years.

We had the embarrassment of an officer at the table with a formal brief on a number of successful Labor government programs. What an extraordinary coincidence! What luck it was that this officer of the Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs was able to bring the brief and there was a whole series of nicely typed out and prepared dorothy dix questions for the lackeys that the government senators on the committee asked ad nauseam at the committee.

The truth of the matter is that the Liberal committee members could not find one other example of an appalling failure of process such as that which Senator Vanstone was involved in. There is nothing comparable to the fiasco that she has presided over. There is nothing comparable to the massive mismanagement of the minister's own responsibilities, nothing comparable to the cover-up that occurred in the minister's office and amongst members of her staff.

It said it all when we were able to establish that on 11 or 12 June Senator Vanstone knew about this issue but did not bother even raising it in any way—formal or informal—with the head of her department, the secretary of DEETYA, Mr Sedgwick, until well over two months later, in late August. That says it all about Senator Vanstone's administration of her own portfolio.

Today we really have learnt how a Liberal government minister runs her own office. We have heard that briefs might go to the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Dr Kemp, and a dropped copy goes to Senator Vanstone. But Senator Vanstone under no circumstances would sign off the brief herself; she would have a DLO sign off the brief. She would not bother reading it.

We have letters from coalition members of parliament, like Mr Slipper and Mr Jull, to Senator Vanstone. Of course, she does not actually look at the letters that come to her and does not respond to them. It takes her months and months to respond to them. If I were Mr Slipper or Mr Jull, I would object most strongly to this.

There is a brief to Senator Vanstone herself on Mr Jull's correspondence which raises a range of serious issues related to the South Pacific Cruise Lines fiasco. That is completely unsigned. That is a brief that went to Minister Vanstone on 16 May. She has not signed that at all. So we have a situation where many of these briefs in Dr Kemp's and Minister Vanstone's office do not appear to be date stamped as they are received. It is a shemozzle in Minister Vanstone's office. No wonder she takes the cake as the most incompetent of the Liberal government ministers—which is saying something in a government that is reeling.

I do not think there is any doubt; you have only to read the editorials, the newspapers and listen to members of her own party bag her mercilessly when you get the opportunity to have a private conversation. It is great to hear it, really. Even members of the government parties know that Minister Vanstone is not up to it. It is all right—I will not name them. They are all very relieved over there, aren't they? I can see a few grins. It is all right, I am not going to name anyone. You are all in the clear.

But let us face it, it has been shown today that Minister Vanstone is either bone lazy, completely incompetent or utterly stupid. There is no other excuse for what has occurred in relation to this matter. I have to say that it has done those Liberal senators who went to that meeting today—a hearing held as a result of a clear direction and order of the Senate—no credit to try to bring up every possible extraneous issue under the sun and waste hour after hour of the Senate's time. It is a pathetic tactic; it has been exposed in the media and, as a result, Senator Vanstone is even more condemned now for the administration of her own portfolio.

We are entitled to seek explanations and answers for this massive mismanagement of nearly $3 million. We will not be put off by this miserable, low life political tactic; we will get to the heart of it. At the end of the day, Senator Vanstone will lose her responsibilities, as she deserves to. As I said, she is bone lazy, incompetent or stupid. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table a report on the visit to Ireland by members of the Australia‐Ireland Parliamentary Friendship Group.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Chairman of this group in the Parliament of Australia, I would like to speak briefly to the report that has just been tabled; and I know that Senator Gibson has already spoken of it. We had the pleasure of accepting a kind invitation from the former Speaker of the Irish parliament, Sean Tracey.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to give sincere thanks to my secretary, Senator Jim McKiernan, for his efforts; His Excellency Richard O'Brien, Ireland's Ambassador to Australia; Mr Eoin Faherty, who organised the program; Mr Seamus Pattison, the present Speaker; Senator Liam Cosgrove, Cathaoirleach, the President of the Senate; His Excellency Eddy Stevens, Australia's Ambassador to Ireland. I give special thanks to the deputy leader of the delegation, Mr Ted Grace. As people who read tabloid newspapers would know, I was accompanied by Senator Grant Chapman, Senator Kay Denman, Mr Richard Evans, Senator Alan Ferguson, Mr Laurie Ferguson, Senator Michael Forshaw, Senator Brian Gibson and Senator Julian McGauran.

At the outset, I would like to say that, by any standard, this delegation learned a lot. I believe we gave a lot and that the visit was of great benefit not only to all of us but to the Australian parliament. Whilst this particular friendship group is smaller than the Australia‐United States Parliamentary Friendship Group and the Australia‐United Kingdom Parlia mentary Friendship group, we are particularly active and we have hosted in Australia not only delegations but also visits by artists and authors, one of whom was Tim Pat Coogan who wrote Michael Collins: A biography. We do pride ourselves as a group. As you would know, Madam Deputy President, 40 per cent of Australian people claim some Irish background, so it is important that we keep those links with our friends in Ireland.

As a group we were very privileged to be able to meet quite a wide selection of senior politicians very soon after the election of the new government. Amongst them were the Deputy Prime Minister, Mary Harney, leader of the Progressive Democrats Party; the former Minister for Finance and the Deputy Leader of the Labour Party, Mr Ruairi Quinn; the Minister for State and Foreign Affairs, Liz O'Donnell; and the Deputy Leader of Fine Gael, Ms Nora Owen. We also met other politicians at different events. One of the most important occasions, of course, was meeting the President of Ireland, Mary Robinson, who is leaving the presidency to take up a position with the United Nations. We were able to pass on our best wishes on behalf of the Australian government on that very important task.

One of the things that our delegation was very interested in was the fact that the taxpayers of Australia, through our government and through the former government, are supplying something like £3 million for the International Fund for Ireland. I know that my colleague Senator McKiernan, if he had the opportunity, would like to speak on this tonight. Unfortunately, he will not be able to do so, but I am looking forward to hearing him speak at a future time.

The International Fund for Ireland plays a very important part in the peace process that is unfolding in Ireland and, in a small way, Australia plays a part in that. I know that the delegation was most impressed with the reception we received from those people. They were genuinely appreciative of the efforts of the Australian government and the Australian people even though, in numerical terms, the amount of money is not all that much. The results that are being achieved with this money, particularly at Dundalk and Carlingford, were very gratifying to us.

Comment was made in the report about the opportunity we were given to have one‐on‐one discussions about the peace process with some of the people involved. It is only by doing those sorts of things that you can really get a feel for what is happening over there. It is pleasing to note that, since our return, there seem to be some good signs of peace being achieved permanently in that troubled area. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman, Sen Grant

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to address some remarks this evening to the report which has just been tabled by my colleague Senator Calvert, the Chairman of the Australia‐Ireland Parliamentary Friendship Group, in relation to the visit to Ireland by the delegation of the friendship group.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing I want to say is that a perusal of the report demonstrates the comprehensive nature of the program which was arranged for us by the parliament of Ireland. It certainly gives the lie to any claim or perception that such visits are mere junkets, and I join with the earlier remarks of Senator Ferguson, in particular, in condemning the remarks of John Laws in relation to this particular visit and also in relation to other colleagues of ours.

He was not the only one who seemed to take umbrage at this particular visit of a delegation to Ireland. There was Matthew Horan and other print journalists who similarly made quite unjustified and unsubstantiated allegations about the nature of this visit. I urge them to digest the details of this report in the hope that they might change their views, although I suppose it is very difficult to change the views of journalists of that nature.

It is also worth mentioning that, following our visit, the Australian ambassador sent a cable to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade in which he highlighted the value of this particular visit in terms of the way in which it made a very positive contribution towards fostering Australia‐Ireland relations. So that was the independent assessment of Australia's ambassador to Ireland, that this was an important and worthwhile visit.

There are some lessons for Australia in what has been achieved in Ireland and Senator Gibson earlier this evening detailed the economic miracle that has occurred in Ireland over the last 10 years. I believe that principal among the lessons that can be learnt from the economic achievement of Ireland is what can be achieved if a government and a nation have, firstly, the political will and, secondly, the unity of purpose to set out a goal and then march towards it. Certainly the turnaround in the economy of Ireland that has been achieved over the past decade is a remarkable achievement.

Although 10 years ago the Irish economy was starting from a much lower base than other European Union countries, over that 10‐year period it has consistently outstripped the rest of the European Union as far as economic growth is concerned—year by year over the decade—albeit, of course, with some funding assistance from the European Community. Nevertheless, the policies that have been put in place have been the major factors contributing to that strong economic growth.

Undoubtedly, the policies that have been applied in Ireland are not necessarily directly transferable to the Australian situation, but there is much that can be learnt from them. Among the most important of those policy prescriptions was the strong emphasis placed by the Irish government, with the support of the opposition, other community leaders, indeed, the Irish community at large, on getting the government budget back into balance and paying off government debt. That was one of the main goals that was set forth in the program of economic recovery which has led to this strong economic growth.
Another factor was the importance placed on quality of education—and Senator Gibson has referred to this in some detail—particularly the basic skills being inculcated through the education system.

Taxation reform was a significant factor and I think that also indicates the incentive that lower tax rates can provide, particularly for investment and for the expansion of economic activity within a country. That is certainly a lesson that Australia can learn.

Lower taxation does not necessarily mean a loss of revenue and reduced government services, because the expanded economic activity that occurs as a result of the incentive of lower taxation, in itself, undergirds the revenue base. Although in individual terms you might have lower tax rates applying, because of the tremendous expansion in economic activity as a result of investment and greater employment being generated, the actual revenue base can be protected, thereby providing the resources for the maintenance of government services. So these are all important lessons that Australia can learn from Ireland. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —In the very short time that is available in this debate, I want to do three things. I want to thank the colleagues who spoke before me for the kind words to me and my wife. It was a pleasure travelling with each and every one of them, and their spouses.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not, in the short time available, seek to justify this particular delegation to Ireland, but let me make mention of the fact that I previously went with a delegation to Ireland which was led by Ron Edwards, then Deputy Speaker in the House of Representatives. We presented as gifts to the hosts of the various functions that we attended bottles of Australian wine. On the occasion of this recent visit, the Tanaiste—the Deputy Prime Minister—of Ireland made the remark that only very recently had Australia displaced Italy as the source country of the second largest amount of wine going into Ireland. So some things can be done in delegations such as this one.

In reading the report—a very brief snapshot of the visit—people will note that it was a very hectic visit, the first day of which lasted 15 hours, so we were not all the time sampling the products of that country. We made only one recommendation. We could have made many others—we could have talked about the taxation system and the economic system. We consciously made the decision that it would be better to progress these matters within our own parties, within the different forums each of us, as backbenchers, is involved with.

The one recommendation, which we all agreed upon, was something that is very dear to my heart, and something which should be dear to the hearts of Australian taxpayers. That is the matter of the expenditure of Australian taxpayers' money in Ireland. Colleagues previously have made mention of the contribution that the International Fund for Ireland is making to the peace process in Ireland. It is heartening to note that that peace process is continuing, and hopefully it will reach a resolution in the near future. I will continue my remarks at a later time.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Minister for Health and Family Services: Media Monitoring Services

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 28 July 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What was the total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etcetera provided to the Minister's office in the 1996‐97 financial year.
(2) Which agency or agencies provided these services.
(3) What was the total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etcetera, provided to the department and its agencies in the 1996‐97 financial year.
(4) Which agency or agencies provided these services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etc, provided to the Minister's office in the 1996‐97 financial year was $44,301.31. This compares with $111,689.60 for Dr Lawrence in the 1994‐95 financial year.
(2) These services were primarily provided by Croll Communications, Media Monitors and Rehame.

(3) The total cost of media monitoring services, including press clippings, electronic media transcripts etc, provided to the department and its agencies in the 1996‐97 financial year was $262,688.64. This compares with $322,604.92 for Dr Lawrence in the 1994‐95 financial year.

(4) These services were primarily provided by Croll Communications and Media Monitors. Other providers included Rehame, Media Search Corporation Ltd (NZ), Imedia Press Clipping Service, Warburton Media Monitoring Service and News Research.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 18 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) What were the top 200 defence export approvals by value in the 1996‐97 financial year; and (b) what are those for the 1997‐98 financial year which may already be approved or are awaiting approval.
(2) Which companies were involved in each of these contracts.
(3) To which countries did each of these approvals refer.
(4) What was the nature of the equipment involved in each contract.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —In accordance with advice to the Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel the following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1)—(4) Details are shown in the following tables. The export approvals cover non‐military lethal goods such as non‐military firearms and ammunition, as well as commercial explosives. The approvals include temporary exports for demonstration and evaluation purposes; returns to manufacturers for warranty and other repairs; and returns to owners of goods that have been repaired or returned after trials in Australia.
The names of the exporters are not released due to the Commercial‐in‐Confidence nature of the information.

For the financial year 1997/98 to 26 August 1997, there have been only 170 approvals for defence and related goods. A cut‐off value of $22,000 has been assigned to approvals for 1997/98 which is similar to that of 1996/97. Below this value, the approvals are not significant and mainly consist of non‐military firearms. Those `awaiting approval' have not been included as each application is considered on a case‐by‐case basis and approval should not be assumed.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 27 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) (a) What contracts has the department, or agencies of the department, provided to KPMG Peat Marwick since 3 March 1996; and (b) what has been the total cost of these contracts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

‐ assisting with assessment of base funding requirements for existing community controlled Aboriginal health and substance abuse services;

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 27 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (a) What contracts has the department, or agencies of the department, provided to KPMG Peat Marwick since 3 March 1996; and (b) what has been the total cost of these contracts.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ellison, Sen Chris
