QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 29 August 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the Minister received any representations on the proposed merger of the Bunbury campus of Edith Cowan University and the Murdoch University.
(2) Does the Minister support the proposed merger.
(3) What steps has the Minister taken, if any, to facilitate the merger.
(4) Can the Minister advise of any other progress that has been made towards the merger.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I have received numerous representations, on behalf of several organisations, concerning the transfer of the Bunbury campus of Edith Cowan University to Murdoch University. These have been both for and against the merger.

(2) As higher education institutions are autonomous bodies set up under State legislation, the decision on the future responsibility for the Bunbury campus ultimately rests with the Western Australian Government and the institutions concerned. As you may be aware, discussions are taking place between officials of my Department and the Western Australian Office of Higher Education on the development of a strategic plan for the provision of higher education in the State. The future of the Bunbury campus should be addressed within this context. The Commonwealth's position is that the strategic plan must have the support of all the parties involved.

(3) Officials of my Department and the Western Australian Office of Higher Education agreed at a June meeting of the Commonwealth and State Joint Planning Committee (JPC) that the Commonwealth would advise Murdoch University of the level of funding that would be available to the Bunbury campus should the transfer proceed. The purpose of this communication was to enable Murdoch University to be in a position to confirm its interest in the transfer so the Commonwealth could then ascertain Edith Cowan University's position on the transfer. My Department initially wrote to the Vice‐Chancellor of Murdoch University in July to indicate a proposed level of funding and has been clarifying the basis of the funding adjustments associated with any transfer of the campus in response to questions raised by Murdoch University.

(4) The new Vice‐Chancellor of Edith Cowan University, Professor Millicent Poole, has recently indicated her opposition to the transfer of the Bunbury campus. It is my view that the Commonwealth is not in a position to pursue the transfer of the Bunbury campus to Murdoch University if it does not have the approval of ECU and in the absence of a State strategic plan agreed to by all Universities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 3 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does all imported food have to meet standards set by the Australian Food Standards Code (AFSC).
(2) Is Standard C1 the relevant standard for cooked pig meat and cooked chicken meat.
(3) Does this standard provide microbiological specifications for cooked chicken and pig meat; if so, where in the standard are the specifications covering these foods.

(4) With reference to section 3(2) of the Imported food Control Act, which states that food poses a risk to human health if it contains pathogenic micro‐organisms or their toxins, and given that the Australian New Zealand Food Authority (ANZFA) advised a Senate committee in 1996 that this section of the Act enables a standard to be imposed on imported food which may be in addition to that required by the Food Standard Code.

Has ANZFA recommended to the Australian Quarantine and Inspection service (AQIS) that standards should be applied to both chicken and pigmeat, in addition to those required by the AFSC, to ensure that any potential for public health problems from pathogenic micro‐organisms or their toxins is removed; if so, was this recommendation made because of the way these products are manufactured, handled, transported and packaged; if not, can ANZFA identify the information it relied on to satisfy itself that the manufacturing, handling, transportation and packaging of these products will be safe.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) Standard C1 is one of the relevant standards. The other standards are:Standard A1—Labelling and Advertising; Standard A2—Date marking of Packed Food; Standard A12—Metals and Contaminants in Food; Standard A14—Maximum Residue Limits; Standard S2—Frozen Pre‐cooked Foods.

(3) No. If the cooked pig meat and cooked chicken meat are frozen there are relevant microbiological specifications in Standard S2. If they are chilled there are no relevant microbiological specifications in the Food Standards Code. However, all food for sale in Australia must comply with the general provisions of the various Food Acts that require food to be fit for human consumption.

(4) ANZFA is in the process of finalising its recommendation to AQIS which will require imported cooked pig meat and cooked chicken meat to comply with the relevant specifications in Standard S2 if it is frozen and a similar set of microbiological specifications if it is chilled. The requirements for chilled product are in addition to those required in the Food Standards code and are not applied to domestic product but are considered necessary because the history of the handling, transportation and packaging of these imported products will not be known.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 4 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: With reference to evidence provided to the Employment, Education and Training References Committee during the inquiry into the status of teachers, in which a witness from the South‐Western Region of Sydney Principals Conference gave evidence that their three closest universities, the Universities of Western Sydney, Wollongong and New South Wales, are all changing their profiles to downgrade teacher education:

(1) What would an examination of the latest 1996‐97 and previous 1995‐96 university profiles across Australia show about the commitment by individual institutions to the provision of teacher education.

(2) Can a table be provided to show by way of comparison the financial, student enrolment and staff establishment of teacher education courses within the nation's universities over the period of the past two profile reports.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The attached table, drawn from my Department's records and published statistics (Selected higher education staff statistics 1995 and 1996, DEETYA) demonstrates that nationwide fluctuations in education load and staffing have been small between 1995 and 1997 (staffing figures are not yet available for 1997). It is clear from the figures that the sector's commitment to teacher education is firm. Variation within individual universities' education load and staff numbers is a matter of internal planning priorities and is not dictated by the Government.

(2) The attached table provides the information requested: information on financial allocation to teacher education by universities is a matter of internal budgeting and is not available to Government.
1 Source: 1997‐1999 and 1998‐2000 Educational Profile Submissions
2 Source: Selected Higher Education Staff Statistics, 1995 and 1996—DEETYA
EFTSU Equivalent Full‐time Student Unit
FTE/FFTE: Full‐time Equivalence/Fractional Full‐Time Equivalence.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business: Salary Packaging

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business, upon notice, on 4 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department negotiated or indicated a willingness to negotiate salary packaging for its employees.
(2) Has the department informed any staff of its intention to offer salary packaging schemes to its employees.
(3) Can a copy be provided of the communication in (2), as well as information regarding: (a) when it took place; and (b) what developments have occurred regarding implementation of salary packaging.
(4) Can details be provided of any salary packaging arrangements which have been made available to employees of the department.
(5) Can details be provided of the number of salary packaging arrangements which have been entered into by employees.

(6) (a) Are salary packaging arrangements being offered to all employees or only selected employees; (b) if selected employees, what class of emp loyee is being offered salary packaging; and (c) what are the salary ranges applicable to these employees.
(7) What percentage of an employee's total salary is allowed to be taken as non‐salary benefits.
(8) Please list the options or items that are allowed to be salary packaged under any department arrangement.
(9) Do any of the arrangements offered benefit from an employer exemption from fringe benefits tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.
(3) The intention was in the form of clauses in a draft proposal for an Agency Agreement (certified agreement) and draft Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs).

(a) The draft proposal for an Agency Agreement was first circulated to staff as a basis for discussion on 4 July 1997 and the draft AWA was first circulated to senior managers as a basis for discussion on 27 August 1997.
(b) A company has been engaged for administration of the process for the department and its employees.
(4) Details are currently being developed. The Agency Agreement and Australian Workplace Agreements are currently being negotiated.
(5) No arrangements have been entered into by employees at this stage.
(6) (a) All employees.
(b) NA.
(c) NA.
(7) 50% has been proposed.
(8) The items are currently being determined.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Health and Family Services: Salary Packaging

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, upon notice, on 4 September 1997:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has the department negotiated or indicated a willingness to negotiate salary packaging for its employees.
(2) Has the department informed any staff of its intention to offer salary packaging schemes to its employees.
(3) Can a copy be provided of the communication in (2), as well as information regarding: (a) when it took place; and (b) what developments have occurred regarding implementation of salary packaging.
(4) Can details be provided of any salary packaging arrangements which have been made available to employees of the department.
(5) Can details be provided of the number of salary packaging arrangements which have been entered into by employees.

(6) (a) Are salary packaging arrangements being offered to all employees or only selected employees: (b) if selected employees, what class of employee is being offered salary packaging; and (c) what are the salary ranges applicable to these employees.
(7) What percentage of an employee's total salary is allowed to be taken as non‐salary benefits.
(8) Please list the options or items that are allowed to be salary packaged under any department arrangement.
(9) Do any of the arrangements offered benefit from an employer exemption from fringe benefits tax.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health and Family Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The department has indicated a willingness to negotiate salary packaging for its employees.

(2) Salary packaging was discussed with focus groups on the development of Australian Workplace Agreements for SES Officers. It has also been raised briefly in focus groups on the development of a certified agreement for other staff. In an information bulletin distributed to all staff on 11 September 1997 the department indicated that it has "the option of offering salary packaging to all staff".

(3) (a) A preliminary discussion paper on salary packaging was distributed to SES Officers invited to attend focus group sessions in July and August. A copy of this is at Attachment A. The all staff information bulletin, which was distributed on 11 September is at Attachment B.
(b) The department is currently working with a consulting firm to develop detailed options and information packages for staff on the implications of salary packaging.
(4) The department has not yet finalised any arrangements for salary packaging.
(5) Nil.
(6) The department has not yet made a final decision on this matter, but has kept open the option of offering salary packaging to all employees.
(7) The department has not made a final decision on this matter.
(8) The department has not made a final decision on this matter.
ATTACHMENT A
SALARY PACKAGING
BACKGROUND
Composition of Packages
Salary packages are generally made up of:
. cash benefits, including salary and allowances;
. non‐cash benefits, including items which are subject to salary sacrifice;
. superannuation; and

. employment costs, which generally covers FBT, leave loadings, administration costs, superannuation guarantee and the new superannuation tax, but some employers may also include payroll tax and workers compensation. (For executives, some employers have also included the costs of offices and administrative support as a way of encouraging economies in these areas.)
Employee's Perspective

From the employee's perspective, to see any benefit in salary packaging, the value of the salary package received must be equal to or greater than the equivalent gross salary that would have been received. However, the past advantages of salary packaging have been greatly eroded through the extension of FBT arrangements to cover most items which are salary sacrificed. For most benefits, the amount of FBT included in the package is equal to the top marginal tax rate. Consequently, there is no monetary advantage in most salary sacrifice. People paying less than the top marginal income tax rate would actually be worse off in most circumstances.

One area where there may be a significant advantage is in the provision of a car, as some costs receive a concessional tax treatment. In addition, some other benefits are exempt from FBT. Other benefits may be included in remuneration packages without attracting FBT as they are subject to the otherwise deductible rule. This applies if an employee would have received a once only income tax deduction had the employee been responsible for providing the benefit. Then the employer may reduce the taxable value by that amount. The only advantage to employees is in terms of a stream of income throughout the year rather than a later lump sum tax refund. Benefits included in these categories are at Appendix 1. Even if there is no financial advantage, some employees may prefer to salary sacrifice as this arrangement is more convenient through automatic bill paying through the salary system. This could apply particularly to people working long hours, or who travel frequently.

Some financial advantage may be gained through the effect of the Medicare Levy and not being liable for other costs, such as the new Superannuation Tax, although the position on whether it is possible to salary sacrifice to specifically avoid this tax is not clear. Our latest advice is that if there are any `loopholes' associated with reducing this tax liability through salary sacrifice, they will soon be closed. If salary is sacrificed it may reduce salary for superannuation purposes. In this case a financial disadvantage may result later in life when pensions come into play.
Employer's Perspective

From the employer's perspective the cost of providing a salary package should not exceed the net cost of providing an equivalent gross salary. In the determination of a net cost of providing a fringe benefit to individual staff, the employer must consider the actual cost of the benefit, a range of tax issues, any additional administrative costs including the maintenance of records and FBT returns, and any on‐costs including superannuation guarantee charge and superannuation surcharge.

Administration costs can be substantial, particularly for items such as managing a car fleet and determining the best tax treatment of these (which can vary according to the number of kilometres driven). The Department of Industrial Relations has also noted that these costs need to be taken into account when determining the cost of packages. However, employer's may still wish to offer salary packaging to attract suitable employees.
ISSUES
Range of Benefits Commonly Available

Appendix 2 provides a brief analysis of items which are generally offered to employees in terms of remuneration packaging. The most common components are employer superannuation contributions, salary sacrifice superannuation contributions, reward payments, cars, professional association membership and self education expenses. The range of major items does not vary significantly from those already provided in the APS to SES Officers.

It may be appropriate not to make any significant changes to current arrangements for the SES given the potential for significant administrative costs and the fact that most other organisations only provide a limited range of benefits to their employees. If other items are included then the administrative costs should probably also be deducted from the package.
Superannuation

Superannuation could be a problem area in the context of salary sacrificing. This is because the average value of CSS benefits is significantly greater than that of average PSS benefits. The latest DoF advice is that the long term costs, as at 30 June 1996, are 18.9% for CSS and 10.1% for PSS.

If we adopted the common practice of providing two people in similar positions with packages with the same total employment cost, then a PSS member would receive significantly more salary than a CSS member. Presumably, this would be achieved through increasing the base salary of the PSS member rather than reducing the base salary of the CSS member. However, significantly different salary increases such as this could not be justified.

The alternative approach would be to exclude the employer contributions under the CSS and PSS schemes from the salary package. The package would then be $x plus superannuation, rather than $y including superannuation. As you will note from Appendix 2, employer superannuation contributions are not always costed when provided. This approach would be justified on the basis that different superannuation benefits are paid now, and that legislation prohibits people from transferring between schemes.

This approach would also avoid the problem that the figures quoted above are average costs only, and that individuals within the one scheme will receive different benefits depending on their personal circumstances, such as age at entry. The logical extension of an argument to differentiate between schemes is that we should also do so between individuals. We would then need to identify each individual's superannuation benefit, even though this is not possible in a defined benefit scheme.
The option of not including superannuation in the salary package would not preclude people from sacrificing salary for an additional superannuation benefit.
QUESTIONS
. Should there be a limit on the proportion of salary which may be salary sacrificed?
. Should the menu of items which may be packaged be limited?
. What items should be included on this menu?
. Should administrative costs of packaged items be borne by the individual?
. Should CSS and PSS contributions be costed in salary packages?

ATTACHMENT B
Workplace Reform in HFS—Bulletin No. 6
11 September 1997
WORKPLACE REFORM in HFS
A MESSAGE FROM THE SECRETARY
Certified Agreement

I wrote to all staff on 28 July with some broad ideas for a Certified Agreement in HFS as a basis for discussion amongst focus groups. I have now begun to receive feedback from the focus groups and there are already a number of consistent themes emerging about how we manage in the Department and suggestions for doing things better.

In light of these, and some further work in Corporate Services guided by the Human Resources Management Committee, I believe we can begin now to put some flesh on the bones of a possible Agreement. I am keen for these proposals and options to be tested further by focus groups, and for those not participating in these groups to also have the opportunity to comment. Your feedback will help us to ensure that the draft Agreement, when finalised, responds as fully as possible to the diverse wishes and needs of staff across the Department.
These more specific suggestions and options build on the three themes I identified previously for the Agreement to support our corporate goals:
. skills development;
. performance management; and
. attracting and retaining staff.
SKILLS DEVELOPMENT
Skills development can be more formally structured into our remuneration and management systems through:
(a) Individual Development Plans for all staff linked to the proposed performance feedback system; and
(b) advancement within and across classification levels linked to both competence and performance.

The IDP process will involve consultation between individual staff and their supervisors, within a framework of required and expected skills for the respective classification and team. Progress against agreed plans should be reviewed twice yearly. The framework will take some time to develop, but good work is already underway through the skills audit process and the initiatives in several program areas. A first round of IDPs could be introduced during l997‐98 accepting that the system should be refined as we learn from experience.

Some changes to the classification structure are suggested below. These are intended, in part, to facilitate clearer career streaming to support advancement linked more directly to the development of relevant skills and competencies, as well as performance. It is important for us to recognise the different requirements of, for example, technical and professional staff, and to balance general competencies with the subject matter knowledge essential for our credibility and high performance.
PERFORMANCE MANAGEMENT

An effective performance management system is critical to overall performance improvement and it is essential that such a system encompass all staff within HFS. Ideally, it should include 360 degree feedback and be closely linked with pay advancement and individual development plans. There should also be close links with our corporate and business planning processes.

An ideal system would build on those things which motivate us already such as concern for our clients, a strong sense of public service and professional values of excellence and objectivity. It would incorporate monetary and non‐monetary rewards, and rewards for teams as well as individuals.

My own view is that we do not combine all these elements very well, and there is a reluctance both to recognise and reward top performance and to address seriously poor performance. Some previous experience in performance based pay has caused many staff to be cautious about trying again. Yet, we must, at the very least, review existing arrangements, such as promotion and incremental advancements which are meant to be based on merit and performance.
Specific suggestions and options include:
Performance feedback and management
Performance Feedback

. A performance feedback system for all staff integrated with other HRM functions including remuneration, rewards, inefficiency, probation and discipline; it would also be integrated with Individual Development Plans. The program could be introduced before a new broad banded salary structure is implemented in 1998 by way of initial performance agreements (and IDPs) from the beginning of l998 for those without them at present.
Probation

. Probationary arrangements should be linked to the performance management system including the performance feedback program and inefficiency. A further option is the use of probationary promotions, subject to any requirements under the new Public Service Act.
Inefficiency
. Streamline the inefficiency process and integrate with the performance feedback system, relying on internal rather than external review processes.
New Classification Structure
Links to performance management and remuneration

. The Government Policy Parameters for agreement making require that the new APS structure be implemented in the life of the first certified agreement or by no later than the end of l998. The Department proposes to introduce a new performance based salary progression system from l July l998.
Detailed proposals are still being developed, but the core of a new performance‐based classification structure might include:

‐ streaming classifications into key career groups for HFS that might be linked to competencies and performance processes; the streams might comprise, for example, a general professional stream (for most policy areas), the different technical/specialist professional streams, an administrative stream and a management stream (an alternative is to fully broadband such streams, possibly along the lines suggested by the Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business);

‐ replacing `increments' with pay advancement more strictly tied to assessments of performance and competence (an alternative is to introduce for all staff a performance based bonus scheme that does not get built into the base pay);
‐ promotion within streams to be based on criteria which give proper recognition to performance and competence, including experience‐at‐level.

. At this stage, team reward arrangements are based only on the non‐monetary (or small monetary) awards arrangements. Options could be developed for monetary rewards for teams, but I would caution against any expectation that it would be easy to design an acceptable and fair system for teams, that involves significant monetary rewards.
Initial Impact

. The Department guarantees that staff would be translated at least at their current dollar salary level and, in addition, on approving an agreement staff would receive a salary increase yet to be determined.
RETENTION AND ATTRACTION OF STAFF

I have previously mentioned that our remuneration strategy needs to reflect our labour market reality and the need to assess our relative attractiveness to the skilled people we need to keep and recruit. Market rates assessments assist us in this regard and we have been gathering data on this to help frame the way ahead. Regular market surveys will be undertaken to ensure we have evidence on which to better inform our decision making about our remuneration arrangements. Such information will be made available to staff and their unions.

We must do a number of other things to be "the employer of choice" such as flexible employment arrangements (eg. work and family policies), effective recruitment systems and individual development planning. Things we should pursue include:
Competitive Remuneration and Salary Progression
Recognition and Rewards
. The performance feedback system will not only facilitate good communication and feedback but also provide an effective vehicle to equitably reward staff.
Salary progression within pay band

. Pay advances (and/or bonuses) will be paid on the basis of attained performance results, measured by both competencies and performance. Pay bands could be widened to improve rewards for good performers.
Competitive remuneration

. A balance needs to be drawn in the Agreement between an across‐the‐board pay increase, and an increase subject to performance results. If there is evidence that changes in pay relativities are required in response to market pressures (eg. for particular technical skills) then that might be achieved through selectively offering higher increases subject to performance results, while keeping a standard across‐the‐board increase in pay for all staff. Within the context of competitive remuneration we also have the option of offering salary packaging to all staff.
Balancing Work and Private Lives
Leave Packaging

. This system involves combining sick leave on full pay and half pay with special leave (parental carers leave) to make, say, l8 days personal leave per year, which is fully accumulative. That is, sick leave could be used for family/carer responsibilities.
Definitions for leave
. Access to personal leave and bereavement leave might recognise a broader definition of immediate family or household.
Carryover of 48/52 Scheme

. The HSH Agency Bargaining Agreement 1994 introduced a scheme that provided for staff to purchase additional leave of up to 4 weeks per year. Although the take up of this leave by staff has been somewhat limited, feedback from focus groups has indicated that staff still value the scheme. On that basis the intention is to ensure this leave provision carries into the new agreement. It may be possible to supplement this with a provision for half pay recreation leave?
Part‐time Work (PTW)

. This initiative aims to streamline the access to PTW for staff and the onerous administrative processes for approving variations to PTW on agreement of all parties. Teams might have authority to grant access to PTW for a team member taking into account operating requirements, budgets, etc. as well as changes in personal circumstances of the team member.
Public Holidays
. This initiative allows managers to grant alternative religious/cultural public holidays to their staff, ie. a substitution scheme.
Working Hours and Flextime

. This initiative would broaden the bandwidth to 7.00am to 8.00pm. This means overtime would not be paid between these hours. Staff would also be able to work normal hours on a weekend if their manager approved the arrangement taking into account such things as building operating costs, supervision, etc.
Home Based Work

. This initiative aims to provide greater access to home based work—we aim for a better win‐win outcome by reviewing the cost structure, assessing the real risks and placing greater onus on staff to meet OH&S and security obligations, and fit out while minimising the costs to the agency. Work teams might have authority regarding home based arrangements for a team member taking into account operating requirements, budgets, etc.
HR SIMPLIFICATION AND DEVOLUTION OF RESPONSIBILITY WITH MATCHING ACCOUNTABILITY TO MANAGERS AND TEAMS

Simplification of our human resource management practices can assist greatly in achieving more effective devolution and in freeing up resources. I have outlined below some initiatives we could pursue to simplify the way we manage our people issues, and to give greater responsibility and accountability for people management issues to managers and teams.
Better Management Process:
Discipline and Grievances

. The Department will undertake to review these processes in consultation with staff after proclamation of the new Public Service Act with a view to simplified internal processes. The purpose is to avoid unnecessary delay, expense and legalism and to ensure quick, fair and realistic resolution of problems that can otherwise damage all the staff affected directly or indirectly.
Allowances
Higher Duties Allowance

. When a job becomes temporarily vacant the expectation would be that the team share the duties without any additional allowance, subject to such duties being within the training, skill and competence of staff members. Longer periods may require negotiation between the team members and the team leader for some form of recognition for team members undertaking such duties, including payment or other reward.
Senior Officer Expense Allowance

. This allowance provides for the amalgamation of the allowance into salary and it would now count as salary for superannuation purposes for SOs. Amalgamation takes away a high administrative workload.
Travelling Allowance and Single Day TA

. This initiative would abolish part day TA for staff travelling by air or rail and develop a reimbursement system for those travelling by road. A review of TA might examine the flexibility of contract accommodation arrangements with payment by the Department directly rather than to the individual. We would look to achieve the maximum concessions from our travel contracts, such as group bookings.
First Aid, Motor Vehicle, Language, Eyesight Testing, Disability Allowances
. Review these allowances to see how and why they are paid. Single rates of allowance, cessation or change to administration procedures are options.
Excess Travelling Time Allowance

. The intention would be to abolish this provision given the very low use and application within the Department, the complexity and inequity of the allowance, and the unreasonably high administration costs for the allowance.
Restriction (On Call)

. Restriction Allowance is payable to a small number of staff required to remain available for recall to duty outside of normal hours generally in relation to security issues or IT support functions. The allowance has complex rules and a high administrative workload in its current form. Introduction of a standard $2 per hour rate for all restriction could significantly reduce the costs of administering payment of the allowance without impacting greatly on the entitlements of the individual staff in receipt of the allowance. Restriction allowance would be paid for the full period of restriction with no deduction for overtime worked.
Remote Locality Allowances

. This initiative removes access to remote locality provisions for new locally engaged staff. Current staff would continue to receive their allowances for a set period. Alternatively we could adopt an option to cash out remote locality allowances or roll them into one allowance to reduce workload in administering these complex provisions. For new recruits to remote localities it would be open to the Department to negotiate transfer/locality costs through an individual Australian Workplace Agreement.
Relocation Allowances

. Rationalisation of allowances and reimbursement arrangements to take up appointment, transfer or promotion within the Department. Give greater discretion to managers to negotiate a package with each staff member.
Loss or damage to clothing
. Removal of access to claims of less than $50 as administrative costs often exceed the cost of the claim.
AGREEMENT FUNDING OPTIONS

I know from the feedback I have received from focus groups that staff are concerned at the prospect of a trade‐off between jobs and a pay rise. That is, people obviously don't want to lose their job or their workmates' job because of a pay rise. I appreciate this concern, but do not see the issue as a one‐dimensional trade‐off. We will have to pay for the skills and people we need if we truly aspire to be an organisation that is best practice and achieves the highest levels of performance in the interests of better and more effective delivery of Government programs. If we are to be an employer of choice for existing staff and for staff who we want to attract to HFS, then we have to adjust our remuneration in line with that of our `competitors'.

Equally, many staff have already mentioned inefficiencies in our current processes which need to be addressed. It would be quite wrong to continue such processes under a misguided desire to protect employment.

Of course we can only work within the resources we have been given by Government and as such we will need to cut our cloth to suit and carefully calculate any pay increase which is part of the certified agreement. But I believe there are a number of options open to us which do not imply an unreasonable jobs/pay tradeoff. These include:
. the 1.5% Safety Net Adjustment (SNA) provided in annual supplementation by the Government;

. examining our work practices to more effectively use our operating budgets thus producing savings—for example, re‐engineering our work places in Divisions, State and Territory Offices, and Programs;

. trading off costly and inflexible employment arrangements to produce more effective and efficient outcomes whilst at the same time producing savings—for example, reducing our expenditure on higher duties allowance;
. other savings initiatives to reduce operating costs—for example, gaining the best price through our travel contract arrangements; and
. staging our pay increases and linking them genuinely to performance and competence.

What this means is that within a context of continuous improvement we will need to seek the highest level of productivity and to examine our expenditure, structures, processes and procedures. Our aim should be to free up funds for high priority purposes and such savings can be shared directly with staff in the form of pay rises. Simplification of HR processes is one example of finding savings. We will need to further reengineer our business practices and structures to facilitate better and more cost effective outcomes.

I encourage all staff to contribute ideas for achieving real savings across their areas of activity. I would like to see in our certified agreement a commitment by all of us in the Department to continually examine our expenditure items and our management processes and structures to see whether there are more efficient and effective ways of going about our business.
TIMING

I would like to see a certified agreement concluded before the end of 1997 with a proposed date of implementation being 1 January 1998, such that the benefits including increases to salary can flow to all staff at that time. Pay performance based increases could flow from l July l998.
AUSTRALIAN WORKPLACE AGREEMENTS (AWAs)

Government policy provides that certified agreements provide for AWAs. I believe AWAs would be suitable for the SES and Medical Officers and perhaps other categories such as Senior Officers A and B. If the Public Service Act is amended it may be possible to offer some senior staff AWAs on the basis of a trade off of tenure for a "loss of tenure" allowance. I do not propose to use AWAs to place all senior staff on fixed term appointment, and I am very keen for HFS to maintain support for a career‐based Australian Public Service.
CONTINUING CONSULTATION

We have been undertaking a very detailed consultation process to provide a context for workplace reform in HFS and to better understand the issues which staff see as important. We are also looking at how we can broaden that consultation, for example, staff representatives who would represent the staff who do not belong to a union. Your ideas and preferences about how we can more effectively consult with all staff would be welcomed.
FEEDBACK

I welcome your feedback on the proposals put forward. In particular I would like these to be discussed in focus groups and more widely in workgroup discussions, but most importantly I need to know what people are saying. So I would ask that staff or groups of staff give feedback to the team working on the workplace reform issues (see attached).

Lastly I appreciate some staff may have concerns with some of the items being proposed. This is an inevitable part of industrial agreement‐making; moreover, in an organisation as diverse as HFS it is not possible to achieve "all things for all people". I would ask that you carefully consider what we are trying to achieve and how the Agreement might best support the Department in meeting its responsibilities and its vision for the future while providing a competitive level of remuneration and conditions for staff members.
A S Podger
Secretary
WORKPLACE REFORM in
Health & Family Services
